title: Moving tour of infamous fortress, part of the transatlantic slave trade
text: A tour of Elmina Castle is a must for any visitor to Ghana who is interested in history and an understanding of the infamous slave trade. Dating from 1482, this is the oldest surviving fortress in sub Saharan Africa that housed captured slaves headed for the Americas.  To take a guided tour of the “castle” and its slave dungeons, including the Door of No Return, is both fascinating and incredibly moving, affording insights into the horrific slave trade in ways that cannot be appreciated through books or even films.

title: Haunting
text: Elmina Castle was one of the hundreds of holding prisons for black men, women and children who had been kidnapped and were about to be shipped to other parts of the world as slaves, never to return to their home and families.  Our excellent guide gave much information about this trade and what it would have been like for these people. It horrified and haunted us. I had heard quite a bit about the slave trade, but not fully understood the size and horror of this mass kidnapping and displacement of people, over so long a period of time and by so many countries occupying Africa at the time. This important part of history warrants greater acknowledgement and understanding.

title: Important, interesting, and underdeveloped attraction
text: Historically important and interesting site. While clean, the location is somewhat neglected and unkept. So much potential to develop and maintain the site further. Heat is a major issue in both indoor and outdoor areas. Air condition should be installed, and exhibits better maintained. So much potential and many things could have been presented in appealing exhibitions and visuals, but there is no investment in upgrading the facility and its exhibits in what seems to have been a very long time. The tour guides however do a great job at presenting enough information without overloading visitors, while creating drama and interest throughout the visit.

title: Haunting
text: This was my second visit to Elmina Castle.  I think my one gripe is that they need to have organised tours at set times. There is more than one guide so if two groups happen to cross each other at the same time it can be difficult to hear what is being said. I also think that group sizes should be limited to a certain number. I was disappointed with the toilet facilities. This is a place that is extensively visited and there is no need to have toilets which are substandard. Great guide and very informative.

title: Elmina Castle and "The Door of No Return"
text:
Elmina Castle, in Ghana, was built by the Portuguese to protect the gold trade in 1482. Although the castle had different ownership over time, from the Portuguese, to the Dutch, and finally the British, it became a major center for the transatlantic slave trade. In the center of the Castle was the Catholic Church.

Elmina Castle, like other castles on the gold coast, were used to hold captured/ kidnapped enslaved Africans before they were loaded onto ships and sold in the Americas as a new workforce.

At this Castle, I was able to see the "Door of No Return" where my ancestors left their homeland to never return again. Our tour guide was outstanding!

title: Elmina Castle - A Day Trip to Take
text: If you are interested in the history of slavery, Elmina Castle is a must see.  This is not a joyful experience, but yet one that is a worthwhile visit.  The Castle was the largest of the several slave embarkation points along Ghana's coast.  As a reasonably well preserved landmark, there are guides available once you get there.  After an hour or two of walking around the castle, you will be thinking about how this human cruelty ever happened.  The exit known as the "doorway of no return" will prompt your thoughts to families with loved ones, children included, who, after months in dungeon quarters, were split apart and never saw each other again.   The only downside was the drive to get there.  With road disarray and construction, it took 3.5 hours to go 100 miles with a hired driver.  At least the continuous scenes of life along the roadside provided a view that was never boring.

title: Atmospheric
text: This castle is a strangely European piece of architecture reflecting the Portuguese, Swedes, Danes, Dutch and British that successively exploited this piece of Africa. It is amazingly well preserved with a Portuguese chapel dominating a claustrophobic, whitewashed courtyard. It is minor miracle these places survived to give one of few pieces of evidence for the transatlantic slave trade. Essential to visit alongside the Cape Coastal Castle nearby.

title: Ancestral Journey 🇬🇭
text: This was one of the things we wanted to do as Grandparents from Holland 🙏🇬🇭 We encourage every diaspora to visit the door of no return and pay their last respects with our Ancestors 🥰. Book your trip with Evo Tour Ghana (+233 558712206) our Tour Guide was very Knowledgeable and Experienced ❤️🥰

title: Bardzo atrakcyjny .
text: Budowany kilka lat przez portugalskich kolonistów został ukończony w roku 1486 . Potem przeszedł w ręce holenderskie i dalej brytyjskie aż do uzyskania przez Ghanę niepodległości w roku 1957 .Pomimo upływu wieków nadal prezentuje się bardzo atrakcyjnie . Miał przez wieki bardzo duże znaczenie handlowe a razem z innymi fortyfikacjami znaczenie militarne . Najczęściej jest kojarzony z niechlubnym handlem niewolnikami. To min  stąd niewolnicy wysyłani byli statkami do Ameryki .Do zobaczenia są lochy i cele w których przetrzymywano niewolników . Dawny portugalski kościół na placu zamkowym pełni obecnie rolę muzeum . Obejrzeć można również ufortyfikowane tarasy zamkowe z armatami chroniącymi przed agresorami . W głównym budynku jest też możliwość zakupu lokalnych pamiątek na kilku stoiskach . Po zamkowych pomieszczeniach można przemieszczać się swobodnie . Z różnych miejsc mamy ciekawe widoki na port rybacki i lagunę . Warto z tej okazji skorzystać .

title: On the must-see list, sobering but well done
text:
Elmina castle is a must-do, especially for Westerners. Don't be turned off by the aggressive sellers approaching you as you arrive. Ignore them and keep walking. Once at the entrance, it is calm and friendly. Our guide was very knowledgable, answered unexpected questions well, was friendly and warm. The tour of course walks you through the dark history of this slave trading castle. Hard to hear at times, but a necessary education to fully understand the history and how it impacts generations to come. There is an opportunity near the end to offer libations to the ancestors and give money to sponsor a wreath in their honor. 

At the end I highly recommend shopping at the 2 (maybe 3?) small shops. We did not negotiate prices here, and it was still much less than the shopping we did later in Accra. And these shops do not have highly assertive salesmen. 

There is a small "museum" as well, but it was just educational boards to read and we didn't find it of much interest following the great tour.

title: A dark period of history that needs to be understood.
text: A well preserved fort/castle that has passed through Portuguese, Dutch and British hands over the years. A place where you can learn about some of the terrible injustices of Empire and the slave trade. Not an easy visit but a necessary and worthwhile one that teaches us the importance of history and the lessons we need to learn. The guides are knowledgable and informative.

title: An experience rich in emotions
text: I visited Elmina Castle with my class on a school trip we discovered where the transatlantic inhuman slave trade began. Different stands and uses of the castle according to the owners and operators since the 15th. Century: Portuguese, Dutch, Danish and British colonialisms Although this is a very educational visit, it is at the same time a very sad and emotional experience.  While the tour guide explained the slave trade, the unimaginable brutality and the incredible cruelty, we listened with tears in our eyes.  we learned a lot during this visit and I recommend visiting the castle if you are in Ghana 🇬🇭

title: Einblick in die Geschichte des Sklavenhandels
text: Ich bin mit dem Taxi zum Elmina Castle (Hin- und Rückfahrt und Wartezeit - 100 Cedi). Die Führung dauert eine Stunde, Eintritt 80 Cedi. Neben dem Cape Coast Castle ein weiteres Sklaven-Forts. Eine Führung vermittelt Einblicke in die Sklavengeschichte. Ich fand das Castle in Cape Coast interessanter, was sicherlich am Guide gelegen hat.

title: Must See
text:
Pay a visit Elmina Castle if you’re in the area.

The first European structure in sub-Saharan Africa, Elmina Castle towers over the Gulf of Guinea’s blue waters on one side and the bustling fishing village on the other. When the Portuguese erected this fortress in 1482, they built it to last. 540 years later the battlements stand strong and the hardwood floors and rafters are worn smooth with the passage of time. 

Spend an hour or two walking freely about the bastions and interior spaces. The sea breezes and commanding views provide ample incentive for reflective pauses. There’s even a small restaurant in the northeast corner where visitors can take refreshments and watch the townspeople’s fishing boats venturing to and fro. 

I traveled to Elmina castle with a local and we didn’t pay an entrance fee or hire a guide, but guides were standing ready to provide a tour. If visitors do some light reading prior to arrival, it’s quite a nice experience to do alone, at your own pace.

My only regret is that the government of Ghana doesn’t put a little more funding towards the maintenance of the window fittings and other small aspects of the building. Elmina Castle is a monument to engineering and exploration, as well as a testament to man’s cruelty during the colonial period.

title: What a visit
text: Emotional visit while one gets to know  where the unhuman transatlantic slaves‘ trade started. Different settlememts and usages for castle according to owiner and operators since the 15th. Century: Portoguise, Dutsch, Danes and Britisch colonialisms.

title: Da rabbrividire, anche con 40°!
text: antico forte, inglese, usato dagli schiavisti, come centro di raccolta degli schiavi deportati dalle loro case a chissà dove!💩

title: Incredibly Moving Experience
text: Our tour guide, Kwame, could not have been any better in describing the events of that period. He was extremely knowledgeable, genuine and well versed in describing the cruelty dished out to the slaves, as well as their families. This is definitely a must see attraction, along with the Slave River Park which brings the story full circle.

title: Memento from the dark past
text:
Although being a very educative tour, it is a very sad experience at the same time. As the tour guide explained the slave trade, the unimaginable brutality and the incredible cruelty, many visitors listened with tears in their eyes. Raises a lot of responsibility questions.
There are a lot of people outside of the castle who offer uninvited services, souvenirs, and they are very difficult to shake off. If you do not want to donate money (consider it as a charity) you`d better ignoring them

title: Our Tour Guide Martin was incredible!
text: I visited Elmina Castle with a large group earlier on this January. Our Guide's name was Martin and he was absolutely excellent. He gave a comprehensive history and context of the castle and the times when it would have been inhabited. He was really knowledgable and answered all our questions with sensitivity. The tour and content was just enough and perfectly timed given the heat. There is a rate for Ghanian's and one for tourists both of which are affordable. I would highly recommend!

title: Fascinating History
text: We visited as part of our tour from a cruise ship. It was a fascinating place and the facts were not "sugar-coated". Even with just a group of tourists in the dungeons you could feel how hot and oppressive they were and helped bring to life how bad the conditions must have been when there were very many more slaves being held there for weeks or months. We will never forget the Door of No Return.

Easy to locate.
This more of events hall for multi-purpose use.
I presume because of it's affiliation to the Musical Society of Nigeria, the acoustic in the halls are above average.
These halls  host  recitals, theatres, live plays, social events, board meetings  etc
The halls come in diffrent capacity
•	Shell Nigeria  Hall            Maximum 1,000 seats

Prices may range from $200  to circa  $5,000 per event

title: Event place
text: The event halls have different carring capacities. The parking space is big and secure. The facility is well maintained.

title: The Muson Centre
text: From musical theater to concerts to Fundraising shows or recitals, Muson centre is the IT place for all things Music and more in Lagos. For those with a taste for  Live performances ,stage plays and everything Music,be sure to visit the Muson centre. There is always a program or two going on.

title: Want to listen to Classical music?
text:
This is the go-to place for Classical music in Lagos. MUSON stands for the Musical Society of Nigeria and they run a music school on the premises. You should try to catch the annual MUSON week in October and there are also Christmas & Easter performances by the MUSON Orchestra & Choir which are always well attended.

If you are in Lagos at the right time you might even get to see one of the now increasingly rare stage plays.

The Halls also serve as venues for shows, meetings and even Church services so not all events there are musical events.

title: A First Class Event Place.
text: A great place for events hosting. Good soundproofing and sound reproduction is very great. However a local band will show itself especially with low quality musical equipment.

title: Venue for good classical music
text: The MUSON Centre will always live up to expectations as a very good place to listen to good classical music. The other function rooms also play host to several events. The venue is likewise central somehow to link to Victoria Island and the Mainland; there are options of how to navigate round

title: Very comfortable place
text: I've been privileged to watch recitals, small concerts, plays and shows in this place for the last 23 years of my life. It has always been a pleasant experience. It's smack in the middle of a busy part of Lagos but don't let that deter you. There's ample parking space most times and it's a secure location. Check out any events happening there and go have fun!

title: Amazing centre
text: This place is used for a lot of different activities especially activities connected with arts. I love how it is set up. You might want to find out what activities they have lined up for your enjoyment.

title: Interesting play at Muson Center
text: Saw a thought-provoking but funny play at the Muson Center. The theater hall was comfortable and well designed. Good view of the stage from all seats. Forehall also good location for before and after reception. All in all a great location for an outing.

title: Events
text: Muson centre is a multi-purpose center with some halls for hire (agip hall, shell hall etc.). I've attended quite a number of shows (SARO, stand up 9ja etc.) there.

title: For the finer things
text:
If you're one that enjoys the finer things like 'live theatre' and the likes. This is the place to catch em. The halls are large and comfy,especially the Shell Hall. 
It's also a good place to host conferences and meetings.

title: Good to host conferences,seminars etc
text: I attended a conference in one of the halls shell hall precisely. The hall is big and very fit for that purpose

title: Lovely!
text: The Muson Centre is a great multi purpose center. Located on the Marina, Onikan, it is home to a fantastic restaurant, a great music hall which presents music, recitals, plays, concerts, etc The centre is also a venue for weddings. Lovely!

title: Electrifying
text: The Muson Centre is electrifying. Whether for musical, stage drama, meeting  etc, it is a promise assured. Regular visits all year round.

title: Nigerian Broadway Show
text: The Muson Center is the place to be if you love ''Live theater''. This the second time I will be attending a musical at the center. The first was  ''SARO'' and the second is ''WAKAA". It's a great place to watch a live stage performance. Both performances  were electrifying. The costumes, the music, the singing, the choreography, the lighting, Really wonderful.

title: Counting the human cost
text:
This was a very moving experience, as it brought to life the real human cost of slavery. It was distressing to think of the conditions endured by the captives.  Our guide gave a good description and explanation of everything we saw. 
We actually went in April 2024, but the website does not give us an option to use the correct date.

title: The biggest slave castle in Ghana, est. 1665
text: The Cape Coast Castle(1665), formerly the Caroulsborg fort (1653) is the biggest slave castle in Ghana. The place is solemn, I felt sad during the tour because there was so much history to unpack.

title: A must-see UNESCO site, full of history
text: We toured Cape Coast Castle on a recent visit to Ghana.  The Castle, with its dungeons where enslaved people were held before their transportation overseas, is full of history.  A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Castle’s dark, dank dungeons are moving reminders — as is its infamous Door of No Return — of the horrors of the slave trade.  The knowledgeable guide gave context to all of the history of the place, including its origins as a fort, as a trading post, and as the last stop for slaves before they were put on ships bound for the Americas.  This is a must-see.

title: Cape Coast Castle – A Journey Through History
text:
Cape Coast Castle, located on Ghana’s central coast, is one of the most significant historical sites in West Africa. This UNESCO World Heritage Site stands as a powerful reminder of the transatlantic slave trade, offering visitors a deeply emotional and educational experience.

Historical Significance

Built by the Swedes in the 1650s and later controlled by the British, Cape Coast Castle was a major hub for the transatlantic slave trade. The castle’s dungeons, where enslaved Africans were held before being shipped to the Americas, leave a haunting impression. Walking through these dark, airless rooms gives a chilling glimpse into the suffering endured by countless men and women.

Tour Experience

Guided tours are available, led by knowledgeable guides who provide a detailed and moving account of the castle’s history. The Door of No Return, through which captives were forced onto slave ships, is one of the most powerful stops on the tour. However, there is also the Door of Return, symbolizing the resilience of African descendants who revisit their ancestral homeland.

Architecture & Scenic Views

Beyond its somber history, the castle itself is an impressive structure, featuring whitewashed walls and breathtaking views of the Atlantic Ocean. The contrast between the beauty of the surroundings and the tragic history within the walls adds to the site’s emotional impact.

Museum & Exhibits

The on-site museum provides valuable context with artifacts, documents, and displays about the slave trade, Ghanaian culture, and colonial history. It’s a great addition to the tour, helping visitors gain a deeper understanding of the past.

Verdict

Cape Coast Castle is a must-visit for history enthusiasts, students, and anyone seeking to understand the impact of the transatlantic slave trade. While the experience can be heavy and emotional, it is an important reminder of history and resilience. The only drawback is that the site can get crowded during peak tourist seasons, and some areas could use better maintenance.

Final Thoughts

A visit to Cape Coast Castle is not just a tour—it’s an unforgettable lesson in history, humanity, and remembrance. Highly recommended for anyone traveling to Ghana.

title: Reminder of Skavery History with Message to Move Forward
text:
Our group of 12 received a tour of the castle with entrance to male  quarters, female quarters, and solitary confinement area.  The tunnel, now closed, that led to the door of no return shows the path from confinement in the castle to the ships where people were sent to slavery in the West. Our guide was educated, well spoken, and compassionate. He answered all our questions and managed to move our group through the place which was crowded with tours today 
Restrooms and parking

title: Worthy visit
text: my first time leaving Germany and visiting Ghana and had a great time, the castle is a highlight of my time in cape coast, very knowledgable and learnt a lot about the history of Ghana.

title: Great tour but smaller groups please
text: Visited Cape Coast Castle today and Thomas was our guide. He was very informative and I enjoyed the visit very much. I do think the guides need to be more forthright with visitors. We were in a big group so it was difficult enough to hear what was being said without phones going off and people talking. Great experience. Toilets very poor.

title: Amazing day trip
text: A fun filled tour. Our guide malik arranged everything nicely. We were thrilled with the educational concept of the site,the start to the finish of the trip  was an exceptional. M&T Ghana Travel and tour are the best.

title: Memorable, sobering
text:
They say that is one of three places in Africa you must visit to understand African history better. This austere fortress is a real testament to the evils of the transatlantic slave trade and the impact on the continent. The industrial scale level of human trafficking is a tough thing to learn about but a valuable lesson to be learnt. 

The tour takes around forty minutes, the castle is smaller than Elimina but the featureless white washed buildings feel more sinister.

title: Zamek niegodziwego handlu .
text: Ze swą zawiłą historią jako obiekt militarny przysłużył  się przede wszystkim handlowi niewolników. Swój obecny wygląd zamek uzyskał pod koniec XVIII wieku .   W jego lochach i celach jednorazowo mieściło się ok 1500 niewolników . Niewolnictwo to był najbardziej opłacalny handel . Do dzisiaj zachowały się w dobrym stanie [ po renowacjach ] zamkowe budynki i imponująca kolekcja armat i kul armatnich . Znajduje się tu również nieduże muzeum etnograficzne . Znajdziemy tu także wiele sklepów z lokalnymi wyrobami i świetną kawiarenkę z klimatycznym wystrojem .

title: Guiding services par excellence
text: amazing history told with passion by an expert in heritage tourism. Professiona tourism par excellence. Congratulations

title: Sobering
text:
They organize 45 min guided tours on the hour. I recommend joining one to hear the history of the castle and better understand what happened there. Sobering experience.
Beside the tragic history, the castle is nice to see and has great views of the nearby fishing harbour, especially from the top levels of the harbour. Great for taking in the atmosphere

title: Eine Führung die einem nahe geht
text:
Ich war vormittags dort und konnte noch zu einer Gruppenführung dazustoßen. Eintritt 80 Cedi. Die Führung dauert ca. 1 Stunde. Man bekommt einen sehr guten Einblick in die Geschichte des Sklavenhandels. Die Geschichte ist Es werden verschiedene Räume gezeigt und sehr detailliert beschrieben, wozu sie dienten. Zum Teil sehr bedrückend. Zuerst werden die Räume der Sklaven gezeigt, die auf engsten Raum gefangen gehalten wurden - danach werden die Hallen des Gouverneurs gezeigt. Dort ist auch ein Souvenirshop, der günstig ist (2 Schlüsselanhänger 20 Cedi). 
Interessante und zugleich bedrückende Tour.

title: Major Slave Castle
text: This is a castle site first developed by the Swedes with a log fort and finally passed down to the British who built the fort into its final form.  It has slave dungeons and a gate of no return.  There is an admission cost, bathrooms and exhibits.

title: Cape Coast Castle
text:
History of how I ended up in babylon.
Come and here the truth for yourself.  School just don't cut it.

title: Excellent and powerful
text:
This is a hard and confronting experience, but a necessary one.  There is much sadness and terror in the story of this place, but there is a resolution, powerful in its simplicity.  It may seem counterintuitive to do something emotionally hard while you're on holiday, but the pain is but a fraction of what was felt by those stolen, starved, imprisoned in the worst conditions, raped and deprived of sunlight and air.  There are three places where tributes of flowers can be laid - try to take natural flowers so that they can degrade naturally and, I suppose, become one with the castle.

This is not a place to take happy snaps, and if you lack melanin, just hang back, be quiet, and recognise that it is our kind who were the masters.  There is a peace to be found here, but also a responsibility.

title: Moving Experience
text: Very moving but informative. Stairs are a little hard for my 76 years old legs, but I did it! We must never let this mistreatment happen again!

title: A must see for everyone
text: We visited the slave "castles" (more like dungeons) on Juneteenth, and it was an experience of a lifetime.   I would highly recommend making a trip here if visiting Ghana.  Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and informed us of many details of the slave trade frequently not taught in history classes.  While it did bring a mix of emotions, I was glad to have be able to see everything firsthand.  For most of us, it was the highlight of our trip.

title: The Transition of the Cape Coast Castle
text:
Great History. 
The Castle was built in the year 1664 by the British.
Before that the Portuguese were the first to settle on the land In the year 1555. Later on the Swedish and fought them in the year 1655.

title: Cape Coast Slave "Castles"
text:
The tour of the Cape Coast Castle was informative, eye-opening, and heart wrenching. I feel everyone who visits Ghana should visit and learn about what went on there.  I'm not really sure why they are called "castles" when such horrific treatment of African people went on there.  They should be called slave dungeons. 

Make sure you have this and the Elmina Castle on your itinerary when you visit Cape Coast, Ghana!

title: Quaint and rustic
text: Quaint and rustic, the first time we'd ever stayed in a round, thatched accommodation, painted with traditional designs. The bed was clean and comfortable. The food was delicious and served outdoors under the stars. Selena was an excellent hostess. Lovely handmade baskets and pottery for sale at reasonable prices in the adjacent store. We also had a lesson on potttery making- no need to tip because there is a charge for this.

title: Hands-on experience at art&crafts
text: The highlight for me was participating in painting, pottery, and weaving classes - this gives you some hint on what it really takes to weave a basket and how we don't appreciate this hard work trying to buy beautiful baskets very cheap. Otherwise the room was good with slight running water problems, the food was plenty and delicious and the staff very friendly. I wish more people were coming to meet these art ladies in the centre. The prices are very reasonable and definitely it was money really well spent.

title: A Truly Wonderful Experience
text:
I stayed for a week in Swopa while visiting a friend in Sirigu. 
The first two days I spent in the dorm room which holds five beds and has two bathrooms and has ceiling fans.
 I then moved into one of the gorgeous self contained bungalows with ensuite shower & toilet and air conditioning.  Both type of rooms were clean although the bathrooms are basic.
While there I attended a painting workshop which was good fun.
The staff are helpful & friendly, the food tasty.
I love this place and am already planning a return visit.

placeInfo.name: SWOPA Ecolodge and Restaurant
placeInfo.address: Bolgatanga Road Sirigu Central, Bolgatanga Ghana

title: Must visit for anyone in Ghana
text: Visiting SWOPA is a must for anyone who truly wants to get in touch with ghanaian culture. The rooms are amazing and the food is delicious. The pottery and weaving workshops are highly advisable. The shop offers all kinds of traditional pottery and baskets at very reasonable prices. Having lived in Ghana for a while, I know what the right prices are for things here. Usually when you want to buy something, you have to bargain. Locals will then ask ridiculous prices sometimes because they can see you're not Ghanaian. At SWOPA all prices are fixed and all objects are labeled with their price. This makes for a very pleasant and fair shopping experience. If you are interested in buying traditional art or pottery: this is the place to do so. The people are very friendly and for a small fee, someone can drive you around the mesmerising and peaceful landscape.

placeInfo.name: SWOPA Ecolodge and Restaurant
placeInfo.address: Bolgatanga Road Sirigu Central, Bolgatanga Ghana

title: Rustic and Peaceful
text:
Subject: Sirigu Women's Organisation for Pottery and Art Guest House
Location: Bolgatanga, Upper East Region, Ghana, Africa
Title: Rustic and peaceful
ID#: 290117711

Spent 3 days at SWOPA and had a wonderful time. Took Arts classes in the morning and went on several different tours in the afternoon. My brain if fully expanded. The staff are very accommodating and were eager to help as much as needed. Sirigu is up in the most northern part of rural Ghana and was quite a bit more arid and hot as compared to the coast. Took an afternoon tour off grounds and a walking tour of area painted traditional homes. Albert, our tour guide, was very knowledgeable about the area and history. Faustina, the coordinator of the arts classes was invested in our success and enjoyment of the crafts. 

The guest house facilities were rustic but clean. Round traditional huts with electricity and running water (most of the time) Not a 5 star hotel, but mostly clean and comfortable. The extra 15 cedis was well worth the air conditioning.  Electricity was partially solar powered so even with lights out fans and lights work. Water pressure and warmth was great. Food was ok. Food choices were limited.  I will definitely be going back when others come to visit.   We stayed 3 days which was a good amount of time.

placeInfo.name: SWOPA Ecolodge and Restaurant

title: ガーナ北部のアート体験村
text: ガーナアッパーイースト州ナブロンゴ近くの、アフリカンアートの体験が出来るゲストハウスです。宿舎全体がシリグアートで可愛く仕上がっており楽しめます。食事やアート体験は事前に電話で予約する必要があります。アート体験は半日程度の滞在時間があった方が、落ち着いて描けます。お土産も併設のクラフトショップで買うことが出来ます。宿舎の屋根は上れるようになっており、周辺も静かな村なので、夜には満天の星空を静かな環境で眺めることができます。夕食のTZ、朝食のレモングラスティーが絶品です。籠バックで有名なニャリガ村も近いです。

placeInfo.name: SWOPA Ecolodge and Restaurant
placeInfo.address: Bolgatanga Road Sirigu Central, Bolgatanga Ghana

title: El primer museo del país para dar voz a las etnias que se encontraban en él.
text: Aquí podemos encontrar las famosas máscaras Gueledé muy logradas, sin ser las mejores de una cultura que debería tener una colección propia y una serie de ilustraciones de sociedades secretas muy representativas de lo que es el vudú en Benín. Sin ir más lejos, más allá de la leyenda, el considerado fundador de Porto Novo es el creador de la sociedad secreta de Zangbetos que aquí aparece.

title: Buen guia y muy interesante
text: Este museo nos ha parecido un museo ilustrativo de las etnias africanas y de sus costumbres y la explicación del guia fue bastante buena.

title: Peu de moyens, peu d'objets
text:
Le Musée, dont l'entrée est gratuite (!) est abrité dans une jolie bâtisse coloniale qui vaut en elle-même le détour mais les collections sont tout de même assez décevantes : de malheureux objets posées sans arrangement et couverts de poussière (le manque de moyens n'empêche pas de dépoussiérer de temps en temps, surtout que les touristes ne se bousculent pas...). Certains objets n'ont rien d'authentiques et ne valent pas mieux que ceux que l'on voit sur les marchés. 
À la fin de la visite on vous mène vers un petit local où quelques tissus de coton tissé sont en vente, le tout présenté par un enfant (en semaine y a pas école?!)
Bref, malgré les efforts de notre guide de bonne volonté, la pauvreté du projet saute aux yeux. Dommage car il y aurait tant à faire!

title: Free, wonderful guide, nice short stop.
text: Very knowledgeable and friendly guide. Museum has moderate content but provide very interesting information about history and tradition.

title: Disappointing
text: A few masks, a few stories, nice building. We came with natural hunger to learn about the various tribes in the country, and met a small, rundown, neglected set of masks and a bit more. So disappointing ,

title: Benin historiamuseo Porto-Novossa
text:
Kohde sijaitsee Porto-Novon keskustassa. 

Isohko rakennus, jossa kaksi kerrosta museon käytössä. Ilmainen sisäänpääsy (vapaaehtoinen maksu oppaalle) sisälsi käyntimme aikana ranskankielisen oppaan, joka opasti läpi museon. 

Jos ranskankieli ei suju on heillä tarjota englanninkielinen kirjanen oppaaksi kierrokselle. 

Naamioita, mallinukkeja, päähineitä, käyttöesineitä...

Jos kaupungissa vierailet on kohde toki käytävä katsastamassa mutta mitenkään järisyttävän hyvä kokemus ei ole kyseessä. Toki saat paremman kuvan kohdemaasta. 

Sisäpihalla kangaspuut, joilla valmistettuja kankaita mahdollista ostaa muutamalla eurolla.

Kuvaaminen kielletty sisätiloissa. 

Pieni osa näyttelyesineistä omasi englanninkielisen kuvauksen. Kirjassa kohteet oli kaikki englanniksi lueteltu. 

Ei lapsiystävällinen.

title: musee ethnographique de porto_novo benin
text: situe en pleine ville de porto_novo au benin,le musee ethnographique de porto_novo est la deuxieme musee de porto_novo apres le musee honmè.il accueille beaucoup de tourisques et visiteurs tous les jours

title: Quirky and interesting
text: We walked in and found an excellent guide that took us around the museum. Fascinating collection and great overview of Benin, the history and culture. Definitely the best musuem in Porto Novo and on my top 5 for Benin.

title: A place to learn about the people of Benin republic
text:
This is a good idea and when I bring people on a trip with Anago Osho Adventures, the first thing I do is to make the tourists learn about the different culture and way of life of the environment people.

The museum is rich with information but the management need to promote the place more for everyone to benefit from the rare collections.

title: Interesting history and museum
text: This museum is simple but provides an interesting history of Benin. Our guide spoke English and was helpful, but there was another person who walked around with us to turn the lights on and off which seemed unnecessary. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area as it's a small space but provides a good amount of history.

title: For one hour in history
text: Stopped there with a friend after a moto tour of the town. The history is revealed again but it is strictly forbidden to take photos

title: Faut bien
text:
Très peu de monuments et musée au Pérou. Donc quand on en voit un il faut en profiter. 
La ville a été délaissée par ses propres politiciens qui avaient peur que le président leur prenne leur électorat. Ils refusaient tous projets venant de l'état. Bilan une ville sans équipements ,peu de routes. l'attrait réside dans la personnalité d'habitants qui soulèvent la dignité de la ville.

title: Et à la fin, le drame
text: Un sympathique petit musée : la collection n'est pas très grandes mais il y a quelques belles pièces. Le guide s'est démené pour rendre la visite vivante et n'a pas été avare d'explications mais... à la fin il nous emmène voir deux métiers à tisser traditionnel dans la cour dont l'un est activé par un enfant. Pas très normal dans un musée national.

title: Une perle
text:
Cette maison d'habitation au riche passé aujourd'hui transformée en musée ethnologique, par son architecture et l'histoire de ses occupants nous apporte des éléments qui nous aident à mieux comprendre la richesse historique du Benin 
Notre guide par son humour et ses commentaires a été une aide précieuse 

Une visite indispensable

title: la ville de porto_novo au bénin
text: c'est vraiment très formidable d'aller au bénin pour visiter des lieux historiques on peut y aussi visiter d'autres villes du bénin

title: This is a MUST to understand the religious/cultural history and customs of Benin
text: It is small museum; we were only allowed to visit the downstairs of an old house converted for this purpose.  So it won´t take you long.  But you see masks and disguises used in traditional dances and ceremonies.   Unfortunately, photos are not allowed.

title: Overview of local culture and history
text: Although it is only a small exhibit in French, the guide did an excellent job of explaining each piece in clear English. We got a very good overview of the history and culture of the country. As always, the more you ask, the more you learn and get out of the tour.

title: The Benin's history and the museum where understands a tradition
text:
At a 2-story museum, a contracted guide guides me.
Photography is prohibited in the inside.
I arrive by car from Cotonou for approximately one hour.

title: Marchez sur les traces de Tintin (L'Oreille Cassée)
text: Ce musée est un passage incontournable lors d'une visite à Porto-Novo. Les guides sont sympathiques et la collection particulièrement intéressante (bien que limitée faute de place si je comprends bien). Cela me semble un bon aperçu de la culture locale.

title: Visite à faire avec un guide

title: Haggling for unique hand crafted items to remember my trip

title: Nigerian Market Shopping
text: Very good experience! Left with bags full of momentous including clothing, placements, fans, leather clutches  jewelry, etc….. Prices were beyond reasonable. It was hot so buy a handful of colorful fans upon arrival and use one to try and keep cool. I wish I could have returned another day without my children for more targeted shopping. Beautiful artwork and carvings but no room in suitcases to bring home. Felt safe and it was an amazing outing!

Overall, good place.

title: Intersting Hidden Gem

Lovely art Market, with just about anything in art and craft you are looking for. Shame the access road is so bad, but once you do arrive, you are greeted with endless rows of creative designs in clothing, furniture, home decorations, etc.
Good prices too. Be prepared for a good haggle, as initial asking process tend to be inflated 150%. A good guide is the cut the price in 3 and work your way up from there. But good  hidden gems if you take the time to look. I love my trips  here.

title: Our National treasure.
text: The National Art Theatre is one of the historical tour destination in Lagos. It is an ideal tourist destination for Private and Group tours. It is educative for the children and it is a place of history and an architectural master piece.

title: Great Picnic Atmosphere
text: Went picnicking and met quite a large number of other people out there with the same intention as ours. Didn't have access to the Art Gallery but the front view art work made a tremendous piece of great background for some nice pictures!

title: Beautiful Landscape
text:
Why bother going into the half functioning theater when there is enough beauty on the outside? The sculptures, the trees, the carvings on the walls, the architecture, the lakes, the submerged bridges, and roads, the lawns, the thick bushes, the horses, the picnickers, etc.

I did see a play there (Altine's Wrath) and it was thrilling. If there isn't a performance going on, just walk around the premises, it's relaxing. Or pack a picnic basket and find a quiet corner with your gang. Lovely place! (And they wanted to sell it off for a mall).

title: great building
text: i enjoyed the two hours there. looks as if the place is being fixed up. impressed at the lack of litter. gardens are pretty and the saying "far from the maddening crowed" is so true.. very piecefull... will be back

title: Nothing for 100 Naira
text:
We could not go into the theatre because a politician was there. We could only enter to a gallery which had very poor exibition. None of our questions about the pictures were answered, the same information was told us about them that we read next to the pictures. The worst gallery ecperience I have ever had.
1000 naira/person were charged for admission, we got no receit. Probably this was the same pocket support we had to give to some policemen and immigration officers.

title: NATIONAL ART THEATRE
text: The National Arts Theatre is the primary centre for the performing arts in Nigeria. The monument is located in Iganmu, Lagos State. Construction was completed in 1976 in preparation for the Festival of Arts and Culture in 1977.Between 1975, and July 2009, the National Theatre has been managed by six successive Administrators. In August 2009, a new General Manager assumed the headship of the National Theatre Management with a new vision.

title: Iconic Landmark in Lagos State
text: This Landmark is  embodied with so much history, being the first place Nigeria celebrated the biggest Tourism event, Festival of Arts and Culture in 1977 (FESTAC77). Built by a Bulgarian company and today its still use for a lot of cultural activities and events.

title: Coming Back
text:
I was happy to see that stage plays are coming back and people are embracing the idea.

It will be nice to make the National Theater environment more attrative to encourage turm out for activities held at that venue

title: The African Art Lives On
text: i was there watching the Musical Concert the atmosphere is great enough car park for everyone and its free also European dishes for breakfast/Lunch /Dinner ..Adequate security Personal for every one in the Theater and very clean and spacious Bathroom for ladies and Gentlemen .it must see

title: memory re-enact
text: it is one place a like going. it creates a warm welcome for people who history, culture and arts. I hope the management of the theatre would work on retouching some fading wall paints at the exterior.

title: What a waste of a beautiful and priceless treasure
text: Everything that should make a place great fun is there.  The movie theatre, arts theatre, artifacts, spaces for restaurants and eateries etc etc.  But corruption reigns supreme and the place is run down by the government people handling things.  My heart bled when I discovered the National Arts Theatre - what corruption can destroy.

title: nice place
text: This is one of the landmarks in Lagos State, a very prominent structure in the heart of the city. Well maintained but is neglected by people. also has cultural museum near by.

title: National Theatre built like a General's Hat
text: The National Theatre is one of Africa's greatest Landmarks rumored to be built like a General Ibrahim Babaginda's Hat. It is supposed to host plays, musical shows and cultural events, unfortunately, it is a relic, it has been neglected and the MUSON Centre now play's the roles the National Theatre ought to play. To me, it is more like an artifact, and I hope it isrejuvinated.

title: Neglected Masterpiece
text: This is one of Africa's best cultural and entertainment masterpieces.  The space and the idea behind the construction is amazing.  But equally amazing is the level of neglect this edifice has been subjected to.  Stinking corruption and mindless selfishness of those under whose care the facility is left is confounding.  It just takes one purposeful leader with integrity to restore the glory of Africa that is the National Arts Theatre.

title: Master piece nice place to visit
text:
This is a place for entertainment. It is well design to accommodate different forms of entertainment. Many school groups, cultural troops, dance groups etc come here for entertainment and presentation for international visitors ensure you have a guide and stick to your tour schedule and group so that you do not get missing.
Many years ago(1978) as a student of Queens college Yaba Lagos, we came for a musical concert here and I lost my group. It took three concerned vigilant older men to redirect me to my group. Thanks to my school uniform too

title: Fufu, Folks in Lagos, Nigeria: Continental fun!
text:
I. I was dropped off at the museum while my family and friends ran errands and shopped in the surrounding block. The electricity was out, but the light from the courtyard and windows was plenty. 
2. I’m sorry, but I took one or two photos. Loved all the exhibits. Found the gift shop person friendly and bought quite a few postcards. 
3. Mailed them to my parents. My mother thought the art inspiring. Later used them as a teaching aid.
4. I treasure the few I have left in a scrapbook.
5. When my family and friends all met again, we enjoyed refreshments and all traveled back to my dear sister, Oyediya Akinrinmade’s home — just across town.

title: Recent price as at Just 2023.
text:
I did not get to see anything. But I wanna let you in on the recent prices.
Children..500
Nigerian adults...1000
Foreigners... 1500
That's the current price

title: Was expecting more
text: A number of reviews and travel guides list this as a must visit. But to be honest, there is not much there. A guide shows you around and tells you exactly what is written on the signs next to the objects, but then asks for payment afterwards. Theres a few lovely objects to see, but more can be made of them. Only go if you have nothing else to do.

title: Not bad
text:
The National museum is old but definitely has good potential and still provided some valuable insights into some aspects of Nigeria's history, customs and traditions. Unfortunately taking of pictures within the museum itself isn't allowed, hence the lack of pictures here. A visit there starts off with a walk through the courtyard (after paying a N300 entry fee) and its scattering of a few displays of artwork and information boards, followed by a walk through the interior area which turns out to be much more expansive than it appears from the outside. The interior contains a sizable display of different artifacts from several Nigerian tribes. It's mostly a self-guided tour (I.e. no tour guide) but most of the arts on display have small signs attached to them providing basic information about each artifact. 

With some investment to make the place a bit more modern and lively, the museum has potential to be a very good tourist attraction.

title: Just Cool
text: The National Museum is a good place to visit. While visiting one definitely will lean a few things about the history of Nigeria and its cultural tribes which makes it really exciting.

title: National Museum Lagos
text: Good location, lots of resources, great learning, and everything to make a good museum. The curators are knowledgeable, but a lot more can be done in terms of preservation, lighting, an using multi media to enhance the experience of the visitors like the shooting of the late head of state, which the Mercedez Benz is present. Over all, I will recommend the visit, worth the time and ticket is great

title: HISTORICAL HERITAGE.
text: This Museum has a rich historical heritage. The location is great, and I found the Bullet Riddled Mercedes Benz Limosine of the Late Nigerian Head of State General Murtala Muhammed who was assasinanted in 1976 very moving.

title: More attention needed!
text:
The museum looks good. However, some pieces of information about certain items are wrong. For example, Ikot Ekpene is in Akwa Ibom not in Cross River State.

Publicity of the museum is low. Hence, people rarely get to visit. Entry fee is ₦200 and you really don't need the tour guards to show you around.

title: Zielig
text:
Als dit representatief moet zijn voor het culturele erfgoed van Nigeria...
Ze willen wel maar ze zijn zo slordig en ze laten het zo snel verloederen.
Tegelijkertijd heeft het dan weer iets ... charmant op typisch Nigeriaanse wijze..

title: Fantastic place to go with kids
text: We decided to go visit the national museum during the Eid public holiday. We were pleasantly surprised. Our tour guide "Figaro" was the absolute best and tickets only cost 1000naira for 8 of us. There's so much to see...old currencies...the car Murtala Mohd died in etc.

title: A step into History
text: Not being a native Nigerian it was interesting seeing some aspects of the Countries history. However, as a National Museum I expected to see more there. But entry was only 200N per person so it is affordable for most. There are 4 main areas spread over the sites to see so a couple of hours is sufficient enough for a visit

title: Excellent look at some of the tribes in Nigeria.
text: Being that there are over 200 languages/tribes in Nigeria this museum couldn't encompass them all.  It DID provide a unique viewing of some of them.  Recommended.

title: The museum of National history
text: This is a place for those interested in learning about the country and what it was like thousands of years ago. The National Museum, Onikan, Lagos is also a place for the tourist who is visiting Nigeria for the first time. It is the first cultural immersion into the multi cultural society that makes up Nigeria. It is a museum that is rich with diverse antiques from the four corners of the country. I recommend this place for everyone. It is advisable to ask questions concerning anything you do not understand, i.e an antique etc.and the guides will be glad to answer you.

title: the national museum
text: I had little knowledge about the historical existence of the country so i made up my mind to tour the national museum because it is a 10 miles from where i was living, i saw so many artifacts and the car that former head of states was killed in but i was not opportuned to take any pictures. it is a lovely place to visit as a tourist in the country.

title: A great place to capture history but needs a sprucing up!
text: So glad I took a tour of this place and saw the beautiful artifacts they had in their museum and gained more knowledge of the history.  But I was truly dissapointed with all of the trash in the courtyard area.  I would think this would be part of the up-keep of the place.  While there I saw someone wheel barrel trash out to the courtyard near the fence and dump it.  Inside was well kept but you could tell it the case displays need a refresh.

title: Terrible State of The Museum
text: I recently returned from the National Museum Benin City and I compared it with the one in Lagos. This is feedback from my clients who happen to have experienced the two museums. For Ambient (Lagos 0, Benin 10) Organisation (Lagos 0, Benin 10) Content (Lagos 0, Benin 10) Funding (Lagos 0, Benin 10) In summary, the National Museum In Lagos is a Joke.

title: No AC
text:
There is No AC in the building so it really takes away your ability to enjoy the history and culture there .
One thing they have kept in its original condition that stands out is the vehicle in which President Murtala Mohammed was assassinated in. The museum however is quite small.

title: National Edifice - Could be bettter
text: I was at National Muesum recently invited by some young artists who had their first exhibition just fresh from school.They partnered with the Sickle cell Aid foundation with the good intention to raise funds. Few people attended and not surprising - the place is nearly run down except for the renovation done in some areas The government can do with investing there- potential sightseeing revenue generating opportunity and a potential must see for visitors.

title: A great collection
text: Not easy to find, but worth the effort. The museum houses a great collection of Nigerian art and artifacts, including an explanation of Nigeria's development into one of the world's largest democracies. I was also impressed that the admission cost for nationals and tourists was less than one USD. The main drawback is that the museum lacked adequate lighting and ventilation to preserve the collection and you are not allowed to take pictures.

title: Best Kept Secret of Lagos
text: This is the Best kept secret of Lagos, you must seek it out to know why. Also opened on public holidays.

title: Slave Dungeon Experience
text: Another Thrilling Experience with Eco Tour Ghana❤️. The Castle Tour was Amazing as We learnt a lot about the slavery in Africa. We also visited other attractions as well😍. The site Guide was Experienced and Contact Mr Noisty on +233 558712206❤️🇬🇭.

title: Cape Coast Castles!
text: A must see! We went to both castles! Please make sure you ask for a tour guide! The tour guide will provide very descriptive history of how the castle was built, what the slaves went thru, and you actually get to your the rooms/dungeons!

title: Ghana's Cape Coast Castle
text:
Such a grounding and somber experience but one that everyone who visits Ghana should experience. The tour I took was nice as the guide took us through the castle while providing background on what transpired there centuries ago. The only downside was when the guide called the tour off before taking us upstairs to see the interior of the castle. 

Also, beware of the gentlemen trying to sell their wares to tourists outside the castle. They can be a bit much if you're not expecting it.

title: The Black Holocaust
text: The untold story of the Black Holocaust lives within the walls of the two castles here, as well as Osu Castle in Accra, and I am glad that the world is finally coming to Ghana to hear them. You actually feel some of the pain and anguish as you hear the story which is told by a group of well educated guides in detail who invite questions and challenges to the message. They are simply insuring that our history will never be rewritten and I truly appreciate them.

title: A pilgrimage to our ancestral home
text: The views were amazing!! It was a grounding experience to see and hear the experience of our ancestors.  Great tour guides.

title: A very interesting (must-see) historical site
text: We really enjoyed our visit to the Castle. Our guide (an employee of the Castle) was very well-informed and knowledgeable and we learnt a lot from him.

title: Godter til historie elsker
text:
Wow...min far og jeg elsker historie. Guide var flink og ret god til at fortælle om både slaver og slavehandlers forhold.
Vi fik både at mærke og føle de dårlig vilkår slaverne var under, ved at være de samme steder som de var og gå de samme steder som de havde gået.
Det er et stort og flot slot, som ligger lige ved stranden, vandet, med både flot udsigt over havet og flot udsigt over Cape coast.
Helt klart et sted at komme hvis man elsker historie.
Men advarelse pas på svindler udenfor slot. De spørger om dit navn og når du kommer ud igen, prøver de at narrer dig at købe ting

title: Very thought provoking
text:
All of these reviews say more or less the same thing, this is a very moving place to visit.
We had a guided tour that lasted about 45 minutes but it could have lasted much longer. There is so much history attached to this castle, I don’t think I have been so overwhelmed on a historical tour before.
Our guide was excellent in so much as he wasn’t shocked by the questions he was asked during our tour.
Definitely worth a visit.

title: A stark reminder of man's inhumanity
text: You must visit but be prepared, this is one of the worst reminders of man's inhumanity. Yes the slaves were bought from the winning side in tribal wars and sold to the slavers, some walked here from as far away as Chad and Mali. The conditions we kept them in is appalling. The dungeons have no light and the slaves were kept in uncleaned conditions for up to 10 weeks.  It reduced some in our small group to tears.

title: One of Humanity's Worst
text:
The debate whether this was a castle or prison is settled once you walk 'the room of no return'. There's literally a slide (image 2); one can only imagine how they shoved them into this room, then narrowed down so they couldn't turn around or fight back (like they do with cattle; image 1) but pushed into one direction, which is where they were loaded onto the ships. To call this a prison, even seems too much of an epitaph for this all but slaughterhouse.

Building a church inside, then proceed to do all God forbade, if only hypocricy at its worst was the worst of this.

title: Fascinating History
text: This was the second castle we visited on the tour from our cruise ship and this one felt different from the other one (Elmina Castle) as it was initially built for defensive purposes. Again, the guides brought the sad history of the place to life. Well worth a visit.

title: Good but can be improved
text: My guide was good but the people were plenty so she didn't get the chance to give everyone the attention we deserved, I will revisit again

title: Francisca was a great guide
text: I had an awesome day at the castle with Francisca as my tour guide, her presentation was so wonderful and touching, I highly recommend Francisca's services!

title: the history was good
text: The tour guide who took me was very experienced she make the history so clear and everything was well organized and on point, I will visit with more friends

title: Great site to learn about history
text: the tour at cape coast castle was very interesting, I had the chance to explore the history of the slave treading, much appreciated tour

title: Great learning experience
text: Cape coast castle was a nice place to visit, with lots of culture, I really enjoyed my tour today, I'm glad to have learnt alot too

title: Great Historical site
text: i learn everything I need to know on the slave Atlantic trading system here, Very educative and well organized

title: Great History
text: I was able to reconnect with my African self here, Francisca was an amazing tour guide to have , she's knowledgeable and really knows the history of the salve trading. I'm happy I took this tour

title: Definitely a must/see, high emotional impact, but poor tour.
text:
Lots of original features and a grim story that contrasts with a beautiful location.
Downside was the tour guide who gave the tour a strong overlay of her own religious views. Happy for someone to tell me they are a born again christian, but giving me god’s view of the slave trade is not very informative.
The tour had a strong element of being designed to produce an emotional impact. It is certainly an emotionally impactful place, but I also felt that a rather crude over-emphasis on emotional impact during the tour detracted from the overall experience.

title: La Porta del Ritorno
text:
Mercoledì 3 agosto 2022 
La visita a Cape Coast Castle ti svuota, è un tuffo nell'orrore, perpetrato per centinaia di anni dall'uomo bianco, da trafficanti senza anima che hanno commerciatoaltri uomini, ignari dell'orribile destino che li attendeva, costretti ad abbandonare la propria terra di origine ed i propri cari. 
Immaginare, come in un incubo, di essere costretti a camminare per giorni e giorni per essere deportati, vivere per mesi in spazi angusti senza luce, senza cibo, né acqua, in attesa di attraversare la cosiddetta "porta del non ritorno" ed essere poi imbarcati, costretti ad una nuova disumana esistenza, al servizio di padroni sfruttatori. 
Eppure serve per non dimenticare, per avere grande rispetto di una razza che è stata perseguitata, schiavizzata e che nonostante tutto questo, a distanza di generazioni, a volte riesce a ritornare in questi posti, in una sorta di pellegrinaggio, riuscendo ad attraversare la “Porta del ritorno” a Cape Coast castle, per avere memoria di tutto quello che in un tempo lontano è successo. 
Nel 2019 il Governo del Ghana, per commemorare il 400° anniversario della tratta degli schiavi, ha lanciato una campagna chiamata l'Anno del Ritorno" con lo slogan "Bentornato a casa", operazione volta ad incoraggiare gli afrodiscendenti a tornare in Ghana alla ricerca delle proprie origini. 
Un bel messaggio, nel segno del perdono, della speranza e della pace. 
La visita a questo posto è una esperienza da vivere, anche se è molto dura, tanto da restare impressa in maniera indelebile nell'anima!

title: Top 5 Things To Do In Lagos
text: I personally love going to Lekki Market to shop for dresses made with Ankara fabric, interesting local art work, or other furnishing pieces.  It is hands down one of my favorite places to visit in Lagos.   It is also a great stop when I am hosting visitors to Lagos, because they can get fabric in the market and find tailors to sew it into whatever creations, buy ready-made pieces, wood carvings, raffia goods, get their market haggling experience, etc.  Prices are usually reasonable (after you have done a bit of bargaining, of course).  And I love the variety of options that can be found here.  The market is relatively organized, but be prepared for the noise of generators, if the power is out.  The road leading to the market is in really terrible condition, and even worse when it rains so be wary of going there in a sedan car.  There is also a N200 charge to park your car in the lot so make sure you have spare cash.

title: Your regular art market in West Africa
text:
Souvenirs can be cheap if you are good with haggling. Ankara fabrics made into bags, purses and notebook covers. You can also easily get your emergency tailor to sew simple dresses.

The market which consists of stalls for raffia bags and beautiful art works is not that much of a big deal. Market is not easily accessible as the road is in dire need of repairs.

title: Lekki the best to shop local
text: Am amazing experience show casing local talent for art, beadwork, wooden carvings, local fabric, handbags and so much more. Friendly environment open to negotiations on prices. Much cheaper than purchasing at the airport. What a lovely experience will go back next time I am in Lagos!!!!

title: Not much here
text:
If you’re thinking souks in Marakesh or the bazaar in Istanbul this is nothing like these. 

We were done in 45 minutes.  Everybody selling the same things.  Beautiful Nigerian fabrics made into purses, bags and notebooks.  

If you want cheap souvenirs for friends at home you’ll find them here.  They really do NOT bargain which I found surprising after visiting other bazaars. 

Worth a very quick trip.  Wear trainers as it’s mucky and muddy.

title: Very different Wooden art and African paintings
text:
This place is amazing for art lovers . You will get plenty of options for home decor (Wooden artifacts and painting). We bought lot of small wooden arifacts ) . I took some to India as well
But do remember to negotiate well!

title: Antiques and a lot more
text: Roads are very bad leading to the market. But lots of African art and lots more which I shall not mention. Can buy things like pearls, paintings, get African clothing stitched. Lots of bargaining. Much. Enter than buying from one of the hotels. Much cheaper. Road leading to market is very bad so a good vehicle is needed.

title: Amazing artwork and unique finds but poor setup...
text:
The Lekki Market is AMAZING if you're looking for unique gifts and original artwork. Canvas art is of very high quality, prices are reasonable considering the talent and they will roll them and pack in a tube for easy travel. You can negotiate a bit but don't insult the artists- they are very talented and could command much higher prices if they had a better setup. Getting there is a huge turnoff, the Lagos State officials should be ashamed- can the Ministry of Art and Culture not build a large open-air facility for the artists to have stalls and properly display there work? This is something they have done very well in countries like Senegal, Burkina Faso, Tanzania and Madagascar. Something simple but clean, organized and easy to access for tourists and visitors. On the day I visited, there was so much standing water that we had to go back and switch cars. The potholes are insane, the area lacks ambiance for tourists and there isn't any signage. When we arrived the Japanese Embassy delegation decided to not even get out of the car because the generators were running and blowing black smoke on you at the entrance. Not a very nice welcome. 

The art is amazing, local and ambiance not so much.

title: Lekki Market
text:
The road to the Lekki Art Market was quite rough and it didn't help that it had rained the previously day. On getting there we were a bit confused as we couldn't easily spot a sign telling us we were at the right place. Inside the market, we were able to spot nice African inspired items, good for gifts. We also walked pass where some of the bags sold in the market are sold. 

When going here, you need to go with your bargaining skills so the traders don't take advantage of you. I always started by bargaining from less than half the price they mention first

title: Shopping for African Artwork
text: The road ushering us to the Lekki Art Market was quite rough. We needed a gift for a speaker at our event and felt that a good artwork will suffice. The market is not large but still has a good collection of paintings, bronze work and wood carvings. We finally settled for a wood carving of a Saxophone. We also discovered that prices were much lower here than most art galleries in the area.

title: A place to kill time for 1/2 day
text: After traveling to many countries within Africa.  It appears that each market around the continent are selling the same stuff.  As it's the same here.  Most vendors welcome you to take photos and associate with you.  But this one particular lane with wooden carvings and furniture, I was yelled at for talking videos.  Other than that, my experience here is okay.

title: Number 1 arts and craft shopping center
text: This is one of the few places I must take my clients to visit in during our Lagos City tours for esquisite creative art works. Just that now a days it takes a while to see something new as they all now sell same stuffs. So it takes a while of walking the entire market to get a few things that are totally unique and cheap.

title: Buy groceries and craft work
text: The Lekki Market is located at the Victoria Island extension/ beginning of Lekki. It is an ideal place to buy souvenirs, art work, beads, paintings and most importantly food.

title: Lekkie market
text: If you're looking for a taste of rich African culture, Lekkie Markets the place to go to.  Experience African talent and craftsmanship at the Lekkie Market.

title: Gifts & Souvenirs
text: Something we will always remember Nigeria with are the gifts and souvenirs we were able to buy at affordable prices. Don’t be afraid to haggle, it is expected !!

title: City Tour of Lagos with our international tourist and friends.
text: This is an excellent and unique stopping point for series of souvenirs, artworks, painting, beautiful beads, artefacts, tie & dye fabrics for both locals and various visiting tourists when showcasing part of what Lagos has to offer. Most tourist took much time here picking trending stuffs....

title: A Challenging Experience
text: On my first visit, we were literally swamped by sellers and hadn't even left our vehicle. I guess my being "oyibo" didn't help. I appreciate this is the Nigerian way but it was a little intimidating being followed, led, pushed and pulled to stores to buy. My husband is Nigerian but even he found it hard to direct them away.  Needless to say, I didn't wish to stay long. I had hoped to buy many traditional items and fabrics but went home disappointed.

title: Average market place though
text: Here you get luxury and meet class that flutters the Lekki community. Buy here and meet the 'bigs' in Lekki

title: A definite visit for a true African market
text: Jam packed with all sorts of interesting art and handmade articles, masks,etc.  It can get overwhelming but definitely worth a visit.

title: Local treasures
text: Great local market experience but you must not be shy of bargaining. We picked up some nice artifacts

title: Typical Lagos Market with the added bonus of a craft section
text:
This is a market i have been too very often. It is a typical market that sells the usual items you will find around Lagos. However, it is cleaner than most Lagos markets and that is a plus. The road leading to the market has been fixed and so access is a lot easier than it used to be.

It is a very safe and sane space. It is also not far from the beaches along the coastal line of Lagos. You feel the usual Lagos bustle but the market is far from crowded and the stalls are well set out.

The craft section is a big attraction of foreigners and expats. The downside of its popularity is that the crafts have become a lot pricier than they used to be. The good news is that this is an old fashion market (it is not a superstore with fixed prices) and it is a game of negotiation so when the seller goes high, you should start with a counter offer that is at least 50% lower than the asking price. Be prepared to haggle on price as this is the most fulfilling part of the experience.

Enjoy your visit to this quaint and niche market.

title: Absolutely must visit
text: An amazing celebration of Nigerian art. Over 30,000 art pieces of various material in one place. Its a true revelation and must visit.
