title: The Elmina Castle Experience marred by leeches outside the walls!
text:
There were 5 of us in the group and the cost of entry & tour totalled £11.96 converted to £ which I thought wasn't bad at all. A warning to everyone, as soon as you arrive in the castle parking area you're pounced on by the street sellers! It's quite unnerving especially if you have senior citizens within the group. They were like leeches & hounds. Note: don't give them your name when they ask, I worked out that what they'll do is get a shell from the sea which is of course free. Write a welcome note on the shell and charge you the earth for it claiming the money which can be accepted in Dollars or sterling will be donated to a local school? they even had badges on lanyards, not sure stipulating what though! probably a discount card of some sort? I was surprised they didn't have high visibility bibs on to give it the full official effect!. This all happens when you're on the tour of course. I'll come back to this afterwards.

The tour guide started, they tried to pack as many visitors into the group which I felt lessoned the experience as I had questions, lots! well, if I'm travelling this far I want to know things as well. Personally I felt the tour was rushed because there was always another group behind us ready to enter the areas of the castle. 

The stories were horrendous, makes me think the English can't be the worst slave traders as the castle was ruled by the Dutch & the Portuguese and after by the English. The slave quarters were a sight to see, I'm not surprised the ruler of the castle died young, what with the diseases going around back then. Imagine being a slave and being a sex slave to the ruler? unimaginable.

There were a lot of places to buy souvenirs but pricy in my opinion, especially the books. I think I'll read about it online. Watch out for the steep stairs, not very disability friendly but then again, the country hasn't moved pace with other countries in the world and there's no rush for it. If you've seen the roads, so called footways and general infrastructure you'll know what I mean.  

After the tour was over we walked around and I thought to myself "Why don't they give this place a lick of paint and do a little bit of maintenance? it was falling apart  especially with the salt in the air. The washrooms weren't clearly signed, I thought we'd had to use the corner until we saw a sign on top of some stairs. You could tell a place by it's toilets and it wasn't great but what alternative was there?. 

Exiting the draw bridge we were mobbed by the leeches and hounds, it was terrible. The castle car park should be out of bounds to these things. It got so bad it caused arguments in the group as one of the senior citizens were hounded so much he was confused about how much to give so he just whipped out £10 but they jumped on him and wanted more. We had to detach him from the mob and usher him into the vehicle for his own safety. I did give them £5 but then they came out with all the teary eyed puppy dog stories of "I need to feed my family" "my  children needs to go to school" "Brexit, Covid, War in Ukraine!" hey, the Tories are always using that line so I'll jump on the band wagon whilst I still can!. 

What these leeches will do is thrust a form in front of you showing amounts of previous donations from previous visitors, obviously high amounts to persuade you to part with money. When I handed over £5 the cheeky leech said "you should double it, it'll help the children". Yeah right, more like help him. I told him where to go and it was all that I had but he still badgered me until I closed the car door on his face, he continued through the window. It was one of the worst experiences on my travels, nothing in comparison to the street sellers, they're tame in comparison to these blood suckers.  

I doubt Elmina Castle's management team will take any notice. Going by the state of the buildings the things outside are the least of there worries, it's just about getting as many through the door as possible. 

One time thing for me, I wouldn't dream of entering the car park if you paid me. Only way to get around this is be dropped at the entrance of the castle by the draw bridge. If security woke up and did their job probably they'll keep the leeches & hounds from trespassing & vastly improving the experience otherwise, a thumbs down from me but the tour was educational and an interesting insight into the tragic things that happened behind these walls.

title: Educative tour
text: This tour was educative, and very smooth Mr Fred the guide did an amazing work by explaining the history of the Castle so well, I highly recommend you also check out this historic site

title: Emotionally intense historical site
text: This is not a castle. This is a slavery dungeon fortress with the Door of No Return. It is heart-wrenching and emotionally intense. No matter what you’ve seen on TV, that can’t compare to the in person experience. The guides are knowledgeable and passionate, making the history become real. If you only get to see one “castle”, this is the one to see.

title: Slave castle tour🇬🇭
text: Great Experience 😍 and the best history from our tour guide🫡. Contact Mr Noisty on +233  559712206🇬🇭.  The castle tour made as moody about how the slaves were transferred to the new world. This castle is the oldest slave castle in the world 🌎. We had fun when our guide took as for a boat ride through the Elmina Township 🚤❤️. Contact Mr Noisty on +233 558722206 for the best experience.

title: A walk down history lane
text: Amazing revelation of what slaves went through. Gives a clear picture of the past. Good history lesson for those who slept through history class 😆

title: Elmina castle
text: En historia om Afrikas slavhandel i på ett ställe. Slottet var lite mindre än cape coast men ger mer information. Fina vyer från slottet.

title: Elmina Castle experience
text: “The energy is strong and the stories are touching, and still, the experience is worth every moment. The tour guide was understanding, friendly, and professional. Thank you Beyond Afrik “

title: A period of history that should be remembered
text: Enlighten view of the horrible past of the slave trade. The stories told should never be forgotten. After all this time the castle is well preserved.

title: A must-see for foreigners and nationals alike
text:
What can I say?
This was a heart wrenching experience. And it wasn't even my first time yet I felt the same sense of sorrow and trepidation as the first time I visited about 20 years ago. 
It was also a time to feel pride for the bravery of my ancestors. Those who fought to end this phase of inhumanity and evil. Evil that was inflicted even with a so-called church on the premises. 

Kwamena was our tour guide and narrator. Excellent work, Kwamena. He told the story well, with the perfect amount of detail and expression. He also looked out for our safety, ensuring that the children especially were secured away from potential hazards such as when he opened the floor flaps to the water wells and dungeons. 

There are several excellent books being sold on site, at the entrance and at the end of the tour, along with souvenirs. Even Shea butter and shittor! We got the children some hand flicked drums which has kept their attention since!

There is a small museum on site as well. 

Beware the hecklers in the car park who will harass you to buy their paintings. I requested a shell that they design with your name and it makes a cute little souvenir but agree the price at the start and if they get grumpy, walk away. They are nice people but they're a bit too much.

Overall, this place is a must-see for all visitors and locals alike. Thank you, Kwamena.

title: Elmina Castle, A walk back in time
text:
We also went up to their chapel and the offices; was quite a solemn experience. Then took us to the male and female dungeons where our people were overcrowded, slept, died, defecated, and for the females menstruated. Many died before the ship arrived due to starvation and inhumane conditions. On the grounds of the dungeons, you will see what they wore, the awful stench would hit your noses but what got me sad was when he got to the door of no return; a small metallic gate.

Now I had a problem because I did not see any food vendor or an eatery, aside from the several souvenir shops for people to buy from. I had the same problem at Afadjato. I would strongly suggest they put up an eatery for visitors to have good local food to enjoy as all of that adds to the beauty of the site. We were there for more than 2 hours and did not see any sign of a food vendor on the premises, rather we had to go into town for something to eat. Then again, I had snacks in my bag and that served us well till hunger set in and we left to the next place.t. Just outside the premises you will have a lot of options to pick from so we did that and had our fill

I recommend an eatery be set up outside the castle

title: Touts detract from visit.
text:
With all respect the castle tour is worth it, however, much the same style if you will have likely visited Cape Coast.

Perhaps things may have been a changed since I was last there, however, my visit was completely sullied by the touts outside who hounded me to the main door and then waited to follow me from the main door. By far the most aggressive touts I encountered in Ghana, who made me feel very unsafe and I would would just advise caution if you plan to visit. 

If you opt otherwise, there are multiple other castles to visit, including at Cape Coast where touts were much more manageable - and the tours were very informative, interesting and sad.

title: Heart Touching Experience
text: Heart Touching Experience. Once you get to Elmina, to visit the castle is a must. I and my husband visited caste 2 times during our stay, everytime with different guide but it was really impressive. The story is really heart touching, specially in these times. Human beings should learn from the past and Elmina Castle belongs to this learning for 100%.

title: Ett måste-besök
text: På samma sätt som man bör besöka koncentrationsläger i Europa bör man besöka detta slavfort och få höra om hur slavhandeln bedrevs och hur de stackars tillfångatagna innevånarna behandlades innan de passerade room of No return för att föras ut till något slavskepp. En otäck historia som bör höras...

title: Great History
text: May we never forget what they went through. And may we understand new forms of slavery still persist

title: Castle visit
text: Interesting visit however as it's visited by lot of tourists from various countries it could be valuable to add some translators for foreigners.

title: Educative
text: The tour guide was amazing and very in depth with knowledge. I wish we wouldn’t take crazy rates from foreigners especially the diaspora as This experience is an even greater deal for them .

title: Emotionally tour around Elmina!
text: We had a good guided tour around Elmina Slave Castle. Built in 1482, this was the hub of the Portuguese (1482-1637) and Dutch slave trade (1637-1872) on the Gold Coast. Under the rule of the Dutch West Indies Company, around 30,000 slaves a year passed through Elmina’s door of no return. It was a very emotional and sobering visit, especially the secret staircase from the women's cells to the Governor's bedroom.

title: Our people suffered
text: Being from Surinam we know how the slaves were brought in. Elmina was very confrontating. They suffered so much.

title: Elmina Castle
text: Elmina es una ciudad situada en la costa atlántica de Ghana. Fue el primer asentamiento europeo en el Oeste de Africa y en la actualidad cuenta con una población de unos 20.000 habitantes. Los portugueses fueron los primeros en ocupar Cape Coast en 1555, lugar al que llamaron Cabo Corso. La Compañía Sueca de África construyó un fuerte en 1653, primero de madera y después de piedra, y lo llamaron Carolusburg por el rey Carlos X de Suecia. Cape Coast, es otra de las ciudades destacadas, conocida como Oguaa es una ciudad de habla Fante, posee un precioso castillo que data del siglo XVII. Fue construido por los suecos y se convirtió rápidamente en el centro de operaciones de la posterior incursión británica. También famosa por su Universidad enfrentamientos entre las potencias europeas para conseguir su dominio. En 1663 fue tomado por los daneses, luego por los holandeses y finalmente pasó a poder de los británicos, que en 1757 reconstruyeron el castillo, dañado por los bombardeos. Todos los ocupantes tuvieron a su vez que combatir contra los nativos del lugar. Imprescindible la visita.

title: Elmina Castle Tour - Ghana
text:
Wanted to share details of the our Elmina Castle Tour, we were staying locally at the Lemon Beach Resort, we didn't have the time to book an official tour but glad we didn't as the tour conducted by the Guides at the Castle was amazing, informative (whilst very harrowing)  engaging and very interesting. 
We took a local taxi to the site and walked up to the Castle, the entrance fee is 40 GHC (cedis) for adults and 30 for students. The guides take you around and share so much information starting from the arrival of the Portuguese in 1471, the Dutch and then the British. The Tour lasts about 1.5 hours. A must for anyone visiting the area.

title: Najstarszy kościół katolicki w Afryce Zachodniej .
text: Plac Agoli pomiędzy tym  kościołem a świątynią pytonów [ która jest sanktuarium wyznawców voodoo ] to arena obchodów dorocznego , styczniowego festiwalu Vodun Days. Kościół można zobaczyć w środku po zakupie symbolicznego biletu . Przymierzałem się do tego przez dwa dni .Jednak  zaabsorbowany obchodami festiwalu przeoczyłem godziny otwarcia kościoła . A jest to najstarszy kościół katolicki w Afryce Zachodniej zbudowany w roku 1909 .Jest dobrze odnowiony i utrzymany .Wizytował go nawet , w listopadzie 2011 roku ówczesny papież Benedykt XVI .

title: Basilique de l'Immaculée Conception , Une oeuvre des Missionnaires Catholiques en 1909 .
text:
Cette basilique de Ouidah , dite de " L'Immaculée Conception " , qui date de 1909 ,  a été longtemps Cathédrale de la Colonie du Dahomey instituée en 1884 , avec Ouidah comme capitale . Elle est le fruit de la persévérance des Missionnaires venus au Bénin dès 1884 .  En 1954 , elle perd son statut de siège du vicariat apostolique au profit de Porto Novo , qui devient capitale de Dahomey . Elle devient basilique en 1989 ; 

La construction de cette basilique dans le style " néo Gothique " a été faite de 1903 à 1909 , grâce à la participation de toute la communauté de Ouidah y compris celle de confession Vaudou , du fait de cette solidarité africaine unique en son genre !!

En arrivant cette basilique se remarque . La façade comporte un clocher de section carrée , mais inachevé , encadré par deux contreforts ouverts de lancettes en vitrail , le tout peint en gris clair . Le porche à la base du clocher , est encadré par une haute portée en arc de plein cintre à voussures peintes en blanc . Le haut du clocher est ouvert d'abats sons , et il est décoré de corniches peintes . Une petite statue d'Evêque ( peut être Monseigneur Dartois initiateur de cet édifice) se trouve au devant du clocher . 

En entrant , on découvre la nef unique , en forme de croix latine , qui est à cinq travées éclairées par des baies géminées à vitraux surmontées d'oculus . Le transept est peu saillant et ouvert de vitraux dans le style de la nef . La voute est de style lambrissé ( bois)  et est portée par des structures métalliques , ce qui lui donne une légèreté de bonne facture . 
Le choeur est placé dans une abside quadrangulaire ouverte de vitraux historiés . L'autel avec ses décorations simples , est placé contre le mur pignon sous une voute débordante en berceau . Une statue de la Vierge Marie au dessus de la croix , constitue les seules ornementations .

La visite de cet édifice est instructive sur le style de l'époque coloniale française , qui reprend celui des édifices français , mais avec des touches de couleurs d'inspiration africaine .  L'utilisation de matériaux légers , métal et bois , est déjà à la mode . 

A l'extérieur , une grotte réalisée en pierre de taille , sert pour les cérémonies en l'honneur de la Vierge notamment le 15 Aout

title: Ville de Porto-Novo
text:
Très bon ville pour avoir négliger pendant tant d'année (capitale du Bénin).
Sans l'union des filles et fils cette ville ne changera pas.

title: One hour is enough!
text:
A poorly maintained collections of dubious quality. The guide did her best to make it sound interesting. There are old Voodou masks, some relics from the Dan-Abomey kingdom. But pretty disappointing for the national museum in the capital city. In the basement there is an exhibition of callabash (excuse the yawn).
And photos inside the museum are not allowed!!!

title: Gèlèdè masques and dance
text: A rather unknown museum, but worth visiting, if you like to know more about the culture and history of Benin. The museum has different Gèlèdè masques, which was for me interesting to see and to hear the story about it, because we visited that before. The guide can tell you a lot. Also look at the other items the museum has.

title: Een stukje historie Benin
text: In Porto Novo bevindt zich het museum waar je meer te weten kan komen over het land en historie van Benin, de vele koninkrijkjes die officieel niet meer bestaan maar soms kom je nog een koning met kroon tegen die in de loby van het hotel ligt te slapen, en de slaven historie met de trieste verhalen van transport naar verre landen en verhalen van slaven die teruggekomen zijn met hun "rijkdom".  Het museum ligt in het centrum echter wat lastig te vinden vraag het aan een lokaal of aan je chauffeur. Een bezoekje aan de markt levert ook mooie plaatjes op "een andere wereld" en zeker de moeite waard!!

title: À ne pas manquer !
text: Musée vraiment intéressant et incontournable pour qui veut toucher un peu à la diversité ethnique et culturelle du Bénin. Un collection remarquable de masques mais aussi des objets caractéristiques liés aux croyances des diverses population du pays. Comme souvent en Afrique le manque de moyens ne garantit pas une préservation et une présentation optimales des objets exposés. Le guide est intéressant. Un artisanat de tissage notamment est présenté en parallèle.

title: Ne pas manquer
text: Vaut surtout pour la collection de masques Gélélé et les commentaires qui sont une bonne introduction à ce que l'on voit tout au long du voyage. J'espère que vous aurez comme nous la chance de faire la visite guidés par Emilienne.

title: Manque de moyens
text: Les musées manquent malheureusement de moyens en Afrique... et je suis toujours un peu déçue ... les pièces ne sont pas très bien entretenues. En revanche, le guide était très bien.

title: It's ok
text: The most interesting part was looking at the map with the different ethnic/tribal groups and having some Q & A with the guide.  For the rest of the museum, we would have preferred to walk around ourselves, see the exhibits and read the signs.  What the museum guide was saying seems to differ from the signs.

title: de moeite waard
text: Een interessant museum om iets over de etnische groeperingen van Benin te weten te komen.

title: Ouidah - is on the future UNESCO site
text: Ouidah is very impressive. the history, the museum, the sites, the people, the restaurant, everything about Ouidah is magical.

title: Well worth a visit
text:
It is well worth walking the whole of the Route des esclaves. You can start from the Ouidah Museum of History and end at the gate of no return. The museum itself has some fascinating images showing the assimilation that took place from west African slaves bringing food, dance, and culture over to the Americas. The artifacts and images from the slave trade are horrific and it really makes you think about the dreadful conditions these people were forced into. Well worth the time to tour around. 

Entrance is free although, at the end of the tour, you donate what you want to the guide. Guides can be conducted in both French and English.

title: Une partie triste de l'histoire de l'humanité
text: Même si triste, il faut connaître et se souvenir de cet partie de l'histoire afin que jamais quelque chose de semblable ne se reproduise

title: Incontournable...
text: Si vous êtes blanc à faire avec l'humilité et le devoir de recueillement qui s'impose ici, le musée comme tout autre lieux de mémoire au Bénin aurait besoin d'une bonne réhabilitation, mais la visite reste incontournable et les différents guides restent très compétant.

title: A faire mais assez décevant
text:
Il faut payer un droit d'entrée pour accéder à la porte, un guide local donne quelques explications sommaires.
Sans grand intérêt historique car la porte est un monument récent qui a pour seul objectif la "commémoration" de l'esclavagisme organisé de concert par les rois d'abomey et les portugais.
Il faut se documenter avant la visite et discuter du sujet après.
Intéressant pour les plus jeunes car cela permet d'initier une discussion sur les relations sociales en Afrique et le rôle des européens sur ce continent.

title: Un devoir de mémoire.
text:
Une grande route qui amène à la plage ou étaient embarqués les esclaves.
C'est juste émouvant de savoir que des miliers de personnes sont partis à cet endroit sans des conditions effroyables.

title: Lieu très conseillé remplis d'histoire
text: Bonjour , c'est un endroit très historique a visiter absolument. Si vous voulez faire partir de notre groupe de touristes internationaux pour visiter cet endroit et pleins d'autres au Bénin a l'occasion de la fête annuelle du vodoun en Janvier 2020  , contactez moi: +447554783736 .

title: Sad history
text: Worth a visit for the important but sad slave history. Also very beautiful architecturally and poignant. There were local guides and definitely worth getting one.

title: Contactez au (+229)95 44 74 78 Pour vous faire vivre le meilleur des temps de la traite négrière à nos jours.
text: Immortaliser l’histoire,faire vivre comme en temps réel,Les Emotions les larmes 😭 et des souvenirs.

title: Very sad history
text: It's quite an emotional journey following the route of the slaves. It is unbelievable what kind of cruelity they experienced. And to think that this was being done to them by fellow human being is pathetic. May this never happened again ever.

title: Sombering history
text: We walked the slave route starting from chacha place and ended at the gate of no return. A very powerful walk thinking about what the slaves that went through here went through. Would definitely recommend this.

title: Gate of No Return
text: The gate of no return was an amazing historic places one must not miss should they visit Benin. Along the way statues that has different meaning could be seen and with a good guide one will get their meanings

title: English speaking guide not around
text: It used to be the old Portuguese fort that is now a museum but unfortunately the English speaking guide was not around when we went. We were told he had gone to Cotonou and we could either wait for like 5 hours or return. We left!

title: Voodoo Festival.
text: This year Benin Voodoo festival was the best ever. Our guest enjoyed lot of fun and learn more about African cultures, traditions and believes.

title: Interesting history, great photos and pictures
text: It is the best establishment with regard to the history of slavery we have seen so far in the country  The Goulbenkian Foundation has done a great job in sending the collection and even though it is not well maintained, you find yourself looking eagerly at each and every exhibit. So interesting, so sad - not the least because of what the Africans did to their own people and how they exploited them so viciously

title: museo interessante
text: Museo da vedere, ben strutturato e ampio; indispensabile una guida che si reperisce all'ingresso. Alcune immagini sono le stesse che ho visto in un analogo museo di Salvador de Bahia dedicato al dramma dello schiavismo

title: Ouidahin museo
text:
Museossa käynti kannattaa ajoittaa ennen port of no returnille käyntiä. Museolta myös osaavat ohjata opastetulle ”kärsimysreitille”, joka päättyy rannan portille. 

Englanninkielinen opas seuraa museon kierroksella. Ei mitenkään säväyttävä museokokemus mutta jos olet läpikulkumatkalla on viitoitus ”valtatieltä” kunnossa. 

Valokuvaus tuttuun tapaan kielletty ja kohde ei ole lapsiystävällinen. 

Pihalla muutama matkamuistomyymälä. 

30min käynti opastuksineen.

title: Interesting slave history
text: The museum was quite small, there was an interesting history of the slave trade and some photos and other artefacts and it took about half hour to an hour to visit with guided tour mandatory. No photos allowed. It could be developed more to improve the museum. After the museum we went to the gate if no return which is very nice memorial monument.

title: the painful story of slaves
text: this places has a lot of history .a horrible period of mankind just because of skin colour. it was sad that a fellow human can treat other humans that way. we were escorted to slave markets, the final road before they were taken to slaves ship. we were told how the slaves were being treated before they took the slave ship to their master

title: rich history
text: The museum showcased the rich history and culture of the people of Benin and Ouidah. it also showed how most West African cultures are intricately linked.

title: Most informative castle tour
text: This is a must-go. The tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and informative. Everyone visiting Ghana absolutely should prioritize Cape Coast Castle.

title: Slavhistoria och obehagliga historier
text: Ett slott med hemsk historia om slavar. Ett informativt men hemskt historia om slavhandeln i världen. Stort slott med fin utsikt.

title: Excellent history
text: Excellent tour included on the entrance price. You get an idea of how slavery was in Ghana and really impressed whit the living conditions.  40 GHS for foreigners.

title: Visiting the ultimate sin
text: A must see just for learning the willpower it took to survive the conditions left in. After this my prosperity has changed.

title: To be remembered!
text:
One thousand men in the male slave dungeon and five hundred women in the female dungeon. Cape Coast Slave Castle dungeon was a place of terror and death. Millions of our African ancestors were shipped off to the new World. This place is a must-see for any Visitor to Ghana.

 Cape Coast Slave dungeon, was were thousands of our ancestors were forced to die. It was shocking! I almost cried, seeing what our people had to go through in order to be shipped off to the new world. The tour guide was on point. I really like his narratives. Never should, we repeat this history!

title: Historical, Educational and Memorable Experience
text:
Recently I traveled to Cape Coast from Accra with a group. Our guide was so very knowledgeable and professional.  

It was a sad experience but the guide was so prolific, the information given allowed me to relax and take it all in.

We did a lot on our Ghanaian trip but visiting Cape Coast Castle was a definite highlight.

title: Took some Married Couples there
text:
In December of 2021 , we visited the Cape Coast Castle as part of our 3 days tour to the Western and Central Regions.
It was a moment filled with lessons and a lot of emotions listening to the guide as he explained the history and showed as the various rooms.
For anyone looking for some history on the slave trade, this is one of the best places to learn from.
Do not forget to take a handkerchief along though because you may need to wipe some tears.

title: Interesting historical site  amidst humunguous polution
text: The visit of the castle and slave dungeons was very interesting and left me in a highly emotional state. On the downside, the environs are extremely polluted and we witnessed quite a few indigenes taking  a sh#t  in the rocks adjacent to the castle.There seems to be a total lack of sanitation and environmental conscience here :-(

title: History- A must to hear the Tour Guides explain the Slave Trade!
text: This was an amazing Castle to visit. The Tour Guide was very well spoken in English. I was amazed to discover that in history, it was the Ghanian Chiefs that made the decision to 'sell' his people to the slave traders. All about obtaining trading goods in return. Very sad to see the conditions in which those slaves were kept and treated.  Travelled in Dec  2018 & Jan 2019. I highly recommend purchasing the DVD video and supporting the artists in surrounding shops, they make the most incredible items.  Ghanian people are beautiful people and they do everything to make this tour worthwhile. In addition, I feel the Ghanian Government could employ their amazing  'Dance Troupe Artists',  to put on daily dance displays, (in their traditional fabric costumes,  at the Castle, to reflect the history and culture.  The Government need to step up their support, for International travellers, to give them richer cultural experiences.  Talented Ghanians are crying out for work, give them jobs  so that they can be part of the travellers rich cultural experiences!

title: Cape coast castle tour
text:
It was an emotional tour.
Our tour guide was very helpful and she engaged us in the tour.

It was a 45 minutes tour and i enjoyed it

title: Breathtaking
text:
This is the most heart wrenching place, so much suffering. The irony of a Christian church built over the squalid and inhumane dungeons the African slaves were forced to endure is lost on no one. Every non-African should come here as part of their basic education. Every African should have the experience of reentering the “Door of no return”. 

We were lucky enough to be shown around by  Mark Tetteh who was knowledgeable and had opinions on the subject matter. I was accompanied by my adopted Nigerian daughter, she felt that he talked to every level of understanding.  He also took time for questions and knew the subject matter intimately. 

Go early to avoid both the school parties and hawkers.

title: Sobering experience
text: Well worth a visit! Sobering piece of history. The guide was really informative and very interesting.

title: Critical history lesson
text: As a European I feel obligatory (and interesting) to learn about the role of Europeans in the brutal past Ghana has and how it still has an impact until today. Cape Coast Castle is a great place to learn and feel the history of colonialism.

title: Historic
text: The background for this place is awful. Anywat the place is worth a visit. You could almost feel the struggle the poor slaves went through for so many years ago.

title: Must see and important in understanding the world’s infrastructure
text: Very intense but I feel like it is critical in understanding our place the world and how the infrastructure of our world was built. The tour guides were very helpful and were able to answer all of our questions.

title: Excellent tour.
text: Really interesting and emotional visit. Had a great tour guide, Kofi Eso. He explained the history and significance of the castle with great clarity and closed the tour with a very moving message about the future. Would definitely recommend a visit.

title: An impressive building that has lasted for hundreds of years and looks beautiful.
text: That Cape Coast Castle is one of the monuments in Ghana that reminds our generation of African slave trade history. The building is old but looks very healthy and strong. It's a nice place to visit with a large group of people. I love the landscape and the sea breeze.

title: Great history
text:
Great place to visit and to remember the horror of slavery. The crime against humanity must not be forgotten. 
Besides that the castle has a great atmosphere surrounding it. Go right along the edge of the castle to you get to the fisherman beach. Children play (at least on Sundays where we we there) and view of the bay is super.

title: Lieu chargé d'histoire
text: Une visite très intéressante, dans un ensemble de bâtiments conservant le témoignage d'un passé terrible.

title: Very Moving Experience
text: Totally enjoyed our visit.  The history and actual evidence of the atrocities committed here are truly moving.  A must see destination for anyone visiting Ghana!

title: Interesting
text: Hidden away, I did not have much of an expectation as to what we would see. There were many artifacts dating back centuries, however, one needs to know that you are not permitted to take any photographs at all, which truly is a pity and ruins the overall feel for visitors. There is very little literature available on the various statues and the whole place seems to have been forgotten about. Very nice friendly guides and staff who were quite happy to show my group around.

title: Old and still fine.
text:
After a couple of years since my last visit, I went with a friend to see the Museum this week. 
Not much of an improvement in the artefacts and art on display in the Museum since my last visit, but I was pleased that they had so many people visiting that day, and a couple of guided tours were underway.

Tickets were N200 (about 50cents) for adults, and N100 ($0.25) for children.

Opens every day 9am and closes 3pm on most days.

Points for:
-Nice for a short visit. So, even if you have a busy schedule, you can pop in. We spent about 30 minutes in all, to have a quick look at all the galleries. 

-Centrally located in Onikan, Lagos Island. It is adjacent to Ikoyi and close to Victoria Island. It is easily accessible, especially if you know the roads around the area.

-Free parking in large car park. 

-Nice grounds with trees. Nice place to have a picnic with family/friends.

-Nice museum shop, though dimly lit.

Points against:
-The air conditioning was off is the largest gallery. They said "currently under repairs"

-There's room for improvement in the display and labelling of items, as well as in other aspects of the Museum.

-Photos not allowed in galleries. Why?

title: An Unusual Museum
text: I always like to visit museums. This one was also a memorable experience, mostly because it is not a national museum you would expect. The building is quite old and there is no air conditioning, but the employees are trying very hard to make the whole experience nice. The entrance fee is 200 Nairas for Nigerians and 300 for tourists, plus the tour guide will ask you for some money in the end, but you tip him as much as you want (I gave him 1000 Nairas because my Nigerian friend told me that was enough). The museum currently hosts two exhibitions - one about Nigerian culture and the other one about the country's governments over the last couple of decades, and both are worth seeing.

title: Pass
text: Needs a refurbishment.  Not much here.  Hot.  Not very well kept displays.  Can finish in 20 minutes or so.

title: ummmm, only ok.
text: I visited Sunday on a Saturday, I was the only visitor. Entrance fee for foreigners: 300 naira (less than one Euro). The staff little interested, in my opinion, in explaining the history of the country, although the enm exhibition itself is beautiful.

title: Decent
text: I enjoyed my time there but wish there was more information and exhibits to see. What they have is informative and you do get a good insight on different cultures.

title: good but could be so much better
text: what there is is fine but more information about each exhibit would be nice, the political history section is done well, and the rest should follow suit. If you dont know Nigerian geography it is hard to put the exhibits into context.

title: Not so much artifacts, just good information
text: I was in some museums and I read only few lines of information because the collection itself is indeed the story and history. Here, you have to do a lot of reading, not so much visual arts collection. Though I love the information about their face marks. Nice facts, so cultural. I just hate the history of slavery..It will break your heart.

title: Great art work without being pampered through beautiful galleries!
text: Yes, this is not the British, Metropolitan or Gulbenkian museums.  Nonetheless, this Nigerian museum contains some stunning works of African wood and bronze artwork that you will never experience anywhere else and that will remind you where Picasso's source Cubist  inspiration came from! (Let's not forget that the British Museum stole 2000 bronze works from Nigeria's city of Benin, never to be returned!).This is art from the heart whereas so much Western art is, as critic George Steiner said, "more interesting for its THEORY than  for its art." I really think it's very worthwhile seeing this museum for its ART (and not just to be pampered through beautiful galleries as in the US and  Europe).

title: VERY POOR FOR THE LARGEST ECONOMY IN AFRICA
text: Have not experienced such small and run down 'national' museum for almost 25 years ( 1990s in Cambodia ) and this is supposed to be the biggest economy in Africa! Sure one can understand lack of budget / expertise etc but surely there is zero excuse for a large country not to put some money into its culture showcase....

title: A good background of history
text: Not so much collections or artefacts but they have some collections that will amaze you especially when you're new in Nigeria. Compared to other museums in other countries, this place might not so special but you will shed a tear when you read about the scars from their faces.

title: The Museum of Nigerian Arts and Culture
text:
The National Museum in Onikan on the Lagos Island in Nigeria is famous for having some of the legacies of 2000 years of Nigerian Arts and Culture and for the regular Art exhibitions. I curated the 1993 World AIDS Day Art Exhibition at the museum where all the artworks sold out and made me famous!
The museum kitchen restaurant here is more than 30 years old and popular for hosting live musical shows of Highlife, Jazz and modern Nigerian hip hop and drama. The museum also has facilities for weddings and other social events.

title: Could Be Better
text:
I was impressed that the air conditioning worked but the lighting sucked. I could barely see the details in most art pieces there. Our tour guide was more into talking to the caucasian tourists like they were part of slavery/colonialism (and in a funny accent).

The apt name is 'The National Cave'. Lights please!! And invest in procurement, there's barely anything of note left there.

title: Poorly Presented Glory
text: From the outside, a visit looks promising but to say I was disappointed is an understatement. Our glory is a shadow of it self and the environment looks a bit unkept but for the foreigner, a visit might be worth it as they would learn a few things about Nigeria. Just opposite the Muson Centre, It's easily accessible from Awolowo Road, Victoria Island or Lagos Island axis.

title: unfulfilled potential
text: I have been three times - partly in the hope that it would get better and that I might have missed something. For a National museum there are so few exhibits and what exists is badly displayed. It could be so much better if someone 'loved' it a bit. History does not seem important.

title: Take in so much of culture and tradition as you cam
text: The national Muesuem is located in a very exciting part of town. It is right besides the Onikan City mall and opposite the Muson Centre (Musical Society of Nigeria). While you need some two hours or more tho fully explore the musuem, I will advise tourists to plan to spend the whole day in that axis. After you visit to the Museum, you can see a movie at the cinema next door or have a meal in the restaurants next door or in the Muson Centre.

title: First Place Giving Receit After Paying Admission Fee
text:
Poor exibition, very rude staff, especially where the political exibition is. 
Staff was talking loud, laughing, listening to music, sitting on the floor. 
No direction where to start and where the rooms are... 
Looks like a19 century village museum.

title: Great for Tweens
text: I took tween boys to this museum and they enjoyed it tremendously. Get the guided tour and go see the room where they have an exhibit on the government it is a treat. The exhibits need to be renovated but the information was relevant and thought provoking. It was an enjoyable visit.

title: Kein Glanzstück für Lagos und Nigeria
text: Man muss dieses Nationalmuseum in Onikan sehen, aber man wird enttäuscht sein. Der Bestand ist über die Jahre "verlorengegangen", die Präsentation der verbliebenen Ausstellungsstücke lieblos, die Beschrift dürftig. Das ruppige Personal sieht sich, wenn überhaupt, eher zur Bewachung denn zur Erläuterung. Häufig fällt die Beleuchtung aus. In einem Nebengebäude befindet sich eine Sonderausstellung mit der Limousine, in der Militärmachthaber Murtala Mohammed 1976 einem Attentat zum Opfer fiel.

title: Very unfriendly staff
text: they suppose to close at 5pm but we have been told at 3pm that we only had 20minutes to see the museum. After we have been charged more than we should on entrance. Building is horribly maintained

title: Nice art-crafts!
text: This market is pretty decent in size; it should have about 200 stalls and they sell from soft stone handicrafts, wood masks, bracelets, etc. to exotic animal purses and ivory (not cool.) Prices are kind of touristy, but it's still decent to buy small things. They have beautiful painings and they will treat you pretty well.

title: Nice place to go
text: You will find a lot of different things to bring home for relatives and friends. But you have to bargain to get a good price.

title: Market of treasures
text: This market is a must visit when in Lagos state. Perfect place to get all sorts of African Fabrics, souvenirs, affordable artworks and masks from different cultures and tribes. Bring your bargaining power when you do visit.

title: Beautiful naija
text:
A place for quantity and quality shopping.I Must recommend!
It's a colourful place to be for food and more.

title: Market and Suprises
text: It is a great place for everyone. You may be surprised what you may eventually find in this market. The people are used to international visitors so you will have a good bargaining and maybe make a friend.

title: Nice but you can find better
text: Nice market with many art and craft stands. Having seen other local markets, though, I think you can find more authentic places. Still a nice place to buy souvenirs and presents for friends and family!

title: Great stuff but need to bargain
text: I loved this market because of all the creative items you can purchase there. You can get really nice bags, clothes, art, crafts, jewelry, crystals, woodwork etc.. Make sure you bargain (I took my Nigeria  bf which helped!) and lots of cash so you can stock up on everything there. I could have spent a lot more time there buying gifts and things for myself but we ran out of cash woops! The other thing is that we went in the middle of the day so it was really hot, and everyone seemed to feeling the heat. I would recommend going morning or later afternoon/evening. Didn't take any photos bc the ones on here already are exactly what the market are like.

title: Expensive Lekki Market
text: Drove in to buy cooking items as I live nearby. I found them unusually expensive. Even regular items like yam, plantain, banana and paw paw were highly priced. They were also not fresh and did not deserve the high price tags.

title: Must for art work, craft and please do not purchase animal skin and related products
text: Lekki market a must visit if you need to deck up your living room, bathroom, bedroom...any room. HEAVY BARGAIN SKILL is must and lots OF FAKE TOO, if you need to buy any thing here be cautious. What do you get here..pearls better than Hyderabad ones, wooden artifacts, Ebony wood artifacts, painting of all kinds, painting made exclusively 100% from butterfly wings, terracotta artwork, metal artwork, paintings made from horn and bones of bovine animals, water color and oil paintings, animal skin and bags,.etc made from animals...You will even see skin of Lions, Cheetah and Crocodile among other wild species. Clothing, Wine and hard liquor, vegetables and fruits, plastic day to day items...first timer can easily spend like 2 to 3 hours here. Shop keepers are cooperative and make you feel safe from anti social elements. The more polite and respectful you are, chances are more of getting a bigger better deal. Be very careful as to what they say and what you end up buying, especially Pearls. Parking too is safe

title: Tiny market
text: Nothing much to say, than the road who leds into the market its the worst ever filled with garbage.. Market has not much to offer...

title: A place to visit
text: A great place to get good art pieces at very affordable prices. I also picked up clutches n handbags for a song!

title: This is great and truly inspiring. Faac Arts say so.
text: There is never a dull moment at this Craft and Art market. Art is expressed freely and uniquely. This a collectors delight.

title: Fabulous!
text:
A really great arts and crafts market. It is quite far from the African Garden Lodge, where I'm staying, but I went on Sunday, so there was no traffic.
You have to haggle, to get good prices, but I picked up some great little tidbits for friends back home, for next to nothing.
We'll worth a visit, but go on a Sunday, to avoid traffic.

title: Fabrics
text: The lekki market has a variety of things, from art work to fabrics to accessories, I personally gave this market a 2 star because I DO NOT like to have to bargain for price! I'd rather just have a fixed fair price, but the problem is you are constantly going to have to negotiate because the traders mark up the price so high almost all  the time; you'd find that from $50 you'd end up bargaining at the end of it all you'd probably would pay $20. So if you have to go to this market, go with your iron boots and some water and do get ready to bargain! bargain! bargain! and oooh also do get ready to be pulled by traders who want you to visit their stores but it is generally quite safe

title: Large market
text: This is a large market, although many of the vendors sell the same kinds of things. Still, it is a good place to go for souvenirs as well as clothes and handbags.

title: Saturday outing
text: Spent a Saturday mirning enjoying the market. Selection is great and market is quite clean and shop owners friendly and aggressive....in a good way. Be prepared to haggle and enjoy the experience

title: Un caos absoluto
text: Una descripción de lo que puedes esperar en este mercado es caos total. Es un mercado par la gente local. No esperes encontrar nada que sea souvenirs o turístico aquí

title: Sunday shopping trip
text: The art and craft market is a little hidden treasure within Lagos, once you get passed the normal Lagos traffic and bumpy roads, you are in a wonderful market setting, haggling for goods, looking at wonderful(and not so wonderful) paintings , mask, beads etc etc. This is a place worthy of a monthly visit, just remember to take water and haggle haggle haggle

title: Real African
text: Nice market, you can get all kinds of African clothes, arts and foreign vegetables that are locally grown. Organic foods.

title: Loved a Good Bargain
text: Great place to get a piece of Lagos. People are willing to bargain. Test your ability to haggle with the best of the best.

title: Very interesting museum
text: Old, not welltained,but very interesting museum. Each one should know about this horrible episode of mankind.

title: Beaucoup d'émotion et une page noire de l'histoire de l'humanité
text: C'est certainement le lieu le plus marquant du Bénin. Ici une grande part sombre de l'histoire de l'humanité s'est déroulé avec le début du circuits infernal de la traite des noirs en Afrique. Le musé est riche en représentation et les explications faite par le guide sont très claires. Aucuns point n'est oublié et la responsabilité de tous les acteurs est mis en évidence. La visite s'est faite avec un ado et un jeune enfant. C'est très important de connaitre cette partie de l'histoire. Autre point très intéressant, c'est la mise en évidence des similitudes culturelles et traditionnelles entre le Brésil et les pays d'Afrique de l'Ouest.

title: Know your history
text:
A lot of history!!! You must hear and see for yourself. The history of the trans Atlantic slave trade and African kingdoms that existed during the time is truly a revealing one.

It's amazing how black communities in the diaspora (in places such as South America and the Caribbean) have preserved certain elements of their culture for centuries and the striking similarities between those cultures and that of certain West African communities today. 

P.S. This museum needs a face lift however... without damaging the history; I felt that it wasn't in the best of shape.

title: Excursion Trip
text:
With about 45 persons that day we drove down to Ouidah from Cotonou, almost an hour.

The road is smooth and free.  Two years before now, we couldn't ply the slave route because it was flooded.  We had to turn back.

If you are going to the point of no return in Ouidah, get a tour guide who should be able to let you know if the route is in perfect state.

What makes this tour site a 'must go' is the story being told about the slave trade way back centuries from the route to the point of no return arc.

title: Emouvant
text: Visite ce site si vraiment tu  aimerais mieux connaitre l'histoire de l'esclavage. C'était purement extraordinaire.

title: History cherished
text:
The museum is rich with antiques and it is encouraging to appreciate the managers for the preservations well done.

However, English speaking guides should be on a stand by for English speaking tourists.

It is a great place for those who value history.

title: Ouidah Museum
text: The museum have a lot of blood chilling history of slavey with lot of historical items  of how slavery was ran way back history.

title: Emotional Journey but Must Have a Guide
text:
My view may be a bit cloudy because it was an emotional place for me. This was a former slave Portuguese Fort that has been turned into a museum and you walk around rooms where pictures describe the unspeakable horrors slaves endured. We were on tour and the guide had arranged an English speaking guide for us who's a decent from a Brazilian slave who repatriated to Benin after slavery ended in Brazil. Of course, he admitted that his great grandfather at the time did not have knowledge of which country his ancestors had come from originally in Africa but he was following the wave of Brazilians who decided to call Ouidah home. 

I can't imagine visiting the museum without a guide because many of the pictures do not come with stories and that means you will miss out on so much. Plus the guide can help take you to the gate of no return which I think is part of the museum and also to other memorials which are there to honor slaves and the lives lost. It's a must do trip but just make sure to bring a guide!

title: No Museum, research the area and history before arriving
text: The Benin Government trying to help their citizens and visitors understand the history of the area and what has occurred here.  This is a monument not museum to the history of what took place here.  Research the trail and spend time to reflect this location and area before coming to the area.

title: The Museum of History of Ouidah has nothing to do with the Gate of No return Monument on the beach
text: The Gate of No return Monument on the beach,  of which there are a number of photographs here, is not The Museum of History of Ouidah. See the actual photo of the building which was originally Fort of São João Baptista de Ajudá built by the Portugese. There is not a lot inside just a few rooms with some artefacts and some explanations in French. Most could be self explanatory without a guide but our guide was quite informative and did add to the experience.

title: Not Great Museum BUT
text: It achieves its effect of making one reflect on Man's inhumanity to Man. The Fort where the .museum is housed was the nub for the slave trade. The Benin authorities should seek international funding to make this Museum worthy of what it is about and to improve the exhibits and their housing. Worth a visit as part of an overall insight into the pernicious and evil slave trade

title: An idiots guide to the Atlantic slave trade.
text: The museum is housed in the old Portugeuse fort that doubled as a slave holding centre on the Benin coast of west Africa. It gives a "no holds barred" account of the way in which the slaves were taken, held, mistreated and eventually made to exit the fort to walk, in chains, down a mile long route to the coast where they would then board the slave ships for the middle passage across the Atlantic to the Americas. Being located in the original fort at Ouidah leaves the traveler with the sense of impending doom and helplessness that the stolen lives must have felt at the time.

title: Eye Opening
text: A eye opening walk through the atrocities that were inflected to the African race for greed. We had an amazing guide Fostine who gave us a thorough historical narrative on the impact of the slave trade and the significance of the monuments and historical pieces. It is a place to visit and I was very happy that a lot of the historical monuments and artifacts were kept in good shape because in a lot of these historical sites things are not archived correctly. It is a beautiful village and you will get your fill with souvenir traders at the actual entrance to the beach Door Of No Return.

title: History of Benin
text:
Interesting history of Benin, a lot about slave trade.
Interesting museum and then follow the slave route to the monument. 
Ouidah is worth visiting for everyone who wants to get to know beninoise culture and history. Make sure you hire a local guide!

title: sensational
text: This is a sensationnel place, this is a part of history because slaves were deported thru this door.

title: Beautiful setting
text: This is the place where the people left when sold into slavery. It is hard to describe the feelings I had as I stood there at the beautiful monument honoring those who were forced to leave their homeland. It is one of those places that changes your perspective forever.

title: Impresionante recorrido
text: Lugar delque partian los esclavos, y tiene muchas cosas relacionadas con el tema que son muy interesantes, y merece la pena verlo, la fortaleza Portuguesa, LA PUERTA DEL NO RETORNO, CON SUS CUATRO KILOMETROS  DERECORRIDO.

title: Excellent et remémorant
text: Très bonne expérience avec la rencontre d'une population accueillante, souriante. On a la possibilité de revenir avec de bons souvenirs comme des tableaux peints, des perles, des statuettes fabriquées en bois

title: un monument aux esclaves
text: C'est un endroit de mémoire qui est mal entretenu et qui est un piège à touristes. Les écritures s'effacent et deviennent illisibles.

title: Important Piece of History
text: Symbolic of a dark time in human history, the exhibits are basic and only a few are from the era.  If you are in Ouidah it is a must see.

title: It was nice..
text: Lovely ☺️  I met Timothy the tour guide who was really helpful and lovely I will surely come back again/ the place is beautiful

A Captivating Visit

title: PROMESSE
text:
la Promesse ….. 
oui la promesse de revenir au musée ! La promesse d’un avenir … la promesse en elle même peut ne pas s’accomplir, au final c’est une promesse

title: A vibrant celebration of African art and culture.
text:
La Fondation Zinsou is a must-visit for anyone interested in contemporary African art and culture. The collection is beautifully curated, with stunning works by talented artists from Benin and across the continent. The exhibits are thought-provoking and offer a fresh perspective on African creativity and heritage.

This visit was recommended by Orisha Trails, and I’m so glad I took their advice ! They organized my visit seamlessly, and their insights into Benin’s art scene made the experience even more enriching. If you’re in Benin, don’t miss this gem.

title: Small
text: Small, exhibit with some nice masks, pleasant student guide explained the voodoo spirits. 1000 CFA suggested donation. The other museum/fort was closed. I walked 9 miles around town, found little else to do in Ouidah. The 400 year-old baobab tree between the  church and Python Temple was my favorite...

title: Exhibits change frequently, free entry
text:
The entrance is free of charge. There is a suggested donation. But they are not pushy.

Modern art is not really my thing, so this exhibit was not really my thing.
But I appreciate the guides and the foundation's commitment to African artists.

title: Un incontournable pour comprendre art et culture du Bénin
text: Visite très intéressante avec notre guide Primaël. L’entrée est gratuite et les expositions sont renouvelées plusieurs fois par an. L’art était un excellent support pour comprendre la culture et les modes de vie du Bénin, notamment liés au vaudou. Je recommande, même si vous n’êtes pas spécialement sensible à l’art contemporain

title: Nice exhibit
text: The museum looks like it has been renovated recently and it is well maintained. Was surprised to see the variety of art from artists in Benin and different parts of Africa. They are exhibiting really nice pieces.

title: Centre culturel incontournable !
text:
Très bel endroit ! c'est l'association du Contemporain et de l'héritage ! 
le lieu est riche et vivant culturellement !

title: Un musée contemporain dans un lieu historique du Vaudou .
text:
Le musée Zensou de Ouidah est un bel exemple de ce que peut faire une organisation privée pour la diffusion de la culture et de l'art local .
Situé dans une demeure de charme entièrement rénovée ,il présente des œuvres contemporainnes d'artistes africains ou autres. 

La lumière diffuse met en valeur les objets exposés et le guide est très explicite sur leurs signification  et expressions.  Ce musée est gratuit et l'on peut faire un don . Je recommande la visite de ce lieu  ,qui fait honneur au mécénat . Dans le jardin interieur on.peut découvrir des œuvres en rapport avec le vaudou qui est largement pratiqué à Ouidah avec la fête début janvier. La statue du dieu  vaudou Tohossou , dieu de l'eau à trois têtes avec son serpent , ainsi que Mami Wata , la redoutable  animent le jardin au gazon presque british . A voir absolument !!

title: Esposizioni di arte contemporanea
text: Forse il posto che più mi ha colpita in Benin: una bellissima collezione di arte africana contemporanea, allestita in una antica casa padronale nel centro di Ouidah, perfettamente conservata. La guida che ci ha accompagnato era davvero preparata e appassionata di arte. Consiglio vivamente una sosta nella caffetteria che offre deliziosi succhi freschi ed è arredata con grande gusto.

title: Un lieu magnifique, des euvres admirables, une équipe très sympathque
text:
Un musée absolument incontournable si vous passez par Ouidah. 
Layo Primaël, l 'excellent guide présente admirablement les œuvres de l’exposition temporaire et connait bien l'histoire de l'art. Vu , début septembre, des œuvres de grands artistes africains ou européens dont l’accrochage est simple et valorisant.  
Le lieu est d'une grande beauté architecturale. Bravo pour la restauration. Un café-restaurant très stylé, dont les prix accessibles pour tout Européen le sont sans doute moins pour les visiteurs locaux, auxquels le musée s'adresse pourtant grâce à une intelligente gratuité.  Hâte d'y retourner!

title: Endroit a visiter
text: Bonjour , c'est un endroit  historique a visiter. Si vous voulez faire partir de notre groupe de touristes internationaux pour visiter cet endroit et pleins d'autres au Bénin a l'occasion de la fête annuelle du vodoun en Janvier 2020  , contactez moi: +447554783736 .

title: Charming Surprise
text: Was pleasantly surprised by this place. Charming and fun and educational. Yes the cafe is pricey but the ambiance was worth it. Only issue was no running water on day I visited but they had a water barrel.

title: Varie proposte culturali interessanti
text: In questo museo ho visitato una mostra sulla città di Cotonou, con vecchie foto. Esposizione interessante e brava la guida. Ci sono spesso mostre tematiche.

title: Un des meilleurs et authentiques musée du Bénin. Je remercie beaucoup la fondation pour cette merveille!
text: C'est un musée excellent! Avec une équipe très accueillante.  Le bâtiment qui l'abrite est une des plus ancien à Ouidah. Dedans, on y retrouve une collection d’œuvres artistiques provenant de tous les coins du monde. Il me manque des mots. Franchement, c'est une merveille !!!!

title: Beautiful, well kept
text: Beautiful, well kept museum showcasing contemporary African art. The wallpaper and decor in the cafe was too beautiful. Garden very well kept, we watched a mini documentary about the making of some of the art. We also didn't pay to go in. They have a gift shop if you want some souvenirs though I didn't buy any there because they were a bit pricey

title: Building is nicely renovated, the exhibition was so so
text: We loved the way the Afro-Brazilian building was renovated. Really amazing. The exhibition itself was not interesting - the one in Cotonou was much much better. Definitely worth a visit.

title: A ne pas rater
text: Magnifique expo réalisée au Bénin par la jeune artiste Pauline Guerrier. Un travail réalisé après un long séjour au Bénin et notamment des ateliers avec des enfants.

title: Magnifique musée
text: On a hésité à y venir, et nous n'avons pas été déçu. Le batiment est très beau et les expositions sont magnifiques et inintéressantes. Art contemporain mélangeant les traditions anciennes donne de très belles pièces à voir.

title: A unique creative Art museum in Benin Republic
text: The creativity of this place and the dedication of the staffs is worthy of note. The curators are always patient. The site has a English speaking curator. The art shop upstair is very picturesque.

title: très beau musée
text: Ouidah, ville formidablement vivante et chargée d’histoire, a ce très beau musée. Art contemporain béninois souvent. Il est heureux de voir des créateurs s’exprimer librement et être exposés ainsi. De plus les guides du musée vous accompagnent et leurs explications sont intéressantes. L’accueil au bar est très sympa aussi. Mérite le détour.

title: Kann ja sein
text: Also, ich habe die "Kapküstentour" nicht mitgemacht. Ich habe Elimina mehrfach gesehen und war auf den Brücken. Naja, es wird viel sehr emotional gesehen. Elmina ist eine Touristenfalle. Verkauf und Nötigung vor der Tür und dann... Ausländer zahlen, Einheimische ein paar Kupeken. Einheimische gehen da nur sowieso hin, wenn sie eigeladen werden. Die sind gegenüber der Sklaverei ganz entspannt. Immerhin haben die Fante ja mit den Kolonialisten kooperiert, um ihre Feine - hauptsächlich Ashanti - vom  Hals zu halten. Aber zurück zur "door of never return" in Elminia. Eine ziemlich zerfallene Burg, vielleicht mal wichtig zu sehen, aber 1x reicht. Finde ich. Arogant gegenüber Touristen und verdammt wenig Aufarbeitung oder Dokumentation. Die Brücken...naja. halb vier aufstehnen, Fahrt zu dem Park....dann im dunkeln ewig durchs Gebüsch. JA, es hat schon was in den Wipfeln über diesen Holzbalken. Es ist sowas wie: wichtig zu sehen, egal ob es mein Leben kostet. Ein gutes Gefühl hat man dabei bestimmt nicht. Gut, daß das die Dänen gebaut haben.....es lohnt sich jedenfalls.

title: Sad but true!
text:
I recently spent a couple of hours touring the "slave castle". It's hard to be whistling a happy tune as you enter the castle, once it hits you what happened there. The gravity of its size and its purpose hits you in your soul. At it's height the castle shipped off 4,000 slaves a year, mostly to the Americas.  The tour guides are both friendly and knowledgeable   The visit to this slave castle was definitely worth my time and money (the "tour" is NOT handicap accessible!). 
While the castle was worth the drive, the drive itself is not!  Ghana and a few other countries have this curious habit of placing rather large speed bumps on its major two-lane highways - a lot of them (sometimes 3 or 4, one right after another). There must be close to 100 of them (about every 1/2 to 1 mile) between Accra and Cape Coast. They can rattle your teeth even when driving slowly over them!  And of course, cars pass another on curves or going up hills that will get your heart pumping, depending upon how fast or aggressive your driver is. No, there is not a major hospital with modern technology nearby, in case one of the drivers makes a misjudgment (I saw one such accident on the way to the coast. Thankfully it was not a major head-on collision but it was close enough!

title: eye opening visit
text: Arrived at Elmina Castle in January 2020. I believe is was 40 cedi to enter and take the tour. The tour was provided by an employee, a younger girl who was excellent in providing information about the castle and the early days of the slave trade. The tour was in depth and provided a very eye opening account of what went on in this place. Overall this tour was well done and worth the 3h drive from Accra. This trip and a visit to Kukum National Park is do-able in a day from Accra and back.

title: Fascinating and emotional
text: Everybody should visit the Elmina Castle, one of mayn castle along the coast of Ghana where the slavetrade was organised and slaves shipped to the Americas. Built originally by the portugese in 1482 as a trading place it developed into a main central for keeping slaves until they could be put of ships to go across the Atlantic. Feeling the history of tens of thousands of persons that sufferede the horros inside the castle is very emontional. The price for entry - 40 Cedis - includes a very competent guide that will take you around the main spots. The tour takes about 45 minutes.

title: Touching experience
text: The Elmina castle might bring you to tears when you're taken round and told the stories  of the plight of the slaves that once passed through this place. It's a nice place to be and  has good management, the tour guides ar great and has the history at their finger tips

title: Not a Castle, but a Horrible Dungeon
text: It is hard to give a 5 star rating for this dungeon of horrors.  The rating is for the staff and the country that saw fit to maintain this place so that we never forget the horror that was the transatlantic slave trade.  Every African American who visits Ghana must go to this place and experience what our ancestors experienced.  It is unforgettable.  And let not the irony escape you of the horrors that took place right next to the beautiful seaside setting.

title: Emotional eye opening
text: As I walked into the castle I felt humbled. I felt the presence of my ancestors straight away. It was a real eye opener. I fulljoy the tour. Learned a lot.

title: Good
text: A good place to visit.alot of anciet history in there .A very emotional tour  but totally great place

title: A Dark and Heavy History
text:
The castle is very well preserved.  The guide that we had was a master story teller who told the history of Elmina with a lot of passion.  His understanding of the history was in depth and he also provided great commentary.  To allow us to experience a fraction of what the slaves experienced, we were placed in some of the dungeons with the doors closed.  
There are a couple of great shops where you can buy books and dvds about the history of the castle.  In addition you can purchase some Ghanian souvenirs.
The view over the town of Elmina is fantastic.

title: Heartbreaking but a necessary visit
text: The castle's history is simply unfathomable. The tour guide we had was passionate and knowledgeable.

title: Another ghastly reminder of human exploitation
text:
This castle is about 11kms from the Cape Coast Castle.

It has lot of similarities with Cape Coast Castle- the white walls, the horro stories within & the disgusting history of both the castles.

It is a historical structure that holds the horrors of the transatlantic slave trade that many countries try to disown & push under the carpet.. A spine chilling journey through dungeons where 150 humans were chained together & made to live a life which was wort then hell. The terrible treatment of humans for the quest for wealth via the Portuguese, Dutch &, English,held in varying times of Elmina Castle. A must see and experience and the preservation of this repulsive thing that was slavery!

Inside and out, Elmina Castle is a very imposing edifice indeed.  Its main claim to fame is that it's the oldest building in sub-Saharan Africa. It was established by the Portuguese in 1482 although most of what we see today is Dutch, post 1637. The British took over the Castle in 1872 and held it until Ghanaian independence in 1957. Subsequent restoration has been done by the Ghanaian government. Visitors are directed to an important building in the main courtyard, now a museum which tells the entire history of the area. It's in a former Portuguese church (1596), which was turned by the Dutch into a market. The Portuguese, Dutch and Brits were all involved in the slave trade and the first port of call on the guided tour is the slave dungeons. Hundreds at any one time were incarcerated here before being led down a tunnel to the "door of no return", a narrow slot, which at one time gave on to the sea, which has since receded. Boats then carried the slaves to ships, which took the captives direct to the Americas. We were also shown a gallery, from where the Governor chose female slaves, who were then taken to the Governor's substantial quarters. It's likely that the women who subsequently gave birth were released. Similar stories are told at other Ghanaian landmarks, e.g. the Cape Coast Castle and the James Fort Prison, Accra. 

Definitely one visit

title: Elmina Castle Visit
text:
A great experience, the impact of the trans Atlantic slave trade will stay with me for a long time. May we vow never ever again to allow such slavery. The walk that slaves had to take and the door of no return
Is etched in my heart forever.

title: A visual portrait, of the African horror story.
text: The Elmina dungeons is the location where the captured and enslaved African people were warehoused and tortured until they were shipped around the world, to slave farms. There are guides on the site that give a detailed history and accounting, of the salved trade. The dungeons have been kept, in tact so that you get a clear and precise undertaking, of what transpired during that era, in time. If you have an ounce of humanity, you must mentally prepare yourself, for some, of the worst atrocities that happened, to people.

title: Inspiring
text: We took hotel car and driver to see it.  You can easily get there and back in a day trip.  I read "Things Fall Apart" on flight over to Ghana which is a wonderful book and helped put things in perspective.  It's hot to walk around and very sunny and we brought sun hats and umbrella for shade.  It's not a castle it's a dungeon, not sure why it's called that.  Scene of horrible atrocities.  Tour was worth it not expensive.  Guide spoke well and with great conviction.

title: Worth visiting
text: Built by the Portuguese, Elmina castle in style and form contrasts to that of Cape Coast. Its haunting history in the slave trade makes it an important site for reflection.

title: Walk in the past
text: We wanted to visit the castles but to be honest it was very depressing.  It was rich in history and full of information.  Visiting the castle and hearing the stories behind it reminds you how humans can be so mean and horrible to one another.  This should never have happened, treating each other like commodities.

title: A smaller version of the Cape Coast Castle, but tells a poignant story of the slave trade
text: The Elmina Castle tells a sad tale about the history of the African people. Slavery played quite a role in the history of Africa and indeed, the bookshop in the Castle offers some insight in the form of books and CD on the history of the slave trade. Our tour guide was amazing and it was really interesting to also see the role played by Christianity in the Slave trade. The Church was right next to the dungeons, a similar scenario that also plays out when we see the stark contrast between the cell where the condemned slave was kept and the next door cell for unruly soldiers.We leave Elmina with the commitment that never again shall humanity witness the level of brutality that was witnessed and perpetrated during the slave trade era.

title: So much history, so little time
text:
The castle has been standing since the 1400s, having served not only as a trading site but also as a slave trading site. 
There's so much history that the guide can't possibly do it all justice. In hindsight, I would recommend to do some reading pre-visit.
What it does, successfully, in a short period of time, is give the visitor a grasp of the unimaginable conditions in which the kidnapped, captive Africans were kept.

title: Slave dungeon
text: There is nothing about this place that should be call a castle. This place should have a proper name of being called a Slave Torture dungeon.

title: Moving
text: Elmina castle is a story of brutal white colonialism.  To walk through the dungeons and learn how these poor people were treated is humbling.  The door of no return is something you need to experience. The cell where they left unruly slave to starve to death, the womens dungeon where the governor would pick women to rape.... horrific. But what is really disgusting and never ever mentioned is the fact that it was Africans selling Africans into slavery.

title: Shamefully engaging with our history
text: Sebastian was an excellent guide and really made you feel a very small bit of how it must have been to be here. Sorry for our history and maybe we should teach more of this in our schools.

title: Emotional und Bedrückend
text: Eine gute Führung. Ich musste öfters mit den Tränen kämpfen, so hat mich die Abscheu betroffen. Unglaublich zu was die Menschheit fähig ist. Ein dunkles und abscheuliches Kapitel auch in der Geschichte von Europa. Es war ein enpfehlungswerter und eindrucksvoller Besuch.

title: Worth the trip, even if out of the way
text: We stopped in Cape Coast en route from Kumasi to the the Accra airport. It is a long way to go but well worth the stop to contextualize a part of Ghana’s long history. Our group was tired after a full week but after the tour, agreed it was worth getting up and out early and taking a 7 hour drive instead of a 45 min flight to be able to take the tour before our departure that evening. Admission was GHC 40 per person for non-Ghana citizens as of Feb 1, 2020. The tour lasts about 45 minutes and is included with admission. Be sure to wear sunscreen and sunglasses or a hat. Water is also a good idea on hot days.

title: Educational and we'll maintained
text:
Very well maintained castle. Both outside and underground chambers.
It is recommended to take a guided tour provided at the entrance.
Takes about 45 mn.
But the overall stay should take arround 2-3 hours depending how deep you want to explore, the fort.
There are many chambers, pathways,  and towers with connecting walls.
Lots of history.
Highly recommended and educational.

title: Interessant und bedrückend
text: Obwohl die Hitze und Schwüle es schwer machte, war die Führung im Castle auf jeden Fall sehr lohnend.

title: Such an important stop
text: This is an important piece of history that needs to be experienced. Pictures and books don't tell enough of the story. Very powerful!

title: Tour with Anthony Bouadi
text: I had one of the best experiences in Ghana whilst at the castle. My tour guide Anthony did a wonderful job guiding myself and other attendees through the tour- a tour that was gut wrenching at times. He took time to explain and answer every question we had, and provided a lot of healing words, as well as brought great clarity/ knowledge about our history. I highly recommend for all tour needs in the Central Region of Ghana.

title: Incredible experience
text: This tour was emotional but necessary. We learned so much about the history of the slave trade and the countries who occupied Cape Coast Castle until it closed. You must visit when in Ghana!

title: Must see
text:
This was possibly one of the most humbling and emotional tours of my life. The learning experience was incredible and the tour guide had this immense storytelling ability that seemed to transcend us back in time. 

Hearing about the conditions the slaves went through and walking on the paths they did from the main entrance, through the male/female dungeons, and finally through the door of no return was heart wrenching. 

This part of history, as distressing and tormenting as it is still is should not be forgotten, in the hope it doesn’t happen again. 

Life altering experience.

title: Nice pictures
text: It was very intresting to see the slaves castle. I actually saw the castle in june 2018 but there was no 2018 dates.

title: An emotional tour for me
text:
Although I am pakeha/abroni/white this tour of the cape coast slVe castle was a very emotional experienxe.
Learning what was done to the 12 million slaves taken from Africa and the estimated million that went through the coast castles was confronting. The suffering of the slaves should never be forgotten and we have an obligation to learn what happened to these people.
I am stunned that i did not know how many were lost to slavery. Surely this is the greatest loss to humankind .
The guides were knowledgable. The castle is reasonably well preserved. We were taken through all the levels from dungeons and the door of no return to the 3rd floor hovenore and european quarters.
You can wander round on your own. I am insure whether this makes a diffrrence to the entrance price of 40 cedis. ($12NZD approx)
It is hot in Ghana so this tour will make you sweat if you are from cooler climates. Take water and a fan. I have been carrying round a wet flannel to cool my self off.
A down side is being harrassed by hawkers outside the castle. Just be firm with your "no" if you are not interested.

title: Cape Coast Castle
text:
This was the second slave fort that we visited on the same day.  These forts are very emotional sights to visit.  When you see the areas where they kept the various slaves and the church located above it, it is very overwhelming.

This fort had a good museum that covered the Atlantic Slave Trade as well.

title: Interessante Geschichte des Sklavenhandels
text: Die Führung war sehr interessant und eindrücklich. Die Räumlichkeiten zu sehen, in denen die Sklaven unter unwürdigen Bedingungen gehalten wurden sind aber auch bedrückend. Auch das Museum ist schön gestaltet, wenn auch teilweise etwas heruntergekommen. Die Führung selbst war etwas lieblos vorgetragen.

title: Hard History Lesson
text: A must see for any member of the diaspora to learn about the history of slavery. It was a humbling and empowering experience all at the same time.

title: Emotional
