text: We went at night. Which added a real atmosphere to the castle. We took the tour with torches. I cried as I know my ancestors went through a terrible ordeal. I learned so much. We were able to light candles and leave an offering to the ancestors. Amazing!

title: Whow - one tour that will remain forever
text: Have you ever wondered about slavery? If you think you know a bit about the subject visit this fort and you will learn so much more as well as other interesting facts about the Europeans, trade and slavery for profit. Absolutely mind boggling to know that there were so many millions died shipping slaves around the world.

title: Inhuman reality which is a blot on mankind - A MUST VISIT
text:
This castle is located at a place which is about 180 kms. from Accra & takes around 3 hours (one way) to reach.

Cape coast Castle is a historical monument with a sordid & tragic story to tell.

This was the place where black man & women were captured from the whole of West Africa,, brought here & kept in the basement of this castle for onward shipment to Americas, Europe & the Carribean.

The men & women were kept separately in underground dungeons in the most unimaginable conditions.

In a 800-100 sq.feet chamber approximately 200 men were kept. They ahd to eat there, sleep there & do everything in that chamber only till the time they were shipped abroad.

Of the total numbers only about 65% could survive & shipped out of the castle.

The rest died in that very chamber.

Females were kept seperately & were subjected to continuous sexual exploitation.

One shudders to think that the governor of the castle was staying in the same castle lavishly.

The Britishers built a church just above the dungeon where slaves were kept like animals , were tortured & many even died.

What an irony !!!

title: October
text: There on a weekend off from volunteering. Was very moving and eerie of what the captives went through. From the chains on the walls to the dungeon and the point of no return. Wreaths and bouquets left in the cells was heart breaking.

title: Emotional History
text: It's a tour everyone should do when you visit Ghana or if you are in Ghana. Very very emotional tour. Very educative and informative. Good for school groups, individuals, cooperate, families, solo.

title: Lohnenswert
text:
Sehr interessante Führung mit einem tiefen Einblick in die dunklen Abgründe der menschlichen Geschichte. 
Nichts für sensible Seelen, sehr informativ und auch sehr nahe gehend.

title: Worth a visit for whatever it is worth :)
text: I was at this museum a week ago with my 8 year old and a 10 year old. The Guide wasn't definitely the best you could get but he made quite an effort. I'd suggest that if you're attending with below 10 kids you do the explaining yourself. The museum is good to get some knowledge of the local cultures that are fast fading away. The Nigerian Government part of the Museum is also a bit interesting especially for the presence of the Car in which a Nigerian President was shot. If you find yourself in Lagos, take a trip there for cultural purposes. Very very cheap entry fee too.

title: Not very well maintained
text: For a NATIONAL MUSEUM a disappointment. The museum is not very well maintained and the curation is quite poorly done.

title: Has seen better days
text: I visited the National Museum during my January 2015 trip to Lagos. I was extremely disappointed by what I saw. First of all, there was no power. Given that this is Nigeria, that in itself was not disappointing...what was disappointing was that the "National Museum" of a country as large as Nigeria did not appear to have an emergency power generator.The attendants indicated no desire to provide any customer service, they appeared to be marking time until 4pm. There were virtually no exhibits to speak about - the one area that they claimed had exhibits could not be accessed if there was a power outage. All the more reason to have a generator! Outside the main museum, the entry to the hut used to store the bullet-ridden Mercedes car of the late dictator, Murtala Muhammed, was being used to wash cars. The entire scene was both comical and sad, and reflective of how rotten the core of Nigeria truly is.

title: Could be such an exciting place to visit . . .
text: . . . but unfortunately enough the entire museum is in a very bad shape, the exhibits are badly conserved and the lighting in some of the (few) rooms is horrible. You are not allowed to take pictures, but ironically you can touch some of the artifacts. Nigeria has a very rich history and deserves a much more appealing "National Museum". The most interesting part is a little shack outside the museum (but being part of it), with a brief historic outline of Nigeria's history after Independence and the original bullet-riddled Mercedes in which president Murtala Mohamed was assassinated.

title: A National Museum
text: This is one of Nigeria's most historical sites and would need to be well maintained for posterity.  It has a rich history of the events that took place right from the slavery days to present day political climate.  I would recommend a visit just to help a tourist understand the history of the country and the variety of cultures.

title: 第４代大統領Murtala Mohammed氏が暗殺された車が生々しい
text: ナイジェリアが国家となる前の時代からヨルバ族　イボ族　ハウサ族がどのように暮らしてきたかが展示されている。ガイドさんが付いてくれて説明してくれる。館内は撮影禁止。別館に第４代大統領が暗殺された際のメルセデスが、そのままの状態で保存されており大変生々しい。一度は訪問しておくと良いかもしれません。入園料は外国人300ナイラ、ナイジェリア人200ナイラ。

title: Enlightening...
text:
As an Expat in Lagos I really wanted to understand the history and dynamics which have shaped this amazing vibrant city of incredible contrast...from run down relics of destruction to high rise chrome and glass splendor, fine hotels and human squalor....I know about the various coups and period of Military rule but I , sadly, did not know much. Our Driver, a fine educated man by the name of Isaac took us to the museum one Saturday and we left very much enlightened.
The Museum will not win any awards and certainly needs to be upgraded and updated but it fulfilled its task in enlightening us....job done!

title: Must see Lagos landmark
text:
I have been visiting the national museum since i was a child and there was a time when my local church (house on the rock) used to hold its Wednesday and Sunday services at the MUSON Center which is opposite the Museum. 
It has great exhibitions from our past and i know that anytime i take out of town visitors who appreciate art to the exhibitions on display, they always leave with that 'wow' feeling. 
i wish they didn't move the Murtala Muhammed exhibition away from the main building into that shed though. i want to assume they had a good reason for doing so.
all in all, its an affordable place to go pay a visit(i paid N100 for a ticket the last time i visited in 2012). You can take your date to the museum instead of the usual cliched cinema/shopping mall. 
I am not sure if the museum kitchen is still function though. it used to serve delicious ,affordable meals back in the day

title: Nigerian history custodian
text: It would amaze you to find artefacts that tells a lot of history at this venue. It is a place often over looked but worth visiting.

title: Amazing recent Exhibit at the end
text:
It's a bit faded and slightly neglected, but let yourself be shown round by one of the enthusiastic guides. They really do add value, Worth wishing them a happy weekend, and where else would you meet a guy called Cosmos?
The main displays concentrate on Nigerian history before the Portugese arrived

The final display is more recent and includes the Nigerian equivalent of Kennedy's limo. This is kept in a shed.

Highly recommended

title: A good visual overview
text: The car in which the President was assassinated was added to the in which the Archduke Ferdinand was assassinated and the uniform in which Nelson was shot ... The Museum is small but gives a good impression of recent events.

title: History of Nigeria in one Building
text: The National Museum is not just your regular museum but one that holds vital information about the history of the country. A great place to take the children. The best part of the trip is seeing the Mercedes Benz Limousine the former  Military President Major Murhitala Mohammed was assassinated in.

title: Interesting but a bit rundown
text:
In all an interesting museum with historical artifacts from the history of Nigeria. Had an exhibition about the traditional life of different groups in Nigeria (with focus on the past of course). Very enthusiastic guide, included in the entrance fee, who actually told things that were not on the labels of the objects. 
At the moment the masterpieces from the Ife culture are not in the museum as they are on loan to other museums across the world as that part is being renovated.

As a national museum it's a bit of a disappointment "is this all?", after all it's the national museum in the countries largest city by far! But it is still a must if you visit Lagos as it gives some insight into the history of the different parts of Nigeria.
Note: the outside has a playground which is not recommended for children as it is too worn down, i.e. dangerous.

title: Learn about Nigeria's ancient civilizations and cultures
text: The museum exhibits Nigeria's ancient civilizations and traditional religions. You can learn more about the different ethnic groups in Nigeria. Moreover, the museum displays Nigeria's government of yesterday and today. Everything is labelled clearly but you can also get someone to show you around for some tips. This is not a European standard museum and you can see that few Nigerians have visited or know about the museum. Still, I think it's worth a visit as you can learn about some old traditions and see some local art.

title: Simple but a must-do! Emblematic!
text: This is a very basic museum but emblematic enough to be visited. Enjoy some free time and a walk in the surroundings.

title: Visite à faire sur le site
text: On ne peut pas passer dans la région sans visiter ce site qui nous rappelle un bien triste passé. Très beau monument du souvenir.

title: Merece la pena
text: Ubicado en el antiguo fuerte portugués, el museo está algo destartalado y vacío de turistas. Es muy útil para conocer mejor la historia de la ciudad (reyes de Ouidah y mapas interesantes). El fuerte además es bonito de ver

title: Best if combined with the Route of the Slaves
text:
The museum itself is quite sparse, although a good guide can help to bring it altogether to give a good overview. Don't worry there are English speaking guides available and there is no obligation to tip (even if mentioned!).

It's best to combine this with the route of the slaves which can be organised through the museum or someone will find you! Again there are English speaking guides and you will need transport for this 4km route - a zem (motorbike) or your own car.

title: Une visite intéressante et émouvante
text: Une visite incontournable, en visitant le Bénin. Bien entretenu, bien présenté. Le Fort Portugais était l'un des lieux de rassemblement et de vente des esclaves. Bon accueil, la guide était bien informée, très intéressante. A ne pas manquer.

title: Good guided tour
text: We were impressed by the tour guide.  The museum has just enough in it to make it interesting. The guides explanation in English was well done

title: Musée non entretenu
text: Nous avions visité le musée en 2009. 7 ans après il est complètement détérioré. Les objets ont quasiment tous disparus il ne reste que des photos. Malgré cela nous avons eu un très bon guide qui a su rendre la visite très intéressante et prenante.

title: Impressionant
text:
Assez peu d objets sont presentes, mais le batiment lui meme est un ancien fort portugais, et cela suffit pour que le guide nous raconte 400 ans d histoire de son pays.
A ne pas rater

title: Knowledgeable staff who spoke English
text: My colleague took me here to learn about the slave trade & to see the Door of no Return. We started at the museum and were able to get an English speaking guide who took me through the museum - it's a little run down and the artefacts are displayed a bit shabbily but they still are able to tell the story of the Portuguese fort well. We were then able to get a different guide to ride in our car as we drove down the slave road to explain the different stops along the way. It was very informative and really helpful to have the guide as there are limited descriptive plaques. We finished at the Python temple where I could hold 2 snakes and have my picture taken.

title: Très touchant
text: Il est parfois impirtant de connaître et surtout de comprendre l'histoire d'un pays et de tout un peuple.. visite très enrichissante et très touchante. Si vous passez à Ouidah un stop est nécessaire !

title: very intersting location
text: i think visit to ouidah is must if you came to visit in Benin, the slave route and the musem are intersting locations which you can get short history lesson about the slavery time.

title: Sehr interessant
text: Auch wenn nicht sehr viele Exponate geboten werden, ist die Ausstellung gerade mit den Dokumenten der grausamen Sklavereigeschichte absolut sehenswert.

title: Sans intérêt... gardez votre guide du routard !
text: Dans un cadre plus proche de la décharge que d'un musée visant à retracer l'histoire d'un peuple et d'une ville capitale dans l'histoire de la traite négrière, vous ne pouvez vous déplacer dans la présence d'un guide (qui n'a de guide que le nom) qui visiblement s'entraine pour un sprint... visite bâclée, explications toujours attendues et surtout surtout... vestiges essentiellement constitués de photocopies... bref, amateurs d'histoire... passez votre chemin;

title: Denkmal und Hütten
text: Ein Museum gibt es hier nicht. Man kann das Gate of no return besichtigen. Auf dem großen Platz finden am 10.01. die Vodoo Festlichkeiten statt. Es liegt außerhalb von Ouidah (15 Min Fahrt). Eine Ansammlung von Souvenirshops und zwei Bars. Die Straße runter gibt es noch ein Denkmal vom Papst J.Paul II und das Gate of Return zu besichtigen. Auf der Strecke liegen einige Restaurants.

title: Mediocre
text: Il monumento non è poi sto granché, è importante vederlo più che altro per rendersi conto delle atrocità di cui l'uomo è capace.

title: A Portuguese Fort rebuilt in 1968: mostly empty rooms
text:
The arch way in the photo is the "Point of Return" on the shore of the sea. Slaves were marched the 4km from Ouidah on the Rue des Esclaves. It is the point of return because the slaves believed there spirits would return even if their bodies did not.
The museum is housed in what was the Portuguese fort which was burned down after independence. Little of the original remains, what you see is mostly a reconstruction. There are few items of real interest inside, some are reproductions.

title: Très émouvant !
text: Sur la route des esclaves, trop d'émotions à penser que des millions d'êtres humains, vendus par leurs rois, sont partis de ces côtes pour servir d'esclave

title: Small but nice museum in an historic building
text: This rather interesting museum is located in the old Forte de São João Baptista de Ajudá. This fort has an interesting history. With its 5 acres (~2 ha), it was at one time the world’s smallest internationally-recognized political unit. It was built on land given to Portugal by King Haffon of Ouidah in 1721, and remained under Portuguese administrative control until Jul 31, 1961. On Aug 1 of the previous year, Dahomey (now Benin) had become independent, and its new government gave Portugal one year to vacate the premises and move on! When the ultimatum expired, the resident Portuguese population of the fort (2 inhabitants, down from 5 in 1921…) tried to set it on fire, rather than surrender it to the new country. The issue only reached closure in 1975, i.e., after the Portuguese revolution of the previous year, when Portugal recognized Dahomey’s sovereignty over the fort. In 1987, the Fundação Gulbenkian of Portugal funded the full rehabilitation of the historic facility, which now houses Ouidah’s Museum of History.

title: History
text: Hmmmmm. This is a must visit if you are in Cotonou. We arrived here and got a volunteer guide to take us around after we paid the official government tariff. Harry our guide was very good and told the stories with a lot of empathy.

title: site UNESCO sur esclavage
text: très bon site historique à ne pas râter à Ouidah pour connaître les méandres de l'esclavage dans le Golfe de Guinée

title: Piacevole scoperta
text: Galleria molto carina e curata. Artigianato locale e i veri colori di capo verde riassunti nelle varie opere esposte

placeInfo.name: Visoes Africanas
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Juhno 159, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: I love Art
text: Can you believe you can find a real Art Gallery in this so little town of this so little island Sal? I did. I found Visoes Africanas and I was amazed to see how many good and famous artists were showing their work there. I was not prepare to find this gallery and didn't buy any painting but if I come back again in vacation in Sal I will have a thought about.

ownerResponse.text: Thank you! We are really happy to hear you enjoyed visiting our gallery. You can also check out our website visoesafricanas.com until next time we see you in Sal.

placeInfo.name: Visoes Africanas
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Juhno 159, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Amazing place for local goods
text: Lekki market is amazing place for finding local goods including handicrafts, woodwork, metalwork, painting, precious stones, old coins etc. Need to bargain for shopping.

title: some great bargains if you haggle
text:
i hadn't been for a while and the road is pretty bad. Not a place to go with dodgy tires on your car.
I went on a Sunday early afternoon deliberately as not everyone opens so it wasn't as crowded as it can get on other days.
A really good variety of art work, fabric and souvenirs. Quite a few shops with ready made african wear and some really well made solid african style carved furniture ( everything from wine cupboard to chest of drawers ) . You get the usual tourist souvenirs but there are some more unusual goodies if you look hard enough . A very large range of paintings in different media and for all tastes, from the basic ( something to cover your walls)  to beautiful detailed paintings.
Prices as in all markets in Africa are variable from expensive to pretty cheap . if you aren't good at haggling I strongly recommend going with someone who knows how to haggle.
It is also a good place to buy fresh fruit and vegetables !

title: Love
text: I just love this market! Downright African and affordable! Especially for those who live abroad, if you come in for a visit to Nigeria, you would definitely want to visit here for souvenirs.. i took a friend there and i practically had to drag her away, lol

title: Overhyped ....too Ordinary
text: Been to many Art and local fabric ready to wear markets ... this place is over hyped and nothing to write home about . The road to the place is totally unmotorable during the raining season .

title: Worth a visit but difficult to find
text: Other reviewers were right-- this place is difficult to find. We only found it with the help of google maps and the fact that my husband had been there years ago.  The roads were atrocious-- a result of the rains, and I'm told they're repaired after the rainy season.  I wouldn't risk the trip in anything other than a 4WD (one that i didn't care too much about).  That said, it's a nice place to purchase souvenirs and let your tourist dollars trickle down a bit to some local merchants.

title: Well worth a visit
text:
If you are travelling to Lagos then the Lekki tourist market is well worth.a visit. You can choose between some very good paintings, carvings, belts, bracelets and local pearls. There are also great opportunities to by fabric and shirts and dresses.

Well worth a visit. Remember to bargain hard!

title: Good place to buy local artefacts
text: Lekki market is the place just under 1roof where you can get artefacts, local- traditional jewellery ,pearls, paintings, souvenirs to gift or decoration...only thing you have to bargain a lot 😔 ...You get vegetables...household stuff at very reasonable price n can get local dress material and get it stitched at the same place.

title: ,lovelt artisans market, dont forget to bargain
text: Lovely place full of art and crafts especially wooden and bronze artifacts, local leather goods, paintings, furniture, pearls, marble articles, local clothes etc. Dont forget to bargain if you need a good deal.they understand foreign languages like hindi and arabic.it is a worthwile experience that anyone interested in local art should have.

title: Shopping Experience
text: Unique experience. Very interesting assortment of Beadwork, African Art and well-made colourful handbags. Very friendly people.

title: Great spot for souvenir shopping
text: Lekki market is slightly hard to get to - especially if it had rained a lot and the roads are flooded! When you get near to the market ask people for the "arts and crafts" market as locals are not familiar with the name Lekki market in our experience. The market has a lovely selection of handmade things and you can see people working on their crafts. Bartering is encouraged and vendors all say the price they are giving you is negotiable. Compared to other places we have been to in Asia and Africa we did not feel overly hassled and were able to browse the arts and crafts without too much difficulty.

title: More shops, more variety, and more prices.
text:
I went to this market today with a friend to pick a few articles of art for house decorations.

The place is as interesting and nice as ever. Good for souvenirs, decorative items, paintings, carvings and antiques.

The prices are very low, and buying more than one piece is an incentive to drive and get a better bargain.

To me, it is better than most museums in Nigeria. Only that you need to engage each store manager or sales person to get the stories and labels of each article.

The prices are very low, but haggling over the prices seemed a little more tiring for me this time around. 

In all, it was another interesting evening in Lagos.

title: great day
text: I would really recommend this destination... each time i am there i am facinated by the arts and crafts, shop keeps hospitalitiy... went with no idea of purchasing... fortune spent and great value... negoitiating is the name of the game... enjoy your visit

title: Hidden treasures
text:
I visited this market to get Ankara bags which I saw in town for 9k. I got them for 3k direct from the stall owners.

It's not too big so you should be in and out in under an hour but there are tons of interesting pieces there. Many stalls are owned by the artist themselves.

Try to avoid the touts Who pretend to be the stall owners and get a commission for bringing a customer. Look around, decide and the go to the shop owner.

It's quite hot there so dress accordingly

:)

title: spending the naira!
text: it's a pity that the road is full of potholes as it's a lovely market to visit with some lovely items. I got a good bargain of some african dresses for my daughter as to buy cloth and find a tailor would've been much more expensive. we enjoyed our time spent here.

title: Compras artesanal
text: En Lekki market encuentras de todo lo que busques, desde utensilios para la cocina como monedas de colección. lo que necesites lo encontraras a buenos precio y si regateas mucho mejor,  días especiales martes y viernes.

title: Love love love
text:
What an amazing adventure!
There is something fir everyone
Bring your hat though there is no sun cover!
Lots of French speakers there

title: Started off Shady
text: Well first off none of the locals have ever heard of this place.  And GPS is a no go.  We finally arrived at a typical Lagos outside market and asked someone who knew where it was.  It's situated behind the "shanty market" for lack of a better term.  Once in and after I stopped sweating, they actually have some pretty nice things.  I have some misgivings about whether these items, carvings, stone work, and some paintings are actually produced by the sellers because from one booth to the next, they all look the same.  Nothing stood out as something I just had to have or that I couldn't get a local (Portland, Oregon) jewelry maker to design.  I'm headed up to Abeokuta to see if I can't find authentic pottery and Adire.

title: Shop for Unique Memorabilia
text: Here one cannot find fridge magnets, but there is plenty of other artefacts that can later remind you f this interesting country with long history. Lekki Market is one of those selling places where you will find livestock, next to clothes, next to bananas and tomatoes, next to jeweleery. And it is really exciting to see. Small tip - do not go alone. If you have a local taxi driver with you, that would be great. Or go in groups.

title: For bargaining gurus
text:
Make you visit when you have plenty of time, the golden rule is not to buy from the first stall. Don't be afraid to bargain as prices of goods are ridiculously set higher than their real value. 

The work of painters are remarkable as well as ladies accessories. Some products are available in all the shops and they seem to be made by the same producer.

Finally you will be very happy to have brought your a large bottler of mineral water.

title: For all your arts and crafts needs
text: The products of local talent on display at reasonable prices - paintings, carvings, beads, corals, cloths, adorned swords, metal work, lion teeth, leopard skins, you name it, you'll probably find it. Can spend an entire day here without covering a quarter of the shops. Well worth a visit for anyone looking for artsy things.

title: Elmina Castle Tour
text: Excellent guide who led us through the harrowing history of the castle and the slave trade.  He was mindful of the hazards of steps, low doorways, uneven paths etc., and took care to ensure our safety.

title: picturesque
text: Real nice dutch castel! Nice organisation. Just they’re most to take care more and renovate.Hope visit again

title: Everyone should take this tour!
text: I have never been more profoundly moved as I had been on this tour.  It brings home the realities of how horrible, inhumane,  and wicked slavery was. It was life-changing.

title: A walk down memory lane
text:
The historically nostalgic edifice that takes you back in time and recounts the story of how slaves were treated and shipped abroad. This monstrous structure set at a strategically ideal location along the Central regional coastline with easy access to the Western region initially named São Jorge da Mina by the Portuguese, the Elmina castle as we now know it will go on to be declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979.

It currently stands as the oldest European building in existence South of the Sahara, and a guided tour through its dungeons and dining area, corridors and chapel, residencies and occupancies makes you better appreciate the mix of emotions, intrigue, suspense, surprise, marvel and mysteries this historical treasure has to offer. 

Our onboard photographer made sure we captured all the memorable moments experienced on the trip.

title: history
text: interesting place to visit when you in the Cape coast. the tour guides gives you inept knowledge of the slave trade

title: The Door of No Return
text:
I took a three hour ride from Accra to Elmina Castle which is situated at the edge of a rough Atlantic Ocean. Stepping through the gate of the castle was reliving the days of slavery and the slave trade. It can make one get real emotional. It is a good place to take history students so they can see history come alive. The 'door of no return' stood out in my memory so much! It was the little slit in the wall through which slaves were pushed into waiting boats which took them to bigger ships which then took them to other lands. 
I left their with my name written on a shell, welcoming me to the area and to Ghana. There are young people at the gates of the castle who in  friendly manner introduce themselves and ask your name. They get the correct spelling then tell you that you will get a gift at the end of your visit into the castle. When you return to the outside you are given the shell and you are asked for a contribution. I saw a tourist arguing with one youngster as he wanted U$5 for the shell. (The shell did not value that.) It is best to change your money to cedis. 1USD- 5cedis.

title: Historical site to be seen
text: Visiting this place just opens your eyes to a part of the past that has shaped a large part of our daily life without us even thinking or k owing about it. The bookshop in there is a wonderful place to find some interesting books about the region and the topic of slavery.

title: Rich history
text: The castle has a very rich and moving history. Our tour guide (Nana) had a tactical and emotionally-engaging way of delivering the history of the castle. During the tour, it almost felt as though we were living the story.

title: Must see. Amazing history
text: I learned more in a one hour tour with a guide than all of the history in my education. Everyone needs to experience this place!    Allow some extra time for photos and videos. The books and videos are expensive but they to sell them to you throughout the tour.

title: WE RETURNED SO WE WON
text:
The grief comes unexpectedly. Embrace it and travel 1-1 or just with your people and guide (privacy is necessary).

A PLACE FOR DIASPORA TO SEE 100000%

Never Foget and continue to make our ancestors proud.

Trip was December 2017.

title: HISTORY
text: I have visited El Mina castle several times. Try to get Robert for the tour, he is very good. His book which is sold in the little store is a must read too. And I would suggest combining your castle visit with a tour of the town El Mina. Contact Felix Nguah from Ghanaecotours. fnguah@ghanaecotours.com. He will take good care of you.

title: Preserving this place must be a priority.
text: This is one of the major existing structures that supported the enslavement of humans based on the color of their skin. Elmina represents the collective shame of Europe and these structures should always serve as a reminder of what is possible when the humanity of people is not respected. The government tour guides are very knowledgeable and are able to give visitors a history of every aspect of the structure. No visit to the area is complete without also visiting the Cape Coast enslavement structure.

title: Extremely interesting  impressive place
text: The view of the castle from each direction - close as well as far - tells immediately that this is a major historical site. Imposing, somber, powerful and so sad. We learned so much and were impressed with the small museum in the old Portugues chapel. Make sure you visit this place as well as the fort in Cape Coast.

title: "Just to Know about the past"
text: I went by friends ...but I was afraid to enter ...I make it through by the help of the tour guide ..I went and learn many things ...I think you should also try to visit

title: Start with the Chapel
text: An amazing and sorrowful place. More than 100 times larger than the Masion des Esclaves on Goree Island.  Look at the chapel where the traders prayed before and after their carnage. I could feel the spirits of my ancestors there.

title: Learn about some of histories sad past
text: I have been through the castle three times, I am on a mission board that brings me in the area once a year, and I always take some of my fellow travelers to visit the slave castle on each trip and never tire of learning of are dark past. The guides have always been very informative and helpful. The parking area has locals that will try to sell you bracelets with your name on. If you are not interested don't give your name.If they have your name they will make you a bracelet and make you feel obligated to buy it.

title: The management of the castle have become more commercially driven
text: This was my second visit to the castle, over 10 years after my first visit. There have been a lot of changes at the castle and it is clear that the managers have become more commercially oriented than in giving visitors a real story. The tour this time was very brief, many of the stories we were told the last time were omitted. And parts of the castle have now been converted to shops where the tour guide spends a lot of energy trying to convince tourists to purchase an item. It was a very shabby experience

title: Da vedere
text: La struttura è ben tenuta e l'ottima descrizione della guida consente di approfondire un pezzo di storia e avere un'idea delle condizioni in cui venivano tenuti gli schiavi.

title: As good as in Cape Coast!
text: Elmina castle is the oldest European fortification built by Portuguese in 1482! The Dutch seized the fort from the Portuguese in 1637. The Dutch were busy with slave trade till 1814. They managed to sell the fort to British in 1872. The Brits did not use the Castle as a slave trade Fort and instead were recruiting the black soldiers for the war in Burma (Myanmar). The fee is 40 cedis for non-Ghanian nationalities and 30 for students. The tour is free of charge.

title: Why are human beeing so cruel to each other??
text: Seeing the depth of thinking that was built into the facility to deconstruct and humiliate a human being was humbling.  The experience was gut-wrenching and visceral.  Everyone should visit this people export facility, to understand how a human being was deconstructed, humiliated and then exported like a commodity or life-stock to then be labeled a slave and further humiliated until death.  Elmina should never be allowed to decay or effaced from the collective heritage of the world.

title: Tournage pour DAHOMEY DISCOVERY
text:
"Sur les pas de mes ancêtres..."

Faire cette découverte avec mes enfants a été un moment chargé d’émotion. Marcher sur les terres d’Abomey, ressentir l’histoire, toucher les murs du passé… c’est une expérience inoubliable. Transmettre cela à mes enfants, c’est leur offrir une part de leur héritage, de leur identité. Merci à tous ceux qui œuvrent pour préserver cette mémoire vivante. Je recommande à toutes les familles afro-descendantes de faire ce voyage symbolique au moins une fois dans leur vie.

title: Peu de choses à voir à part le temple vaudou caméléon
text: Une visite relativement réduite. Le palais d’Abomey est en restauration, donc pas de visite, la partie accessible est seulement une grande cour où vous trouverez les échoppes traditionnelles pour touriste. La visite/tour complète est plus interessante de par les explications du guide. On vous emmènera voir différents palais/cases où à part quelques décorations sur les murs vous ne verrez que des bâtiments vides mais cela reste interessant de par les explications. Le point le plus sympa reste le marché des fétiches vaudou (photos payantes en plus) et la basilique vaudou caméléon où l’on peut rentrer en se déchaussant avant. Le monastère vaudou situé à côté ne se visite pas mais sa décoration est sympa. Parlons du prix : tout est négociable. Le guide qui se présentera à vous devant le palais vous accompagnera pour le circuit en négociant un prix global incluant les différents tickets d’entrée (pour quelles entrées, on se demande). Compter 15K CFA pour le tout. Si vous êtes accompagné d’un béninois, vous aurez plus de chance de réduire le prix. La visite nécessite une voiture avec chauffeur pour se déplacer d’un endroit à un autre.

title: Visite assez chère et d’intérêt limité
text:
Le palais est en rénovation. Il n’est pas visitable actuellement. Malgré cela, un employé du service touristique et un guide nous ont proposé de visiter un certain nombre de sites attenants. Après négociations, leurs tarifs se sont montés à 8000 + 10 000 = 18 000 CFA. A cela s’est ajouté la location d’une voiture (indispensable pour une visite), soit 15 000 CFA.

Cette visite d’environ 3 heures a été moyennement intéressante. La plus grande partie du temps a été consommée en déplacements, les distances étant très grandes. A part un site, il était impossible d’entrer à cause des rénovations. Pour cette raison il m’est un peu difficile de juger mais il semble que beaucoup de « palais » sont réduits à un petit édifice. Le guide déconseillait d’en visiter d’autres, notamment celui du roi Behanzin, parce que cela conduirait à des « complications » = offrandes à faire…

Ce guide était excellent et connaissait sur le bout des doigts l’histoire du Bénin et aussi les détails de la religion vaudoun, point fort de la visite avec un passage au village coeur de cette religion, qui comprend un couvent (inaccessible aux non adeptes). J’ai beaucoup appris, mais cela ne contrebalance pas le coût de la visite et l’indigence des choses à voir.

title: Wygląda bardzo kiepsko.
text:
Już od wejścia widać ,że nie jest to obiekt zadbany .Kompleks dwunastu tzw. pałaców królewskich to w rzeczywistości niczym specjalnym nie wyróżniające się parterowe  budynki. Pochodzą z lat 1625-1900 i należały do kolejnych królów Dahomeju .Przed budynkiem muzealnym strażnik informował ,że muzeum jest zamknięte . Pozostał więc spacer bo dość rozległym terenie i oglądanie zaniedbanych parterowych budynków. 
Kompleks pałacowy jest na liście światowego dziedzictwa UNESCO już od roku 1985 ale już przez jakiś czas był zagrożony wykreśleniem z tej listy.

title: Peccato sia in ristrutturazione
text: Abbiamo potuto vedere poco di questi bei palazzi purtroppo perché è tutto in rifacimento ed è accessibile solo la parte che attornia un grande cortile dove si trovano tutti i venditori. Vale sicuramente una visita ma attualmente ben poco.

title: Absolutamente prescindible
text: Restos del palacio real en el que sólo están las paredes y casi nada en su interior, una persona haciendo telas con un telar del año de la picor y un taller textil

title: andrebbe tenuto meglio
text: Mi aveva incuriosito questo sito perché è l’unico sito UNESCO culturale del paese. Purtroppo non c'è molto da vedere poiché parte degli edifici non è visitabile, i pochi reperti sono in vetrine polverose e non si possono fare foto tranne che nel cortile dove sono in vendita articoli per turisti. Anche i tradizionali tetti di paglia sono stati sostituiti con lamiere arrugginite aumentando un'impressione di degrado. Interessanti le spiegazioni ma sarebbe da tenere meglio.

title: Historical value, unfortunately not well preserved.
text:
A visit to the palace(s) is something you must do. But it is really a pity it is not better maintained. It has great historic and cultural value.
We had a great English speaking guide, who also guided us around further in the city of Abomey.
Guide : Hyacinthe  + 229 95 54 46 33
Aside from that very few things foreseen for tourists (icl. Toilet). But it seems some investments to come with the French cooperation.

The Palace is still being used by the King, so when the king is there you take off your shoes (hot sand!)  And can be a bit crowded because of ceremonies.
Photos not allowed, but can work around that 🙃.

title: Interesting and peaceful place to visit
text:
We really enjoyed our visit but agree with others that there isn’t much information given by the palace itself, so for the best experience you should go with a guide. With a guide we found the visit and the palace really interesting and enjoyed learning about the history of Abomey. 
(We visited with English-speaking guide, Mark, who is one of a group of guides from across the country who were trained up by the government. Mark was excellent and showed us all the best sites of Abomey. We sadly did not note down his surname but your hotel should be able to help you find him, as ours did).

title: Une visite incontournable à Abomey
text: Il n'y a pas grand chose à voir malheureusement car la plupart des bâtiments ne sont pas accessibles. On prend conscience de la taille du site, l'histoire est bien racontée par les guides, mais il est interdit de photographier ( alors que de nos jours ce sont les réseaux sociaux qui suscitent l'envie ). Les quelques reliques sont enfermées dans des présentoirs poussiéreux dans des bâtiments sans éclairage. Vraiment dommage car le Bénin tient là un potentiel touristique exceptionnel qu'il ne sait malheureusement pas exploiter. Cela reste tout de même une visite incontournable à Abomey.

title: Interesting regional history
text:
The tour has to be done without shoes and it's a big compound, We were also told that photos weren't allowed during the tour. Organizing a guide is essential because there is a lot of history and there aren't any plaques through the palace describing the artifacts or functions. It is still a functioning palace and while we were there the acting King was holding court in the main courtyard and there were ceremonies which was interesting to experience. 

It was explained to us that the Kingdom of Abomey was the only kingdom in West Africa with an female security force which was established when one of the queens was ruling the kingdom for some years. Our guide explained this to us but the tour would have been improved if there was a plaque that described the circumstances and historical context. 

There were several interesting displays especially the original thrown which was very tall and was resting on the skulls of defeated kings.

title: Abomey mérite mieux que des palais dégradés !
text:
Abomey a été depuis le premier roi Gangnihesdou ( 1600-1621) jusqu'au dernier Behanzin ( 1889-1894)  un puissant royaume appelé plus tard  royaume du Dahomey ( nom francisé). Ces rois de droit divin et au pouvoir absolu , avaient droit de vie et de mort sur leurs sujets.  Ils pratiquaient la décapitation , sans hésiter.  Ils ont , pendant la période de l'esclavage, vendu nombre de leurs vaincus et de leurs sujets aux négriers européens . Le marché de Ouidah a été florissant pendant des siècles.

Le système royal est entièrement réglé par le roi qui dispose d'un nombre important de concubines qui sont suppervisees par la reine mère.  Les derniers rois utilisaient  des amazones, femmes entraînées à la guerre , qui sont restées fidèles jusqu'à dernier moment pendant la conquête française, qui a déposé le roi Behanzin en 1894 . Avec sa redoutable armée,  le royaume à vassalise les autres royaumes de l'actuel Bénin à l'exception de celui de Hogbonou ( Porto Novo ) où le roi  Joffa avait déjà conclu un accord commercial avec la France en 1882.
Le roi Behanzin , bien qu'ayant règne que 5 ans , est très populaire , car  il est le symbole de la résistance contre l'envahisseur français   qui a eut du mal à le vaincre, malgré une supériorité numérique et technologique. 

La visite de ce musée est décevante  , par la vétusté des lieux , la médiocrité en valeur des quelques objets et par l'interdiction de prendre des photos , que je considère comme contre productive pour la promotion du site .Seules les explications  du guide sont détaillées et intéressantes. Le seul endroit où les photos sont autorisées est la première cour où les marchands du temple présentent leurs objets pour touristes. A noter que ce qui donne une impression de dégradation sont les tôles rouillées qui ont remplacé les toits traditionnels en paille . De même, les vitrines qui présentent des objets sont tellement sales qu 'on a du mal à les distinguer !

L'entrée est payante 1000 francs pour les beninois et 3000 francs pour les autres .

title: Très bel héritage du royaume du Dahomey
text: Vaste domaine royal où l'on peut découvrir le passé culturel très riche de cette partie du Bénin. Très bon guide en prime

title: Une visite incontournable et intéressante
text: Je n'étais plus allé la-bas depuis des années. Malheureusement l'endroit est décrépie faute d'argent pour l'entretenir. C'est désormais gratuit pour tous. Un excellent guide connaissant bien son histoire nous à fait visiter les lieux pendant 1H30. c'était bien expliqué. Pas grand chose à voir dans les bâtiments et les quelques objets exposés sont poussiéreux et les vitrines suffisamment sales pour empêcher de lire les explications. Malgré cela, ça reste intéressant, il faut le faire. Les artisans locaux, à la sortie, sont sympas et les articles pas trop chers ( mais bien sur, toujours négocier le prix ). N'oublier pas de prendre une bouteille d'eau avec vous.

title: See it - but with a guide
text:
Its a little difficult for an European to be impressed by these few clay-based, single story bulidings. They are ancient by the standards in Benin, as they have been constructed around 1830-ish. Unfortunately they did not refurbish ANY of the furniture, maps & graphics hanging on the walls. Most of them are impossible to read. 

They have a much venerated grave of the king Ghezo, which they believe is still with us, as the hut was supposed to be his room. There used to be furniture, but they threw it out, and nobody cared enough to even put a random bed  and some chairs there to pretend that they are the originals. 

There are a few artifacts in the museum - some of them very interesting but in high state of disrepair. By that I mean that they are literally falling apart. The famous  throne with 4 skulls is in a glass cabinet so dirty that you can barely see the shape of that throne.

But dont be discouraged by all this. Get a guide to tell you the stories behind all that and you will really enjoy your time.

title: A must for the history!
text: A rather interesting but harsh history of the royals. I'd definitely recommend as a lot of history here. Guide was excellent. The grounds are v big. Definitely worth a visit..

title: le roi Béhanzin
text:
e #Roi_Gbèhanzin et une partie de sa famille ont été déportés vers la Martinique. Après plusieurs années d'une farouche guerre anticolonialiste, #Gbèhanzin se rendra au Colonel Dodds pour épargner son peuple mais aussi pour essayer d'aller trouver des explications à cette invasion auprès du président français Carnot. 

Le roi du Danxomè se faisait alors accompagner de son fils Wanignilo, de son cousin Adandédjan, 3 de ses filles, 4 reines et du couple Fanou, son traducteur. 

Gbèhanzin ne rencontrera jamais aucun président français, il mourra 12 ans plus tard à Blida (Algérie) de colère et de maladie.

La suite, c'est 125 ans de pillage, d'humiliation, de déshumanisation, qui laisseront place à la corruption, l'irresponsabilité et à l'incurie de notre élite.

title: le roi béhanzin
text:
Béhanzin né en 1845 et mort en 1906, est traditionnellement le onzième roi d’Abomey. Fils de Da-Da Glèlè Kini-Kini, Béhanzin est d’abord connu sous le nom d’Ahokponu puis de prince Kondo à partir de 1875.

Béhanzin est Roi du Dahomey du 6 janvier 1890 au 15 janvier 1894, date de sa reddition. Il décède à Blida (Alger) le 10 décembre 1906. Être sacré, il porte plusieurs titres : Dada (père de toute la communauté), Dokounnon (détenteur et dispensateur de biens), Sèmèdo (maître du monde), Aïnon (maître de la terre), Jèhossou (maître des perles), etc.

Ses insignes de pouvoir sont le kataklè (tabouret tripode), les afokpa (sandales), le avotita (pagne tissé et décoré de motifs appliqués), le awè (parasol), le makpo (spetre), le so (fusil) et lehwi (sabre). Il a été marié à douze femmes et a eu probablement plus de cinquante enfants.

title: Belle héritage du passé.
text: Ce n'est pas le Louvre bien entendu mais une belle part de l'histoire des rois d'Abomey vous sera raconté par des guides compétents. NB, une rénovation du site est prévue, une belle invitation au tourisme au Bénin.

title: Interesting place
text: The place itself does not really look like a palace, but with a good guide you do get the story and the right impression. We liked especially the strange clay figurines on the walls and the stories behind them, they are quite unique. Do ask about their active involvement in the slave trade - it made them insanely rich and powerful.

title: I had a nice chilling time with the gods
text: It's an active groove with engravements of history of the Osogbo people. I took tour around the place with the help of a guide.

title: Mystischer Ort
text:
Ich bin von Ibadan aus angereist - Bus 2000 Naira und Motortaxi zum Eingang 500 Naira. Die Fahrt nach Osun dauert ca. 2h. 
Am Eingang liegt eine Preisliste aus: Eintritt für Studenten 1.000 Naira, Fotos mit dem Handy 1500 Naira. Mir wurde noch ein Guide empfohlen, aber 8.000 Naira waren mit zu viel. Natürlich versteht man nicht allzu viel, wenn man ohne Guide den heiligen Hain besichtigt. Zumindest sind im Wald viele Skulpturen und Schreine zu sehen. Auf dem Rückweg bin ich zum Fluss und durfte bei einer Zeremonie zuschauen. Nichts für schwache Nerven, da eine Ziege geköpft wurde. Aber nichtsdestotrotz eine interessante Erfahrungen. 
Am Eingnag ist ein kleiner Souvenirshop, welcher eher Schmuck führt.

title: Священный лес
text: Священный для племён йоруба лес. Почитается как место обитания богини плодородия Осун. В 2005г внесен в список Всемирного наследия Юнеско.

title: Ok
text:
The two hour guided walk was tranquil and interesting. The monkeys running around with their babies hitched to their bellies very cute, but they leap and jump yo grab bananas from you! 

I was surprised that the fantastical  and unusual (if not downright weird ) statues  depicting local spiritual beliefs by Austrian  Suzanne Wenger  surrounding the grove resulted in it being inscribed on the UNESCO heritage. To my mind  Nigeria has more impressive sights like the Benin Bronzes and Badagry. I wouldn’t come all the way from overseas to see this, but if in the area  sure…

title: Exciting
text: The view is beautiful as well as the welcoming monkeys although the pay for the camera is a big turn off for me but it is a lovely place to visit.

title: A Groove with Historical Views and Persons On Ground to tell the tale
text:
i visited the groove and saw with my own eyes stories read from books and journals and i met those to give brushes to the history been shed for years.
I was privileged to witness the cleansing process before worshippers were allowed into the groove, i took pictures too to this effect as well.
Nigeria is got an heritage to cling to if properly harnessed.

title: With friends
text: It was a very sunny Saturday and its good to Na at the osun grove although we met none there but I did satisfy my need to visits there and the monkeys are very interesting ones

title: Historical and inspirational
text:
I love the fact that with the osun osogbo a part of our tradition and history is being preserved. The mona monkeys welcome you on arrival. its 1000 naira per person to visit 200 Naira for mobile cameras and about 2000 Naira for digital digital camera. Your fee includes a guide that takes you around the grove. There is a yearly festival in august that attracts visitors and osun worshippers from everywhere.

The Osun Osogbo grove also includes an art village with tye and dye, paintings, wood carvings, drums and other arts and craft. its totally worth a visit

title: Lovely but eerie 😀
text: So once you step into this place, youd have an eerie feeling, seems like all the African gods inhabit this place, decorated with very creative artwork, the grove is a place to be, get close to nature, experience healing and meditation, if you love the African tradition and culture, here is your goto destination. Expect to see monkeys jumping around, and reserve some tips for the praying women at the entrance of the shrine. Feel free to to pray to the river goddess,  and experience walking through the first ever suspension bridge in Nigeria.

title: Worth the visit!
text: This was one of the first sites I visited in Nigeria and it was worth it. Takes you on a journey to the ancient Yoruba civilisation. Beautiful art works, amazing architecture, fantastic landscape and nature. I totally enjoyed myself. I hope this site’s maintenance remains top-notch!

title: An Historical Site worthy visit
text:
Osun groove is a sacred groove that has been in existence for so long a time. At the grove, you have the historical consultant who are on ground to take you round and tell you more about the sacred grove. 

Is a good place to visit for one who believe more in culture and traditions.

title: Very intereesting place to visit
text: Susan Wenger, an artist and Yoruban priestess has transform this spiritual with her modern and magical scupturees.

title: The surviving groove of a people
text:
The Osun Oshogbo groove and the people of the ancient town are indivisible.
The adoration for Osun, the deity of fertility is undeniable. The numerous monkeys along the road to the groove and in the groove are a spectacle to behold as they are used to the people. It is a common sight to see drivers parking their cars to give bananas and other food to these animals who are friendly.
I advice anyone that is going to Oshogbo or to explore the groove or the town to go with a guide because most of the places are unmarked. It has no signage or directions.  
It will do the tourist or visitor so much good to employ the service of  a guide because the guide will take the visitor beyond his or bargain.

title: Simply the best tourist attraction in Nigeria
text:
I was there severally time but the best season is august when the festival take place.
Tradition, religions and Nature become a mix of colours and sounds.
You can choose to enjoy the relaxing side or the learning side.
Everyday you can discover new things and statues, not far from the entrance you can taste good and cheap palm wine.
During the festival you can meet people from worldwide.
you cannot leave Nigeria without one visit at the park.

title: Nice day trip
text: Can easily do this on your own, however I did it with a guide in hopes of learning more about the Yorba culture.  Walk through a tranquil park with interesting sculptures.

title: Breathtaking experience!
text: I strongly recommend going to Osun-Osogbo grove if you are in the area. When entering the grove through the main gate, you can already feel the unique energy that lies within. We enjoyed a 2-hour walk through the grove, visiting two shrines and lots of the sculptures/art work on the premises. It's a truly spiritual and peaceful place.

title: Beautiful
text:
We went to the Osogbo Secret Grove last week. We were accompanied by a priest. The nature and art from Susanne Wenger is really special and beautiful.
One should wear sneakers, long trousers and Moskito spray.

title: Magical, beautiful and beyond words.
text:
This is by far the most amazing place I have entered. I want to thank Doyin Olosun for a very interesting tour in the Grove. 
As soon as you step into this sacred virgin forest, you immediately feel the magic all around you, and you sense how you find peace. Here, no trees are getting cut down or animals caught or hunted. The work of Adunni Olorisa (Susanne Wenger) and the Sacred Art Movement is breathtaking and very unique. Monkeys are jumbing around you, hoping that you might have brought some bananas, prayers are being said and blessings given. This place is indeed very sacred for the everyday life of the devotees of the Orisa religion. 
The Osun-Osogbo Sacred Grove is without any doubt a place I would warmly recommend people to experience, with respect for the sacred character of the place.

title: Nigéria 2017
text: Floresta Sagrada de Osun, local cheio de mistérios com o Templo e o Rio Osun e suas sacerdotisas. Em agosto há a festa de Osun, que é visitada por uma multidão de adeptos de orisa. Experiência maravilhosa.

title: Mystical Sacred Place
text:
The Osogbo grove is a serene mystical place and the source of spiritual strength and growth for the Yoruba people including the diaspora. The site, a UNESCO world heritage site has been carefully maintained for tourists and religious devotees. I was impressed by the management and tour guides. 
One could also easily overlook the impressive sculptures on the walls surrounding the grove. Also the grove is home to a number of rare animals, plants and birds. It is a spiritual oasis.

title: Amazing place
