title: Humbling and Sobering Experience
text: Visited the Castle with my wife and 10 years old son and was left numb by the experience. Walking through the entire complex and seeing the sharp contrasts between the dungeons where the slaves were holed up and the lavish, expansive quarters of the slave merchants was too much to bear. What agony and dehumanizing pains my ancestors had to go through with the connivance of greedy and selfish collaborators. The huge irony for us was the Church located on the top floor of the Castle. Highly recommended for all interested in slave trade history. Very knowledgeable tour guide make the visit pleasant and highly informative.

title: Tragically infamous
text: The guided tour of the Cape Coast castle juxtaposes the beauty of the surroundings with the inhumanity of the site.  A UNESCO World Heritage site, this castle is an infamous reminder of the inhumanity of the slave trade. With a small museum on the slave trade, this is a place worth visiting.

title: Offers an opportunity to appreciate the Slave trade - Quite Emotional
text: The Tour of the Cape Coast Castle is an emotional one for any visitor, and coupled with the fact that 2019 has been tagged the 'Year of Return', the significance of the role played by the Slave trade in African history is even more apt.

title: Historical place
text:
A must visit place to get to know more about the history of beginning of slavery. 
You will get also to enjoy the nice views of the ocean.

title: Great setting and views, standard tour and shops
text: This is another castle in the grim series of slave towers along Ghana's coast. Smaller than Elmina, the story is much the same horrific narrative. Several stores inside offer standard fare to tourists. There is normally also an interesting exhibition of local artists

title: Where I started
text: I’m from the Caribbean. This is where My linage started. It’s a powerful very emotional tour. All the tragedies my ancestors had to endure. It fulfilled my heart to be able to go to where it all began although very sad and tragic. The Tour guides are very very informative and knowledgable. It think it cost 10 Ghana Cedis to enter. There’s also gift stores inside. Take time to reflect as the ocean breeze blow please don’t make this experience all about talking videos and pictures. It should be more than that.

title: Educative
text:
Nice reception 
Very good history and brief of the uses and purposes the Castle served during before and after the abolishing of slave trade

title: A Must See
text:
This is one of the most emotional trips that I have taken in my life. 
The fee to enter is really low. The guide was exceptional and although there were only 4 in my group we got our own guide and so were not rushed and could move around the facility at our own pace. He was able to answer most of our questions.
 Remember to wear comfortable shoes as there's quite a bit of ground to cover.

title: history meets Mystery meets 'his story'
text: A MUST VISIT for all visiting Ghana. A slice of history as u walk the talk and relive a part of the history and unvail the mystery surrounding the castle as you hear your guide's story of the castle - giving a slice of history best learnt lesson. On my way back from KAKUM national park  to accra i visited the place and was mesmerised by its history.. actually entered the cold dungeon where slaves were kept in chains soaked in their own excreta with only a small hole at the top to throw water to wash off the excreta when air was unbearable to those soldiers outside. From there they were taken to Door of no return to board ships to america to work in farms never to return back. Last century some of the dead bodies were brought back home from america and reburried in ghana and then the door was renamed door of return. ...

title: Insight into the past
text: Visited the castle on the return trip from Kakum National Park to Accra. Interesting to see the inside. Have a snack or lunch at the Cape Coast Restautant. Personally I found  the guild was very repetitive in his commentary. We could see how terrible the conditions were and didnt need to hear a dozen time that the chained slaves had to urinate, deficate amd menstrate over themselves and others in the dark crowded dungeons.

title: YEAR OF RETURN!
text:
I guess it's Providence that made it possible that I return to Ghana in 2019, designated by the Ghanaian authorities as the "Year of Return" - and more so, that I return to Cape Coast to see the castle again.

Some of my colleagues had not been there before and were teary on the tour of the dungeons and various parts of the slave house, as the castle guide took us around. It's always a sobering experience...

title: Ghana's must visit #1!
text: Taking a guided tour of Cape Coast Castle and learning about slavery cannot leave a sane person indifferent. So moving and very sad. There are other slave trading forts along the coast but this one is not to miss.

title: One of the many Highlights
text: AMAZING place.  The history is presented very well, with a museum with chronological story that really takes time to tell in pictures and words, so good for adults and kids alike.  This was followed by an in person tour that was derived in a sincere and sometimes chilling fashion, but it was excellent to hear the raw emotion that came through when referring to the relatively recent history.  We visited Cape Coast after we had been traveling in Ghana for a few weeks, and had spent time in the north and east, and this really tied a lot of what we had seen and learned together.  I wouldn't miss it.

title: Important Lessons on Slavery
text: A tour of this Castle will reveal important information about slavery centuries ago. It was also used for Gold trade. It is highly recommended for those who want to know about how Global trade was done in the Atlantic centuries ago.

title: Cape Coast Castle
text:
My partner and I visited this World Heritage Site on Monday and, having paid the modest fee to go inside, we’re allocated our guide, Mavis.  

We couldn’t have wished for a more educated and informative guide than Mavis. 

We spent upwards of two hours at the site in a tour that wasn’t at any staged rushed.  

We were given the time to contemplate the horror of what this place once was.  

It is, ultimately, a place and a learning experience that will stay with for a very long time.  

Well worth the effort.

title: Shocking
text: Must see if you're in Ghana. It's terrible to imagine how they treated slaves. The castle is well preserved. We did a guided tour and visited the museum. The view is wonderful.

title: Knowledge is power
text: Cape Coast Castle is one of about forty "slave castles", or large commercial forts, built on the Gold Coast of West Africa by European traders. It was originally built by the Swedes for trade in timber and gold, but later used in the trans-Atlantic slave trade.

title: Sklaven Burg in Cape Coast (Ghana) - ein Besuch wert
text:
Wir machten uns auf den Weg zur Besichtigung des UNESCO Weltkulturerbes „Elmina Castle“ — einer ehemaligen Sklavenburg.  

Elmina Castle wurde 1482 von den Portugiesen erbaut und ist die älteste von Europäern errichtete Sklavenburg Westafrikas. Im Laufe der Geschichte gehörte sie zu dem niederländischen und britischen Kolonialreich. Ursprünglich wurde die Burg für den Warenhandel zwischen Westafrika und Europa erbaut und erst später zur Sklavenburg umstrukturiert. Noch bis zur Abschaffung der Sklaverei im Jahr 1814 wurden hier ca. 3 Millionen Sklaven aus Ghana, Togo, der Elfenbeinküste und Burkina Faso unter unwürdigen Bedingungen gefangen gehalten. Innerhalb der Festung waren bis zu 600 Männer und 400 Frauen zeitgleich in unterschiedlich großen Kammern inhaftiert. Der einzige Auslass aus der Burg bestand durch die „Door of no return“, das heißt die Sklaven wurden auf Schiffen in die Karibik und nach Nordamerika deportiert.

Das Oberhaupt des Castles war der Gouverneur. Dieser suchte sich Frauen als Geliebte aus. Ergab sich daraus eine Schwangerschaft, waren sie „the lucky ones“, da sie in separaten Häusern untergebracht wurden und somit im Land blieben.

Im Vergleich zu den beengten Zellen, in denen beispielsweise bis zu 150 Frauen auf engstem Raum gefangen gehalten wurden, sind die Privaträume des Gouverneurs großzügig. Von seinen Räumen auf der obersten Ebene an der Spitze der Festung blickt er auf die Soldaten und vor allem auf die Gefangenen herab. Heute genießen wir von hier aus einen fantastischen Blick auf den Atlantik. Über die Mauern der Burg hinaus betrachten wir das Treiben des ca. 200 m entfernten Fischerhafens und des daran anschließenden Marktes. Die Fischer kennzeichnen ihre Boote mit internationalen Flaggen, um da eigene bei der Einfahrt in den Hafen schneller erkennen zu können. Die Eindrücke der Vergangenheit trüben unsere Stimmung, doch wie uns der Guide lehrt, sehen wir dies als Mahnmal der Geschichte, die sich nicht wiederholen sollte.

Letzendlich waren wir alle sehr begeistert von der Burg. Die Führung war super. Sie dauert circa 1,5 bis 2 Stunden. Es gibt auch einen kleinen Shop, in dem man Getränke und Souvenirs kaufen kann.
Toiletten sind auch vorhanden.
Es is definitv einen Besuch wert!

title: Ghana Trip
text: Depressing, sad and educational.  I wouldn't recommend for children under 10 years of age, especially if you have a sensitive child like myself

title: Cape coast white castel
text: It was an eye opening experience of what Africans went through during the slave trade period. I wasn’t myself for a while, still not myself, being so close to where it all happened. Nice cordial tour guides. Worth every penny. Africa needs restitution for what happened to them. A place to visit when in Ghana.

title: Sublime fondation d'art contemporain
text:
C'est peut-être le seul lieu culturel dont vous entendrez parler depuis l'Europe, et c'est pour une bonne raison!
Installé dans un ancien édifice colonial, le lieu est très beau. Il expose des artistes africains contemporains, même si vous n'êtes pas passionnés ou que vous n'y connaissez rien, cela vaut le détour. Les pièces sont aérées, les œuvres bien exposées, les guides compétents.
Le prix d'entrée est libre.
Ne manquez pas le café-boutique. Possibilité de déjeuner, mais le café est un peu cher. Par contre la boutique vaut le coup d’œil, pas donné non plus mais original. Vous y trouverez : bijoux, divers objets en tissus africains : sacs de toutes tailles, houses d'ordinateur, cravates, nappes, mais aussi coussins, trousses de toilettes et surtout de nombreux catalogues sur l'art africains et les expositions de la fondation.
Un lieu à ne pas manquer, vaut le déplacement jusqu'à Ouidah!

title: Zinsou Fondation Museum
text:
This museum contains paintings of top Artists and have history of different paintings.
A good place to go if you are a lover of Art

title: Seule visite vraiment plaisante...
text: En effet la maison est superbe, bien rénovée et aérée. Les guides sont bien formés et connaissent leur sujet. La collection est sérieuse, méticuleusement choisie et éclectique. Au final, ce fut pour nous la visite la plus plaisante de Ouidah, sans rabatteurs ou charlatans, calme et agréable.

title: Nice building
text: The building itself is a really pleasant structure and exudes a calm and peaceful ambience. The cafe has very good food and service although expensive for Benin at 1500 for a beer and 5000 for a burger and fries or a nice salad. I am not a lover of contemporary art so I think it best to say nothing regarding that aspect here.

title: Molto interessante
text: Bel museo di arte contemporanea situato in un bell'edificio coloniale stile déco. Pesonale accogliente e disponibile

title: the guide is good
text: the guide was good , the art was good , the problem is the language barrier , they only speak french there

title: tres belle surprise
text: quel bonheur d'avoir été déposée par un ami juste à la porte !!  ce fut un régal , conduite par un guide dont on ne peut oublier le nom : Fortune, un trésor de connaissance et un accueil si simple et chaleureux. Le cadre en lui même est un régal pour les yeux

title: Très bon musée
text: Le musée de la fondation Zinsou à Ouidah a été pour nous une très bonne surprise. L'exposition est très intéressante, et le guide très compétent. L'accès à la fondation est gratuite, mais il est possible de faire un don à la fin de la visite. Le musée a également un très bon café avec wifi. Ce musée mérite le détour.

title: Belle surprise
text: On est tombé par hasard sur ce musée et c'était vraiment une belle surprise. Le guide était très gentil et accueillant: de bonnes explications et un bon aperçu de la culture locale. A visiter absolument.

title: Revenir toujours avec le même plaisir !
text: La villa est belle et l'ambiance somptueuse avec ses couloirs ses fenêtres multiples en bois qui s'ouvre sur l'art contemporain africain. Il faut saluer la performance de cette fondation à Cotonou et à Ouidah avec Marie Cécile Zinsou qui défend l'art contemporain envers et contre tout. Ne ratez jamais à Ouidah cette visite et passer un bon moment à déjeuner ou au café sur des palmes en tissus colorés

title: Redécouverte de l'histoire du Dahomey
text: Au travers d'expositions variées (œuvres artistiques, livres...) on redécouvre l'histoire du Dahomey.

title: Lovely exposition of modern African art and a nice café and gift shop also
text: The Foundation selects truly excellent examples of contemporary art from all over Africa.  It is nicely displayed (a small sample, but definitely worthwhile) in the founder's old family home in Ouidah.  The service and food at the café were good, as was the small but tasteful selection at the gift shop.

title: Bravo. Plein la vue!
text: C est tout simplement extraordinaire de déambuler dans cette superbe villa de style colonial et d y découvrir des œuvres d artistes béninois, nigérians, ghanéens.... avec des guides souriants et sympathiques. Petit détour obligatoire au cafe de La fondation et à la boutique, j adore!

title: Deuxième visite, toujours aussi intéressante !
text: Déjà visité en 2015, nous avons vu cette année une nouvelle exposition très intéressante de masques gèlèdé réalisés suite à une commande du musée visant à enquêter sur les demandes du peuple béninois aux candidats à la future élection présidentielle. En outre nous avons pu constater les efforts de sensibilisation à l'art, réalisés auprès des écoliers de Ouidah : quelle chance pour eux. Bravo à la Fondation.

title: Une très belle visite
text: Ne pas manquer à Ouidah, ce musée improbable dans ce lieu, dans le cadre d'une maison ancienne très bien aménagée, une très belle présentation d'oeuvres d'art d'artistes Béninois. Visite passionnante, grâce au talent de la guide, très compétente et intéressante.

title: Exceptionnel
text:
Le lieu est unique et superbe, vrai joyaux patrimonial.
Les artistes présentés sont passionnants, les guides sont accueillants, souriants, je vous recommande vraiment ce musée. Et n'hésitez pas à prendre un café après la visite (on y sert du nespresso!), l'endroit est magique et les articles de la boutique changent de l'habituel centre artisanal où l'on voit toujours les mêmes choses. A ne pas rater !!

title: Nice exhibit in a beautiful setting
text: Came here recently with my wife to see the La Fabrique à Fantasmes exhibit. What a most pleasant experience: the exhibit was very well curated, with a nice mixture of works as far as artists represented, their country of origin, and media used; the setting—a beautifully restored house from the early 1900s—was equally inspiring; the staff was very helpful and friendly; and lastly, the café (reviewed elsewhere) was super charming and cozy. A morning well spent indeed!

title: Mediocre
text: Tres peu d artistes sont proposes, et pas mes gouts du tout. Tres figuratif! L ensemble a ete visite avec un guide que l on comprenait tres mal

title: Lovely house, nice art
text: We had a great tour of the museum mainly due to the fact that my wife is fluent in French and translated as the guide took us around. They've done well with the space. Definitely worth a visit if you're in town.

title: A ne pas rater !
text:
Si vous passez à Ouidah, ne manquez pas la fondation Zinsou afin de découvrir quelques échantillons de l'art contemporain africain. Cela a été pour nous une vraie découverte. Avec une salle par artiste de différents pays et les explications très éclairantes de notre guide, nous avons pu comprendre et mieux apprécier les œuvres. Chaque artiste a un style bien à lui, utilisant souvent des matériaux de récupération. La visite est complémentaire de celle faite à Cotonou où la fondation a aussi un lieu d'exposition, consacré à un seul artiste.
L'entrée et la visite est gratuite. On peut terminer par un petit tour au café meublé de façon contemporaine mais avec de magnifiques tissus africains traditionnels.

title: Quality locally produced merchandise
text: Very worthy shop staffed by friendly and knowledgeable ladies. Wanted to shop here knowing all the products and products is produced locally on Cape Verde and not the tourist tat supposedly from Senegal but in reality China. Purchased lots of different items as gifts for back home in the UK with the only limitation being the 20kg luggage allowance on TUI. I'd thoroughly recommend shopping here knowing the stuff is produced by Cape Verde locals and all profits help the locals in other positive ways.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Fair trade, support locally made goods
text: Such a lovely little shop, beautiful crafts and great people. We need to support things created on the island and not shipped half way across the world

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: The best souvenirs and local products from Cabo Verde in SAL
text:
Very happy about this local initiative discovery only a few moments before leaving SAL! 
The lady was very instructive, patient, n taught me a lot about cabo verde’s history. 
And you only wanna buy the whole shop! As it looks very Sharp with great products 💚
Thank you !

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Echte Unikate von den Kapverden
text: Wir haben unsere Souvenirs von Sal in diesem Shop gekauft. Hier gibt es tolle Produkte aus der Region, keine Massenware.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Great fair trade produce
text: A lovely shop selling fair trade produce aimed at helping women. Lovely food, drink and produce served by lovely staff. A pleasure to shop here.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: O sítio certo para fazer compras
text: Sem dúvida a melhor escolha para comprar lembranças. Preços justos para artesãos e para quem compra. Ao contrário das restantes lojas, que têm todas a mesma oferta e misturam peças locais com outras feitas em série na China e objectos de outros países africanos, esta loja tem uma grande variedade de produtos caboverdianos - do artesanato aos doces, licores, sais de banho e muito mais. Tem também os preços bem identificados em escudos caboverdianos e euros, o que não acontece nas restantes lojas (onde o preço varia a cada dia e consoante o comprador). O atendimento é excelente e não há confusões com os trocos entre escudos e euros, em que o comprador fica sempre a perder. Comércio justo e sério para quem compra e quem vende e ainda se contribui para uma boa causa. Aconselho vivamente.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

text: Best souvenir shop in Santa Maria. There is z variety of nice local items and the shopkeeper is very friendly. I would absolutely recommend going there!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Produits locaux Cap Vert
text: Produits locaux de qualité je recommande. Une bonne sélection haute en couleurs. Rhum (gorge) vieux à découvrir. Personnel du magasin d’une grande gentillesse.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Lovely fair trade shop
text: Great fair trade and local art. Lovely shop with lots of interesting souvenirs produced locally.also, it sells local coffee beans and a nice variety of liquers. We did most of our souvenir shopping here. Fairly priced,good service. Would recommend

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Boutique de souvenirs commerce équitable
text:
Accueil très sympathique.
Produits locaux artisanaux à prix très raisonnables. Si vous souhaitez acheter des souvenirs à Santa Maria, commencez par là : c'est très diversifié et vous êtes sûr d'acheter des produits faits par des locaux (commerce équitable).

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Great fair trade souvenirs!
text: Lots of souvenirs from (women owned) local businesses! Aloe vera products, drinks, fashion, beauty products, soaps, ...

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Progetto molto bello
text: Sostenere l’artigianato locale è possibile! Tutto fatto a mano e con passione! Da sale, cioccolato e marmellate a borse, accessori e altro!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Vrais souvenirs CV
text:
Les vrais souvenirs made in cabo verde! En plus vous faites une bonne action pour les locaux.
Il y en a pour tous les goûts !

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Cute little fair trade shop in the center of Santa Maria
text: Cute little shop with good quality products, friendly staff and locally produced, clearly fair trade products. Good chance to buy truly locally made memories to yourself and loved ones. Definytely worth a visit!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Lovely piace with lots of locale handmade souvenirs
text:
Piccolo negozio con molti souvenir colorati fatti a mano.
Consigliatissimo per portare a casa ricordi dell'isola del sal

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Toppers
text: Wat een gevoel voor service. Je komt binnen en de mensen glimlachen direct. Kortom topservice. Hier houden wij van en worden wij heel blij van. Cabo Verde No Stress!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: A recommander
text: Produits de qualité. Bon accueil. Originalité. La diversité des produits est appréciable entre porte clé, manique, produits de beauté et capillaires

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Eerlijke producten
text: Pak koffiebonen gekocht. Dan krijg je het idee dat het ook daadwerkelijk uit Cabo Verde komt. Vriendelijk personeel en ik kon met euro’s betalen

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Lovely little shop
text: If you're in Santa Maria, Sal, don't miss this lovely little shop for handmade souvenirs! The craftsmanship is beautiful, and the staff are incredibly friendly and helpful. I picked up a few chocolates and coconut liqueur for my family, and they absolutely loved it. The quality of the products is excellent, and the warm, welcoming atmosphere makes the shopping experience even better. A perfect spot to find meaningful gifts!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Variedade e tradição cabo verdiana
text:
Uma loja que oferece artesanato cabo verdiano, no meio da cidade repleta de lojas com artesanato senegalês, todo igual.
Muita variedade e o facto de ser fair trade, levamos pelas bonitas e et uma ajuda aos artesãos.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: TOUCHANT
text:
Petit musée simple et touchant.  Un incontournable de Mindelo,  ne pas manquer.3 euros l entrée. 
Quelques effets personnels de la diva aux pieds nus,  robes , documents personnels, photos et autres .  Appareils audio murales pour écouter la musique de Cesaria sur place. Sa  vie est retracée sur de grands panneaux. 
Bonne visite !

title: Desapontamento - Cise, merecias bem mais!
text: A simplicidade da Diva dos pés descalços merecia bem mais do seu amado São'sente. Saí daquela casinha a que chamaram Núcleo Museológico Cesária Évora com um sentimento de tristeza e injustiça. Senti um certo abandono à "grandeza" que ela foi para o mundo, para o seu povo, no papel que teve na projeção mundial da cultura Cabo-verdiana, a doce Cize.

title: Honteux.
text: Aucun respect des horaires d'ouverture pour un musée trop petit, ne mettant pas assez en valeur le talent de cette grande artiste : il en résulte un goût de tristesse et de gâchis.

title: Il semblerait que ce beau bâtiment soit en travaux
text: Malheureusement ce magnifique bâtiment, ancien palais du gouvernement est encore fermé.nous sommes restés 10 jours et n’avons pu y entrer

title: Nucléo Museologico Cesaria Evora
text: Fermé et encore fermé. Que passa ? On a fini par trouver un minuscule musée pas loin de là. Aussi modeste que la vie de Cize comme ils l’appellent là bas. Mais beaucoup de vidéo très intéressantes et instructives. Entrée 3€. Rua Guerra Mendes

title: Passionnant et sans prétention.
text: Si l’extérieur ne paye pas de mine et ne paraît pas engageant, on est vite pris par l’histoire de ce personnage qui a vécu dans cette maison. L’émotion n’en est que plus belle!

title: A small overview of the city's history
text: A very modest display, but it's still worth stopping to familiarize yourself with what's on display. Fresh works by local artists are also presented here.  A very modest display, but it's still worth stopping to familiarize yourself with what's on display. Fresh works by local artists are also presented here. No fee!

title: a not miss in Cabo verde
text: this is the famous Cesaria Evora museum , the house where the greatest singer lived while alive. We were even able to talk to her living brother.

title: Sehr schönes Museum, viele Exponate
text: Wer die Musik von Cesaria Evora kennt und mag, sollte unbedigt das Museum besuchen! Man sieht viele Utensielen aus ihrem Leben aber auch original Fotos und Kleider die sie bei Konzerten trug!

title: Nice insight into Cesaria's life
text: Interesting details of Cesaria's life. Record covers, dresses she wore at concerts, many pictures on tour of with friends and family...

title: Pamiątki po Cesarii Evora
text: Warto zobaczyć pamiątki zebrane przez fana Cesarii. Niestety rodzina Cesarii nie zdołała stworzyć musem. W muzeum polski akcent- zdjęcie Cesarii z Kayą - ze wspólnego koncertu.

title: Authentiquement vôtre
text: Petit musée au cœur de la ville dédié à la star de Mindelo et du Cap Vert. Une collection assez éclectique dont la présentation ne manque pas d'un charme que je qualifierais de joyeusement désuet. Rien d'époustoufflant mais cette visite reste néanmoins un des instants des plus touchants de mon séjour au Cap Vert.

title: Prachtige Afrikaanse kunst
text: Het deel over Cesaria Evora was het voor ons niet echt waard te bezoeken. Maar de Afrikaanse kunst die tentoongesteld stond was prachtig, zeker een bezoek waard.

title: Magnifique
text:
2 collections, Cesaria Evora d’un côté - à être la.... - et l’art africain de l’autre avec un premier étage à ne pas manquer. Des objets magnifiques.
Il faut y faire un tour.

title: Voor Afrikaanse kunst een must-see!
text: Als je van Afrikaanse kunst houdt, moet je hier echt naar binnen! Het is klein, maar zeer de moeite waard. Prachtige maskers in alle soorten en maten en een aantal sculpturen. De andere kant van het museum is ingericht met alles over locale heldin zangeres Cesária Évora. Niet echt bijzonder, maar je krijgt wel een gevoel van haar indrukwekkende oeuvre. Mensen vinden 7 euro entree misschien wat duur in verhouding, maar je houd daarmee wel het prachtige gebouw en cultuur mee in stand.

title: The African Art Rooms upstairs were stunning.
text: There was an art exhibition downstairs to the left and the Cesaria Evora Tribute to the right. We had to pay 8 euros each to see all exhibits which for us was well worth it having got access to the many rooms abovej which contained the most amazing wealth of african art in all its intricate carving.there was witch doctors masks both fearsome yet often comical expressions Musical instruments inlaid with colourful mosaics .Strange but beautiful statues and artifacts.A throne that was symbolic with elephant tusks six foot high ...which I was assurred were made of wood.Somewhere in the depths of my mind the ensemble of the throne and tusks I felt I had seen them before Shaka Khan King of the Zulus...maybe the film crew borrowed it .It was all set in sunlight and airy rooms painted white walls of an old portuguese palace. Nothing like our dull and sunless victorian Museums.But maybe thats changed since I was a child. I thoroughly recommend you see this exhibit  it was glorious.

title: Small but fascinating and moving memorial to Cesaria Evora
text: I visited this museum to pay homage to Cape Verde's most famous person.  It is situated in an ordinary house in a side street (not her original house I don't think) and contains personal items such as her dresses, hair curlers, favourite coffee mug and ashtray as well as awards and decorations from her singing career.  The story of her life is told in Portuguese, English and (I think) French.  There is a very moving film of her funeral procession when all the local musicians accompanied her coffin to the cemetery playing 'Sodade'.  Also you can listen to a wide selection of her songs on audio.  The museum is excellent value and should be better known.  Perhaps they could have more of her CDs on sale, though I did buy one.

title: Découverte incontournable
text: D’abord il y a le palais rose qui domine, et témoigne du passé colonial. À l’intérieur, 3 expositions différentes de l’art local contemporain lumineux, une collection d’objets d’art africain remarquable, l’évocation touchante de la vie de Cesaria Evora.

title: Le Palais Rose
text: Très belle demeure, les expositions proposées étaient des peintures de 3 talentueux artistes cap verdiens ainsi que la vie musicale de Cesaria Evora a l'étage se trouvent des sculptures africaines (colons) d’ailleurs j’en ai acheter un en souvenir. Très belle exposition il faut y aller

title: Emotional moments!
text: I was very excited when I visited the museum by seeing the photos, dresses that Cesaria Evora wore at her concerts. The personel was very helpful by giving information and answering to some of my questions. There was another exhibition with African objects. I felt very grateful and lucky that I had the chance to visit Mindelo and the museum!

title: Le parcours des esclaves: un devoir de mémoire
text:
La fondation Zinsou, abrîte le premier musée d’art contemporain africain. Le musée Zinsou de Ouidah est d’abord la rénovation d’une œuvre architecturale unique.

Ouidah qui se veut « villes de tous les patrimoines » avec son histoire dense honore les artistes contemporains africains. Cyprien Tokoudagba, Samuel Fosso, Romuald Hazoumé, SolyCissé, le musée d’arts africains de Ouidah vous donne rendez-vous pour une autre facette de l’Afrique. Une facette qui jusque-là ne pouvait être visitée qu’à Paris, New-York, et autres grandes villes occidentales.

Très belle initiative ce musée dont j'ai beaucoup apprécié la visite.

title: endroit au milieu de nul part
text: la porte du non retour fut errigé par rapport à l'esclavagisme de l'epoque. Les portuguais faisait monter en particulier les.youroubas dans des bateaux à cet endroit la. certains se jetaient à l'eau pour ne pas quitter leur terre. le chemin commence à ouida.

title: Nice place
text:
The Ouidah Museum of History contains a small, but very interesting. exhibition of objects related with the history of slavery and the religious and cultural relations between Benin and Brazil, thanks to the trafiic of slaves, brought from Benin in the XVII, XVIII and XIX centuries. 
The local tour guides are very good, well educated and available to answer all questions. 
The Musuem islocated inside na old portuguese fort of the early XVIII century, what is a plus.

title: Histoire du pays
text: Passage obligé pour connaitre un peu l'histoire de l'esclavage par les Portugais et les Français au Bénin. Endroit imprégné d'un passé douloureux qu'on peut encore ressentir.

title: poor but full of history
text: I was reluctant to hire a guide but, that is the best choice. I high recommend NOT to hire the opportunist people that always will surround to you there but hire one at Municipality Turist Office, particularly to Mr. CARLOMAGNO, the most well english speaker guy there. He is the guy who build some of the monuments along the way to reach the slaves-gate (on the pic). (he's kindly, selfless, and he will take care well of your necesities, avoiding thieves). On the  gate there are not too much to see, the beach is nice even looks abandoned. This slaves-rute and a free musem (zinsao... -I'm not sure about the name) is the best (and unique) realy nice thing to know in all the country. Price approx. 20 USD.

title: =D
text:
O Museu conta a história de reis antigos, a passagem dos portugueses e outros povos pelo Benin.

Em muitos aspectos consegui ver familiaridades entre as culturas do Brasil e do Bénin. Vale a pena!

title: Intereesting if sad.
text: Got take on a tour by an amusing local and he jovially explained there was no money in the  treasure box.  Get a book called the Viceroy of Ouidah to find out more about the place and the Da Silvas. Yayi Bonis wife is a DaSilva.

title: Musée décevant
text: Le musée pourrait être bien, si on pouvait le visiter librement, sans la houlette obligatoire d'un guide. On aimerait flâner, lire les légendes, imaginer ou retrouver ce qu'on aura lu, ou ce qu'on lira ensuite.

title: Exposição interessante
text: Gostamos muito desse museu, apesar dele ter o mesmo inconveniente que muitos dos outros que visitamos na Africa: quase nenhuma explicação escrita, por isso a qualidade da visita depende do guia. Dois pontos altos: exposição sobre o paralelo entre a cultura brasileira e a africana; uma exposição sobre as mascaras usadas para certas danças por uma sociedade secreta.

title: Museo molto carino
text: È la storia e le verità di questo Paese. Se siete in Benin e passate di la, andate a vederlo. Vi sono rappresentazioni e quadri molto carini e pieni si significato e valore umano.

title: Interesting photography
text: The museum is very interesting, our guide was too. There is also an exhibition about the parallel between the voodoo culture in Benin and Brazil, with beautiful photographs.

title: Douloureuse route des esclaves
text: Le Musée est un fort portugais qui retrace l'histoire de l'esclavage. Et la présence coloniale des portugais et des français. Possibilité moyennant finance de faire la route des esclaves avec le guide jusqu'à la porte de non retour.

title: Het verleden zichtbaar
text:
Ongeveer 30 minuten met de auto vanaf Cotonou ligt het stadje Quidah, het stadje is nauwelijks bekend in de buitenwereld maar toch bevinden zich hier enkele bijzondere locaties en gebeurtenissen vanuit het verleden.
Volgens de overleving bevindt de oorsprong van VOODOO zich in deze omgeving en is er een VOODOO Museum vlak buiten het stadje, waar men je meer kan vertellen over de rituelen en gebruiken van VOODOO. Advies: neem een vertrouwde chauffeur mee bv vanuit je hotel en fotografeer mensen pas na dat je toestemming hebt gekregen.
In de stad Quidah bevind zich het Portugese Fort waar in het verleden de slaven werden verzameld en door de Portugezen naar o.a. Brazilië werden verscheept, het Fort is nog geheel intact en is nu als museum en dagelijks te bezoeken.   
Na het bezoek aan het museum kan je via de marktplaats naar de kust rijden, ca. 5 km., over dit pad moesten de slaven lopen naar de schepen die voor de kust lagen. Op dit pad staan nog de beelden waarlangs ze moesten lopen om afscheid te nemen van hun land. Ook bevindt zich halverwege dit pad een dorpje waar VOODOO priesters hun rituelen uitvoeren. Fotografeer niet zonder toestemming!
Aangekomen bij de kust staat er nu een monument op de plaats waar de slaven Afrika hebben verlaten, al met al een zeer indrukwekkende locatie.
Langs de kust kan je dan weer terug naar Cotonou.

title: Intéressant mais attention aux propositions des pseudo guides
text: L'endroit est intéressant à visiter mais ne donner aucune suite aux propositions que font certains des guides du musée pour vous accompagner à la fête vaudou par exemple ou pour vous expliquer la route des esclaves... ils ne cherchent qu'à vous arnaquer et à vous soutirez de l'argent.

title: Some interest, but not much presentation
text: There were some interesting pieces on display here, showing the history of the city and the fort, but everything felt run-down and ignored.  Most of the information concerned the Portuguese control of the city and their missionaries; I got very little information on the indigenous people or how they lived.  I just feel like so much more could be done with this place.

title: O.K. aber besser gleich zum Office de Tourisme
text: Das kleine Museum ist durchaus sehenswert. Viel sinnvoller aber ist, sich zum Office de Tourisme zu begeben, um dort gestaffelt nach Länge sich von einem ortskundigen Führer das zeigen zu lassen, was in der Geschichte dieses Jahrhunderte alten Städchen an Orten, Strassenbzügen, Märkten lles noch zu sehen ist. Diese Führung ist wirklich erstklassig unde rspärt langes überflüssiges Lesen in halbgaren Reuseführern.

title: Interessant und gut gemacht
text: Das Museum ist sehr authentisch und übersichtlich. Die Tour dauert ca. 20min. Sehenswert ist die Fotoausstellung.

title: On est mal à l'aise, mais cela fait partie de l'histoire...
text:
On ne peut pas se rendre au Bénin, sans faire une halte à Ouidah et visiter cet ancien fort portugais si chargé de souvenirs terribles...
On s'imprègne de l'histoire de presque un million d'esclaves, de leurs conditions de détention avant leur grand départ pour l'Atlantique ( pour ceux qui arrivaient à survivre...) 
L'ambiance est chargée, pesante, On imagine les souffrances endurées, on en voit les traces, on comprend la bêtise humaine.
Commencez par visiter le fort avec ses casernes, sa chapelle, ses objets conservés dans la résidence.
Puis suivez le chemin de 4 km jusqu'à la plage d'où partaient les bateaux, en passant par la place aux enchères, l'arbre de l'oubli et la porte du non retour.
Imprégnez vous de cette ambiance terrible et, une fois parvenu sur la plage, soufflez un peu. Vous en aurez besoin.
L'endroit est vraiment magnifique.

title: African Market
text:
We go as often as our budget allows. The Lekki Market is a must if you want to buy gifts or any other household items, fresh food, furniture, art, jewellery, etc, etc.
Wear flip-flops or gumboots and leave flashy jewellery and expensive items at home....then be prepared to negotiate!!!

title: Good Exploration and Bargain Place
text: Market provides lots of local/nearby African countries art works. Ranging from semi precious stones, wood carvings, brass antiques, paintings, ornaments, leather goods,  elephant tusk etc etc. However one need to be cautious about the ingenuity of products as well local rules for animal goods trade. Bargain depends upon individual ranging from 1/2 to 1/4 of original price.

title: Unique shopping experience
text: The market is not easy to find because it's located at the back of main parking area but once you find it, it presents a variety of art pieces. To get value for money, you have to be very good at bargaining! We got some nice jewellery at fair prices. Because of the weak Naira, if you change your dollars you can get really nice art pieces and souvenirs.

title: Once a Treasure Trove
text:
Lekki market I believe also know as lekki craft market was a place I enjoyed and looked forward to visiting. It had various merchants with an array of items, from paintings, carvings, jewellery, books etc. I was fortunate to have acquired some beautiful pieces in the past. That was about 5 years ago.
I visited the market last month and was a bit disappointed. It seemed to have been improved but not sure it adds credit to it. You have somewhat more solid concrete stalls, but no order to the arrangements of the stalls. Also it seems more of a general market than for arts and crafts. It is quite difficult to navigate. 
Access road and parking is an issue as road is bad and parking inadequate. 
Overall still worth the visit and you might be lucky to find odd interesting pieces.

title: Local craft and textile market..a tourist hotspot in a very unaccesible place
text: This is a definite must- visit market for tourists to pick up arts, crafts, local fabrics already sewn, beautiful bags made with local fabrics etc etc. I am a local but I visit often to buy pearls and ready made ankara loose kaftans. I went there for some nice loose ankara blouses over Christmas which I wear on leggings... The market is quiet but the road is very bad and untarred!!! In the rainy season, it is terrible and not motor able!! Be prepared to pay a levy of 200 NAIRA for packing!!! Enjoy your visit if you can get there

title: Lots to see at the market!
text: A very busy, easy to get lost in, market. Most important tidbit is to not show up until about 11-1130 am. Various shops will all kinds of local crafts. My personal favorite was the hand woven baskets. Many of them come from Ghana, and you can bargain a bit on the price. As always in these kind of markets, keep your pocketbook close to you and stay alert. Never had a problem, but you never can tell. I visited this market a few times with friends while I lived in Lagos 2013 to 2015.

title: Crazy, Fun Place
text: I went on a Sunday and only a fraction of the shops were open.  But it was even better.  Great crafts, art and jewelry.  Be prepared to bargain and push the vendors away.  It's a must see while in Lagos.

title: Difficult to Navigate
text:
Many sellers all willing to do a quick trade, it can be a bit overwhelming when so many are trying to see to you.  It is useful to have someone who knows the area and can fend off the crowds.

Be careful off the prices, there is a lot of flexibility, paying too early will cause you to pay too much.

title: Difficult to find
text: This is well worth a visit but it is very difficult to find as Lekki is the name of the area so there are a couple of markets but you'll know when you're going there because the road is difficult to negotiate in a car or motorbike. You walk through a food market first and then in a compound is where the real market is selling all local hand made items such as wood carvings, jewellery, cloths, paintings, artwork and many other items. You will have to haggle of course but i paid 6500n for a wood carving that was 15000n at the hotel. Bargain.

title: Crowded, Everything Under the Sun
text: The Lekki market is a fun place to visit & shop around. Be prepared for some vendors that pitch aggressive attempts to get you to buy their wares. If you see something you really like, ask the price, then shake your head a walk away. The vendors will immediately cut their offer 25-50%, then you can start bargaining. Many stalls claim to be selling "African Ivory" but it's really some other wood darkened with shoe polish.

title: Hard to find but worth it
text: this is really called jakande market and it is tucked down a back street, went on a sunday when not all stalls open, and just as well as huge, with loads of stalls selling every sort of souvenir you could ever want, prices half of that charged at Silverbird culture village in Abuja and good quality. friendly non-pushy stall owners make it nice to visit.

title: Loved it!
text: So much amazing art. I went in search of some leather and got carried away by all the art, jewelry, color, and textures. You would find pretty much anything here but prepare to drive a hard bargain so you get a fair deal.

title: Arts, crafts, furniture, souvenirs, antiques....nice!
text:
If you haven't been before take a guide. Even for me as a local there's plenty going on and lots to see. You can order hand carved furniture, get a dress blinged with beads an buy ingredients for your dinner all in minutes.

It you need a relatively decent market setting at which to purchase you African souvenirs, this would be the place, so long as you're coming from Ikoyi or Victoria Island. I would think it would be quite out of the way for anyone coming from other locations. Its a must see place though. Parking is typical Lagos, always a crush when you find a space. What amazed me was finding fabric with designs from way back when I was a young 'un. :)

Expats come to frequent this market to find those 'one-off' pieces for their homes.

Nice place to visit

title: muy bueno
text: Si quieres llevar de recuerdo algo africano, éste es el lugar. El lugar es ideal para conocer la cultura de un país. No puede faltar en tu lista de sitios por visitar.

title: Art Market
text: If you're looking for a market that has African fabric, locally made African print clothing, jewellery and art work, look no further. This market has it all. The market can be a little overwhelming and confusing with the amount things happening at the same time. Be patient and take your time.

title: Hard to Rate
text: Lekki market is a place to find all sorts of items from staple foods to artisan crafts. Some merchants are a bit pushy. If you find something that you like, ask the price, shake your head and walk away. The original offer will drop, then start negotiations. You'll find the least expensive souvenirs here with the most variety.

title: Lekki Market
text: If your looking for where to buy anything or trading of all kinds like beads,native wears, art and crafts and many more think of Lekki Market

title: Lagos Market for Art
text:
Love paintings, tradition beads, native attire, art and crafts of ivory, wood, etc then this is where to be.
This is where I bring my foreign friends to shop for something African they would love to take back with them. Look no further for such souvenirs.
There's something for everyone in terms of price. You could also have some customization done. Please only go with money you want to spend as you're likely to spend every cash as there's always something extra you would like to have.
The roads that lead to the market can be tricky in the raining season but once you arrive at the market you're fine.
Also make sure there is always an attend on ground and close by when you enter any shop or inspect any wares. There was one nasty but the other time with a foreigner (I won't mention country) and a trader who claimed some of his stones were missing. Same shop I was buying something from so I tried to intervene, thought I could settle the cost but alas one stone cost half of all the money I brought to the market. Very likely an isolated event but something to learn from.
So if you're in Lagos and want to purchase art or native memorabilia, etc, you know where to be.

title: Great place for fun, art, souvenirs, etc.
text:
There are two Kekki markets right next to each other, one is more general and one is more arts and crafts. The market is a bit overwhelming at first and through it looks a little rough, I never felt unsafe. Had loads of fun looking around. I'm told the market does start closing up by 6 or so on week days (and the traffic is crazy by then anyway) so either go during the day or on the weekends. 

LOCATION NOTE: When I visited the TripAdvisor site (October 1, 2016) it displayed  a correct description of the market location but their map (and therefore navigation in the app if you use it) was completely wrong. Make sure to check Google maps for the correct location. 

Have fun

title: Cultural goods
text: I enjoyed the market and the traders were keen to sell but friendly and not intrusive or rude. My group purchased local crafts like painting, engraved cattle horn, bead jewellery, animal bookends and a traditional knife. Very colourful and enjoyable walking through the narrow stalls.

title: Форт Эльмина
text: Мне очень понравился этот форт, больше чем аналогичный в кейп кост. Был построен еще в 1482 году и служил впоследствии в качестве перевалочной базы для отправки рабов в Америку.

title: Should visit
text:
The Elmina Slave Fort is a castle built by the Portuguese as a Slave holding area before they were shipped to the Americas. Though it reminds one of the horrors humans inflict on humans, it should be visited to ensure such horrors are not repeated. The British won this from the Dutch who had kicked the Portuguese out but all three empires used this outpost for their slave trading activities, till the British Privy Council abolished slavery in England and the British Empire.

It is a three and a half hour drive on a Sunday and a little longer on other days of the week.
One should combine it with a visit to the Cape Coast slave fort which is on the same road, half an hour

title: Elmina castle
text: I’m studying in Cape Coast and visited Elmina Castle. Very informative guide with a lot of knowledge. A really great place to visit to learn about colonialism and slave trade in Ghana and Africa

title: Harrowing experience
text:
Unbelievable suffering for the slaves whom were captured and brutalised here.   Squeezed  in a cell with many others and be faced with  human mental, emotional and physical torture. Never having privacy to conduct normal human daily function and then having to sleep amongst or on it was soul destroying .
One word......Harrowing!!

title: Life changing
text: All I can say is that this was a life changing visit. It was painful to see what the diaspora of West Africans suffered. It stands as a reminder for humanity to be better in the present and future. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!

title: Terribly impressive and moving.
text: An exhaustive guided tour through the excruciatingly painful history of the castle : the appalling slaves' confinement rooms leading to the "door of no return".

title: Visit to Elmina with Worlanyo Tours
text: It was an amazing experience, seeing all that with have read and heard about slave trade in Ghana in person, with these castles posing us evidence to that. Our visit to the castle was combined with a visit to the fishing community to meet with the Chief fisherman and his entourage, Fort Jago and the old Dutch colonial cemetery. In all, the experience was tremendous and thank Worlanyo Tours for putting all together.

title: Amazing
text:
Our visit to Elmina castle was a great but sombre experience. Our tour guide Ato was exceptional and extremely knowledgable. I learned so much. I plan on visiting again the next time I’m in Ghana. You simply can’t miss out in this opportunity.
To actually stand in a part of my history was such a special moment. To see the conditions they endured, to stand in the exact place where people died, were chained, the door of no return...I simply can’t forget.
Do yourself a favour and visit.

title: Sorrowful Memories That Never Disappears.
text:
Elmina Castle which is also known as St. George Castle is recognized by UNSESCO as a World Heritage Site. Elmina Castle, erected by the Portuguese in 1482, was the first trading post built on the Gulf of Guinea, and the castle is the oldest European building in existence in the Sahara. Pay a visit to the Castle as well as the fishing harbour and market. If you like, walk up the hill to visit 	Fort St Jago, offering wonderful panoramic views over the town.
As a tour guide working in Ghana, if you ask me, i will say, yes, Elmina Castle is the oldest castle having rich history on the slave trade but to have a real experience regarding the slave trade, you need to be at the Cape Coast Castle where the castle itself tells the story of what actually happened there regarding the slave trade,
a. The palaver hall where the slaves were sold and branded is bigger.
b. The male dungeon which connect through a tunnel to the female dungeon and leading to the sea where boats wait to take the slaves to a land unknown to them against their will. The dungeon at the Cape Coast castle held hundreds or thousands at a time.
c. The door of no return which is now known as a door of return is well structured for the human cargo to pass swiftly without much efforts into the waiting ships which carries the slaves away forever.

title: A story worth knowing
text:
Compared to the cape coast castle, I honestly really liked the elmina castle more.

A lot more to see, a better picture of the past was painted verbally with physical evidence

Hard to photograph as everything is huge and close.

Entry fee 5gh (locals) 40gh (foreign) comes with a tour guide. Tours are mostly conducted in groups

An emotional tour for some but definitely thought provoking and conversation starter for all.

Guides welcome questions and try their best to answer

Regards
The free tour guide
@chefinskinnyjeans
Instagram

title: Beautiful castle, with deep signifigance
text:
Elmina is the largest slave castle in the world. We had a wonderful tour guide that explained things so perfectly to our kids. We learned that once the slaves set foot in the castle, they could spend up to three months in horrific conditions. And that “The door of no return” was a portal through which the slaves were lowered into small boats and then loaded onto bigger ships further out to sea, never to set foot in their homeland again and with a final goodbye to the freedom they once knew.  Our kids are young, but were able to follow the guides teachings.
Only down side was the hawkers in the parking lot.  Very pushy, but not a reason not to go.  Just be prepared to say no if you are not interested.

title: Must see when in Ghana
text:
Elmina Castle is a must see when in Ghana to better understand the history of the county and horrors that happend here.

Our tour guide was really good. Telling the facts as they are, but not blaming anybody. I am Dutch and my people played a major roll in Elminas history. I did not felt blamed, but humbled to walk together with a Ghanaian friend in Elmina. A very intense place. A place we need to preserve and protect. Something they are doing very well!

title: Great attraction aside from the beggars
text:
This really is a must see attraction and a World Heritage site. Our guide was fantastic, tailoring our tour to suit the ages of the children in our group, aged 9 to 15.  It is a most excellent insight into the history of the castle, and what those poor people went through. 

I wish that some investment came with being a World Heritage site. It is a great place as it is, but you can see how it might be improved with just a little more funding. 

The only downside was the hassle we received from the people outside the castle. I’ve been traveling to Ghana regularly for 20 years and this was definitely the worst I’ve experienced. 

They seemed friendly at first, asking for our names. But there was a catch - they’d put our names onto shells (without asking) when we came out of the castle and asked for payment for having done this. When this wasn’t successful they wanted us to put our names and contact information on a piece of paper - which we didn’t do. They said it was to sponsor their football team which, of course, is fictional. They were overly persistent, even when told that we already support a football team and school in Ghana.  When this didn’t work they resorted to just asking for money. 

Anyway, don’t be put off from visiting. Just be aware that these people hang around and that these are their tricks!

title: Interessante geschiedenis
text: Het kasteel zelf is heel indrukwekkend en zeker de moeite om te bezoeken. De geschiedenis erachter is erg interessant. De gids had er geen zin in en hield alles heel kort, mompelde meestal onverstaanbaar en reageerde kwaad als we een vraag stelden.

title: Historia de esclavitud
text: Fuerte de tiempos coloniales, donde se controlaba la costa y donde se negociaba con los esclavos. Merece la pena la visita

title: A harrowing insight into the shame of the past.
text:
This cannot be described as an enjoyable day out by any means, it is a stark and harrowing place to be, and shows just what barbarians the human race can produce. 

The guide we had was very knowledgable, and posed searching questions as well as explaining the history of the whole disgraceful time of slavery. His words around the last govenor of the prison, and the poem written about him as a "god fearing, honorable man" were resonant - simply to say that in a time of slavery, how this man was god fearing and honourable was, perhaps, something that only he could explain.

There are alot of people who could do with a visit here when they spout off about immigration, and their far right political views - this is exactly the sort of thing that could possibly put right some of the wrongs that still plague proportions of the western population.

It was a deeply moving experience, and while it isn't nice, if you're here you need to see it - in the same way as you need to see the holocaust experience. As uncomfortable as it is for a western white person, we need to cement in our minds that these appalling things must never happen again, and that the modern equivalents of the people who did this, and are trying to promote inequality (read Nigel Farage etc.) must be prevented from having a platform to try and return to this type of inhumane treatment and abuse.

It's a piece of history that everybody should understand and regret.

title: Beauty and horror
text: The castle is huge and you go on a guided tour. There are occasional stops at small shops within the castle. You see the beautiful scenery of the ocean views and you duck under the small doorways that people sold into slavery were trapped in. It's an important place to visit. Bring toilet paper and a camera. You will stay at least an hour.

title: Elmina Castle - a haunting but unforgettable experience
text:
Elmina Castle in Ghana's Cape Coast region was built as a fort by the Portuguese in 1482, and is the oldest building in sub-Saharan Africa.

Now a World Heritage Site, the Portuguese and then Dutch imprisoned hundreds of thousands of slaves before they were shipped to the Americas. It's a haunting, sad place, and a reminder how cruel humans can be to one another. Slaves were imprisoned in the harshest conditions, and many died here. Slaves that attempted to rebellion were thrown in a dungeon that was only opened when the last had died.

Ironically, there's a church in the centre of the castle.

In the room where hundreds of women were kept, there is still an acrid smell, hundreds of years after the last slaves were here. 

You can hire a driver for $100 to $150 for the day in Accra, to take you to Elmina and the nearby Kakum National Park, where there's an amazing canopy tour. You'll pay about 40 Ghanaian Cedis for a 1-1.5 hour tour of the castle. 

Wear comfortable walking shoes.

title: Wow. Do not miss this!
text: This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a must-see for your visit to Ghana. 550 year old castle that for several hundred years held 1,000 slaves at a time chained in dungeons before they were loaded onto ships bound for North America and the Caribbean. The guided tour is excellent. Nice gift shop.

title: Moving Experience
text: Elmina castle was one of the largest castles used to camp slaves during the Trans-Atlantic slave trade era. Our tour guide took us to some of the dungeons where the slaves were kept and to the tiny exit each slave went through to the ships when they arrived. A visit here will help you to appreciate the suffering humanity endured during that era and hope that it never occurs again.

title: Interesting
text: The place itself does not really look like a palace, but with a good guide you do get the story and the right impression. We like especially the strange clay figurines on the walls and the stories behind them,

title: Amazing history
text: We really enjoyed our visit here. I would recommend getting an English speaking guide. This is very well preserved on African standards and some fascinating history comes from here. Would definitely recommend!

title: interessante
text:
Sito Unesco da oltre 30 anni e forse per questo è riuscito a conservarsi in buono stato. Anche se al posto dei tetti in lamiera potrebbero essere ripristinate le coperture tradizionali.
Interessanti le descrizioni della guida, che spiega nel dettaglio tradizioni e riti.

title: Interestinf
text: Informative and interesting. Recommend to those wanting to know more than just a beach . It’s about learning that Benin is an amazing place of history

title: Interessante
text: Visita interessante peccato sia vietato fare le foto! Consiglio la visita, perchè le storie raccontate dalla guida sono impensabili

title: Interesting history
text: I was the only person visiting when I came and I found this trip interesting. They had an English speaking guide who led me around the large complex and explained everything. The buildings have lots of bas reliefs and there are some artefacts inside including many ancient thrones and decorative staffs and some gifts from Europeans during the slave trade. Not a huge amount of things but enough to keep interested and imaging how it would have been in its glory. The history was interesting. Took around an hour all in and the tour is mandatory, you can’t visit alone. Photos weren’t allowed inside the complex at all which was a pity, even the outside of building with the bas reliefs.

title: L'histoire des rois
text:
Le musée ouvre à 9H et sa visite est conditionnée par la présence d'un guide officiel sur place ; sauf qu'elle est arrivée à près de 9H30. 

Le lieu n'est pas très bien entretenu malgré le prix d'entrée de 2500CFA. 

Les photos ne sont pas autorisés. 

Il y a certes quelques objets historique, mais rien de transcendant / exceptionnel / rare. 
La guide parlait doucement et me donnait envie de dormir ; cependant ce qui est raconté sur l'époque des rois reste intéressant.

title: A Slice of Dahomean History
text:
Interesting site that focuses on the once great Dahomey empire. These are the palaces of King Ghézo and King Glélé that has been turned into a museum.

The palaces showcase interesting bas reliefs, artifacts and collections. I had an English speaking guide who is very knowledgeable about the history and gave me a thorough explanation of the different sites within the palace. 

Only downside is you can’t take pictures inside the palace.

title: Fascinating place
text:
Located right in the heart of Abomey this is a great place to learn about the Benin Kingdom - a part of history completely neglected in my UK schooling. There are some very interesting artefacts and you can easily spend a couple of hours wandering around. Although some of the buildings are slightly falling into disrepair you do get the sense of what it must have been like at the height of the kingdom (surely the main aim of every museum right?) The English speaking guide was informative and very knowledgeable about this time period, which was good.

Only disappointing thing was we weren't allowed to take photos anywhere on the tour. Other than that, it's a highly educational morning out.

title: a place of history
text: a great place to learn abt History. the guide was totally great explain to us about the great Abomey Empire. he brought us room to room  and show us the abomey stuff ,the history of the kings,the warriors ,the wars ,how the abomey people lived during that time. after the guided tours, there were stalls of souvenir shops where u can buy stuff if you are interesed

title: Quick Visit
text: I was staying in Bohicon and went for to see the Royal Palace of Abomey, its not too far. I paid 500 CFA for a Zem to take me there. The entrance fee was 2500 CFA and that comes with a guided tour. Afterwards you can hire the guide again to take you around Abomey on a Moto if you'd like.

title: Full of history, the other edge of the brazilian slavery sistem
text: A great place to see that there was history outside europe. They never teach us this in the school in Brazil.

title: Visite
text: Dommage que nous ne puissions pas faire de photo, visite intéressante, un guide très compétent connaissant sin sujet

title: Belle visite du Palais des Rois d’Abomey .
text:
Visite incontournable du Palais des Rois d’ Abomey . Pour s’imprégner de la culture de cette région du Bénin et comprendre son histoire .
Et puis à la sortie l’ artisanat proposé est intéressant surtout pour les tissus.

title: Belle découverte.
text: Visite à faire avec un guide local, nous avions  "Mathieu" qui nous a fait découvrir l histoire des rois avec beaucoup de passion. Nous n avons pas vu le temps passé 1h30. Ce fut une belle découverte.

title: Un viaggio nel tempo....
text: Luogo interessante da visitare anche se non è tenuto in buone condizioni. Merita comunque la visita se non altro per rendersi conto di come era strutturata la vita di corte in questa nazione africana. Nel cortile principale ci sono venditori di suvenir, c'è anche un telaio per la tessitura con cui vengono prodette le stoffe che sono messe in vendita.

title: schreckliche präsentation
text: Der königliche Palast gibt wirklich nicht viel her , die wenigen Ausstellungsstücke sind nicht beleuchtet, da ständig der Strom gekappt wird . auf die Frage warum die Führerin keine Taschenlampe hat - nur Schulter zucken . alles verstaubt . Der letzte Raum mit Königsstühlen und einigen Reliquien ist ok . Man muss ihn aber extra aufsperren .

title: Eher enttäuschend
text: Ist die gleiche Sehenswürdigkeit wie die Royal Palaces, also siehe die Bewertung dort. Zusammengefasst: trotz Weltkulturerbestatus kein wirkliches Highlight.

title: Eher enttäuschend
text: Ein Weltkulturerbe, dass von außen noch halbwegs interessant aussieht, aber von innen leider nur wenig zu bieten hat. Einige der Räume zeigen Gegenstände der alten Könige und der Führer gibt sicher sein Bestes. Allerdings ist ein Fotografierverbot im Inneren der Paläste und die Baustellenatmosphäre eigentlich ein "No-Go" für ein Weltkulturerbe, zumal Fotos keine Schäden verursachen würden. OK, es ist eine Sehenswürdigkeit, aber kein wirkliches Highlight.

title: Vietato fotografare.
text: Appena entrati, presso la biglietteria iniziano i cartelli che intimano di non fotografare né all'interno del palazzo né nei cortili interni ma soltanto nel cortile principale (dove ci sono i negozi di souvenir). Ci sono degli armadietti dove depositare le macchine fotografiche. Non si capisce bene la logica di tale divieto, che è comunque sgradevole perché alcuni punti del palazzo sono molto fotogenici, in particolare le facciate con le nicchie con gli inserti scultorei e le porte di legno finemente intagliate. Il sito è protetto dall'Unesco, ma la manutenzione lascia molto a desiderare. Le nicchie con le sculture sono piene di ragnatele e i prati incolti. Bruttissimi i tetti di lamiera, che hanno l'unico pregio di riprendere vagamente il color rosso terracotta dei palazzi e delle mura. Alcuni palazzi ospitano il museo, i cui pezzi salienti sono, a mio avviso, gli scettri reali (ce n'è uno per ognuno dei re) e i troni. Il regno del Dahomey termina nell'anno 1900 con l'invasione francese.

title: Un musée d’art contemporain africain
text: La Villa Ajavon, belle bâtisse de type afro- brésilien construite en 1922 et cédée en baille par les héritiers à la fondation Zinsou, abrîte le premier musée d’art contemporain africain. Le musée Zinsou de Ouidah est d’abord la rénovation d’une œuvre architecturale unique. Visitez le musée de la fondation Zinsou, j'y ai vécu une belle expérience.

title: Музей истории Африки
text: Посещение музея заняло не больше часа, зато много интересного мы узнали об Африки и местных жителях.

title: A voir absolument !
text:
Ouidah , fief du Vaudou béninois est une étape indispensable sur la route de Lome Ou dans l'autre sens sur la route de Cotonou .
Il faut s'arrêter en ville pour au moins 2 raisons :
La magnifique cathédrale de Ouidah , 1er cathédrale d'afrique construite au début du 20 eme siècle , et la fondation Zinsou ,fondation d'art contemporain , unique en Afrique .
Située derriere la cathédrale , la fondation est installée dans une vieille maison coloniale de 1929, cette fondation fait la part belle , aux jeunes et moins  jeunes artistes contemporains africains , venant d'afrique du sud , du togo , du benin bien sur mais aussi de Tanzanie et même d'Ethiopie .
En tous cas à ne pas rater , d'autant que les guides sont excellents et competents .

title: Lieu unique au Bénin
text:
In a beautifull freshly renovated house. 
Well trained people who give free explanation.
Unique Art collection in the country

title: Beautiful place, worth a visit
text: Beautifully restored place. includes lots of artwork from all over Africa. Certainly worth the trip from cotonou!

title: great environment & guide, average items inside
text: the guide Ms,  Raymonde is the only one who really can help you with the english language. The museum is free-cost and resume the african-culture throught painting and plastic arts. No pics allowed. Nice and comfortable bar but dont accept. USD., only local currency. The private owner made a great effort to develop the art and mantain the culture in the country.

title: meraviglioso

è un museo di arte moderna, con esposizioni di artisti africani.
la struttura è bellissima, anche solo per prendersi un caffè! c'è la connessione wi fi gratuita...insomma una perla ...dovrebbero esserci più luoghi così in Africa

title: A Gem in West Africa

title: The best attraction in Ouidah

A very nice selection of modern art and guides who make this art very accesssible. A nice museumshop and a vey pleasant cafe/restaurant complete this really marvelous place.
