title: Touched story well told
text: 2019 is the year of home coming of African Americans in the diaspora. To those who believe they come from Ghana and others who are interested in the history of the trans - Atlantic Slave trade, the UNESCO world heritage site the cape coast castle is a must tour. Any day I visited the cape coast castle I connect with history and reflect on it. Obuoba Tours will recommend the castle to all those who will travel to Ghana this year. Make sure you ask of Sebastian a site guide who is so knowledgeable with the history.

title: A sad history lesson
text: Very educational tour. A place that you should visit if you go to Ghana. The building is not special, but the atrocities should not be forgotten.

title: to trzeba zobaczyć
text: to był moj pierwszy raz i chętnie powrócę! lekcja historii i pokory. Niesamowita lokalizacja, dobrze utrzymany obiekt, piękne widoki, trzeba zobaczyć i poznać!

title: Beeindruckendes Relikt aus dunkler Zeit
text:
Cape Coast Castle sollte unbedingt mit Führung besichtigt werden. Dann bekommt einen besonderen Eindruck, unter welchen Umständen seinerzeit der Sklaven-Transfer hier abgewickelt wurde. 
Humanitäter Umgang mit der "Ware Mensch" war eher sehr klein geschrieben. Hat man aber schon häufiger auf der Welt erlebt. In vielen Ländern, auch in der Neuzeit. 
Also, wer will da den Finger heben?

title: Very Good History Lesson
text:
My eyes were open to so much. There is so much to learn and to literally weep over. The things these poor slaves experienced is painful to hear and just to try to imagine. Reaching the point of no return is a sobering moment.  

Personally, my preference is Elmina Castle if you only have time to visit one.  But if you experience both, please do. It will change you forever, regardless of your race, nationality or age.

title: A faire absolument
text:
Château rempli d'histoire. Beau bâtiment avec vue sur la baie.
A 3h d'accra, facile d'accès en voiture.

title: WE RETURNED SO WE WON
text:
The most tragic experience of our life. The emotional turmoil over the kidnapping, forced incarceration and brutality rained down upon my ancestors sent of to the Caribbean and the Americas. Through the door of NO RETURN.

YET BITTERLY AND PROUDLY there we stood. Empowered that our ancestors survived the brutality and we will continue to make them proud!

A PLACE FOR DIASPORA TO SEE 10000% NEVER FORGET!

Pay to go alone with your guide so you can grieve privately.

title: Interesting, moving, great scenery, a must!
text: We visited this castle after Elmina, which I believe is even more impressive. The interesting museum here, the scenery, the dungeons, the fact that all the area surrounding it is still so active - gives you a feeling that this all happened not so long ago. I would strongly recommend to visit both castles. They are different and each one compliments the other. Ask the guides hard questions - I was not impressed with their knowledge and intrigued with their bias

title: History Not To Be Repeated
text: It was with much reverence for those that suffered here that we visited this former slave holding castle and dungeons.   It's hard to imagine the suffering that people endured here and elsewhere during the slave trade.   We pray for freedom of all people.

title: The scale of human enslavement.
text: This is the most preserved of the extant enslavement structures in West Africa. The tour guides give a riveting account of the warehousing of humans before transporting them to the Americas and the Caribbean. The guides explain the purpose of the holding cells for men, women and children. Also how rebellious men and women were punished and allowed to die without food and water. The tour also includes how women were raped and abused by the captors. The tour concluded with a walk to the infamous "Door of No Return".

title: Really Pulled At My Heart
text: To step into the slave dungeons that held so many before being transported through the middle passage to the Americas and other places, pulled at my heart. As I closed my eyes and listened to the tour guide tell what it was like, you could feel the presence of a people who went through here. This was an eye opening tour and the tour guide did a stellar job in communicating the history lessons.

title: Sobering history tour
text:
This is a very good tour, reasonably priced, and interesting. You learn a lot about the history of the castle, when it was built, what nations occupied it and when, and the slave trade of which the castle played a large part. The tour is guided and  very interesting! It is quite sobering to think of all the people that went through the "door of no return" on their way to serve as slaves in the new world. 
The location is awesome as well, right on the shore of the gulf, with local fishermen's boats pulled up on the beach in front of the castle and many other boats docked or beached in the lagoon behind the castle. It is a feast for the senses! So much color, and the hustle bustle of the townspeople going about their daily routines. The smell of the lagoon and open sewer system can be a challenge to ignore, but if you can, visiting the castle is an enriching experience. I've visited twice since 2012, bringing groups both times, and I would certainly visit again. Been to Cape Coast Castle as well, but I must say, I like Elmina a little better.

title: Well Worth A Visit
text: It’s a must visit to pay respects to those millions of Africans who suffered at the castle and were shipped off against their will to serve the empire building of the Europeans. Steeped in history, with great views of the coast, it’s a great place to remember that every soul on the planet is important and we should do to others as we would like done to ourselves....whatever our perceived differences....

title: Very emotional visit
text: As one of the smaller castles it packed a big punch. It was hard being in the slave cells it was so hot and then I realized this was my ancestors reality shacked and with 100’s or more people! Then I humbled myself. I want to visit the larger castles as well! Great place to visit!

title: Must see!
text:
Als je in Cape Coast bent dan moet je hier naar toe. Geen plaats om trots op je voorouders te zijn.
Heb een rondleiding met een gids gedaan. Op deze manier hoor je zaken die anders aan je voorbij gaan.

title: Home at last
text: This was a really emotional visit, great story telling and presentation of historical facts. The visit was inexpensive and educational. The gift shop was also a nice touch. If you are ever in Ghana, this place is a must.

title: Heartfelt tour
text:
I enjoyed the castle tour. The guide was very good. He actually made us cry when he was telling us the history of the slave castle. It was an emotional tour that left us uneasy. That aside the guide pulled some jokes to make us relax.

If u visit the cape coast u must definitely visit the castle.

**********loved it *********

title: Must see
text: Been twice and I still get chills walking the same halls many walked in shackles. Great place to see a little bit of what it might have been like so many years ago. Tony was our tour guide and he was great!!!

title: the place were my ancectors were before me.
text: This place is a amazing and a emotional piece of history that is a must see if you are in Ghana. you can feel the sprit of the people and were here before. You can feel the pain that they had to go through while they were here. You can feel the lack of air in the dungeon that they stayed in, until they had to leave alive or dead.

title: Mother Goddess
text:
What a pristine Landmark preserved to perfection. The scultures and grounds are beautiful it was a pleseant beautiful walk through beautiful forest with gorgeous monkeys leading the way. 

It was a spritial high and a great chance to meditate and connect with the energies in the space.  You get a historical tour from a docent guide who gives you a historical narrative of the grounds. A most see space if you in Nigeria.

title: Easter period visit to the sacred grove
text:
Was an interesting outing.

The gate fee cost N200 for adults and free for children.
There was a tour guide at no extra cost. 
At the entrance, there were lots of monkeys (not sure wat specie).

The monkeys are friendly and they love to be fed bananas which we got from a lady who sells them at an affordable and cheap rate of N20 to N100.

Lots of arts, places and history inside the groove itself .....Pictures speaks more than words.

Visit and see for yourself.

title: One of the best tourist spots in Nigeria.
text: I have been a couple of times and each time I come around,I cannot but appreciate the efforts that have come into making it a world class tourist destination.The history behind it authentic and exciting. The location has been  jealousy guarded from the usual onslaught of unappreciative Nigerians.

title: Sacred Indeed
text: Was always scared of visiting but after the visit I realized it was not as scary as I thought. The locals at the site are friendly and I learnt more about the history of the place.

title: Beautiful and Interesting
text:
The entry fee to this place is 200naira and it was worth every Kobo. The monkeys welcome you as you come in and it will be nice if you could at least buy them some bananas. A banana seller is just right around the corner.

The guide was very knowledgeable and the fee paid included the guide. So there is no need to pay more. 

The Osun festival happens around the 2nd or 3rd week of August and we were told that was the best time to visit. 

The artworks were breathtaking and I asked the Osun goddess for triplets and loads of wealth. I hope she heard me. Lol.

title: A must-see for any visitor to western Nigeria
text:
Or perhaps I should clarify a little. It's a must-see for anyone with an interest in African history, art, culture and religion.
The ideal time to visit the grove would be at the culmination of the Osun Festival which holds annually in August. In addition to all that the grove has to offer, the August tourist will have the opportunity to take in a vibrant ceremony whose traditions date back a few hundred years. 
I have toured the grove unassisted in the past but during my recent visits, it's been made increasingly difficult to tour the site without engaging one of the official guides. Their fee is not exorbitant - I think I paid the equivalent of less than $20 for a 3-hour tour (you can spend more or less time depending on how much time you're willing and able to spend at each shrine or statue). 
I was puzzled by the security alert attached to this site by TripAdvisor. I've never heard of anyone's safety or security being compromised in the area. I was lugging a substantial bag of blatantly expensive photographic equipment and should have been an obvious target for miscreants. I remained constantly aware fo my surroundings as I always am in unfamiliar locations and never once sensed or saw a threat. 
The forest and structures within the site would delight any photographer. The ubiquitous Mona Monkeys at the grove's entrance will entertain any nature -lover. Your own prior research or the help of a good guide will ensure that you appreciate the history and cultural significance of this place.

title: Holiday thing
text: Highly recommended for tourists.  It's good to have some banana to feed the friendly baby monkeys. They will welcome you as you enter the gate. The staff are also helpful and you are allocated a guide to take you around and give you the history.

title: Nature, Culture and Arts combined
text:
We hired a guide Toyin to take us through the forest walk which we felt enhanced the overall experience she took us to the art pieces in different locations of the sacred grove. There were amazing finds amid the serene greenery - art pieces in different locations though the sheer dedication of few folks who invested time, effort and funds to maintain and improve this place.  

We ended our tour with a visit to Susanne Weger's house which we highly recommend as well.

Note that there is a camera fee for phone cameras 1000 naira and normal cameras and 3000 naira so plan ahead on who should be the assigned photographer!

title: Touch of nature and close to nature
text: It is an experience worth having in seeing the power of nature and what the Supreme being has given to us to adore HIM

title: Road Trip to Osun-Osogbo Sacred Groove
text:
My trip to the famous Osun-Osogbo Sacred groove was breathtaking as I had so much fun and was also educated about Osogbo and It's people.

The groove is believed to have a supernatural healing powers that cures illnesses, most especially bareness.

There are a few restricted zones in the groove namely: Igbo Ifa (Meaning Forest of Ifa - a god) and the second Ataoja's palace (Ataoja is the title of the traditional ruler of Osogbo land) believed to be the meeting place of the Ogboni confraternity.

Ultimately, the environment is quite serene and the tour guides knows their job as they are prompt to provide answers to questions.

You can also visit astrologers for less that $5 if you want to...."smiles".

I recommend this site to anyone planning to visit Osogbo anytime soon.

Please feel free to ask any question you have an I will try as much as possible to answer them to the best of my knowledge.

Gracias.

title: Serene in a magical way
text: The Osun-Osogbo groove is a UNESCO world heritage site. It is beautiful and serene in a magical way. The sculptures are huge and very intricately detailed. The annual Osun-Osogbo Festival sees this place packed with worshipers and tourists. Visit the groove to feel closer to nature and learn more about the rich history of the Yoruba people.

title: MY CRADLE
text: this is my origin. I have absolutely nothing negative to write about this historical heritage of all Osun origins.

title: Another Visit
text: The last time i was here was in 1985, as with before i have a chaperone as i was travelling via Osun to the North, quite an experience and highly recommended if you are interested in history and mythology

title: one of those truly globally unique places
text: the whole Osogbo experience is very special particularly if you have affinity with local culture.  First, the sacred Grove is magical for two reasons. 1.  that it is still a functioning Shrine for the ancient Yoruba religion - for Osun the Water Goddess - is rare in a country when fundamental Christianity and Islam has destroyed much of the original Orisha and other local Nigerian religious sites.  2 that the outstanding and mystical art of Suzanne Wenger so clearly fraternises with the local environment that they both become as one.  Second, when you are in osogbo make sure you visit Suzanne's amazing house, Nike's gallery and art complex where students learn traditional cultural crafts such as Adire (traditional Yoruba batik).

title: Highlight of My Time in South Eastern Nigeria
text:
The sacred grove was such a sight to see! The artwork was just incredible and the history surrounding it is very interesting. Luckily my fiancee and I were visiting a friend who lives in Ile Ife, and had him as our escort and guide, which made things much easier. To be honest doing anything sans a friend who is a local or native is basically impossible, unless you know the culture and are a seasoned traveler. However the people of Osogbo were very nice and welcoming, if not a bit wary or curious as to our presence as foreigners. My fiancee and I wanted to learn as in depth as we could about the Ifa religion and thanks to our friends and his acquaintances we were able to. 

I lived in Nigeria for over 2 years (In Yola, Adamawa) and my time in Ife/Osogbo and the surrounding areas was the most enjoyable time I had in those two years. I love the Yoruba people, they are kind and warm people and probobly the most sincere you will find in Nigeria. 

This is a place many people will never see and it really is a damn shame, because this part of Nigeria is steeped in history, tradition, and beauty. Love love love the Osun Grove!

title: Osun-Osogbo Sacred Grove
text:
One of the fewest UNESCO World Heritage Centre (WHC) in Nigeria, Osun-Osogbo Sacred Grove is a must view place for every traveller.  A place that has its own traditional background which is respected even now by every sorts of people in the town.  Reasonable entry fee with guide, additional charges for Photography...

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osun-Osogbo

title: OSUN RIVER
text: Yo fui al festival de Osun, me gustó mucho. Les recomiendo que vayan a finales de agosto, que es la fecha del festival. Se hace una procesión desde el templo de Osun hasta el río, ahí se pueden ver los bailes y la música tradicionales y los ritos a Osun, la deidad del rio. La gente es muy amable. Las personas que tocan los tambores les querrán tocar a cambio de dinero como aportación voluntaria, ya es de cada quien si aceptan o no. También hay adivinaciones de los sacerdotes y sacerdotisas. Es un ambiente muy agradable, hay visitantes tanto locales como extranjeros (asiáticos, europeos, americanos, latinoamericanos). También hay mucha seguridad, hay muchos policías ese día porque al evento va el rey de Osogbo. Hay muchas actividades por hacer, muchas cosas qué ver y mucha gente qué conocer. Yo sí les recomiendo la visita.

title: Sacred or secret?
text:
Nice place to visit, admission fee includes a guide, which is very welcome and you will learn a lot about this forest. Somehow they want to rip you off with the photography charge/fee, which is incredibly expensive, so try to make a some kind of a deal.

Recommended.

title: Good Collection
text: A place where all the traditional african collections are available. From leather to wooden to pearls. Great place for Interior decorative items, portraits.

title: Art Shoppers Haven
text:
If you follow my reviews,  you'd know I'm a serious art lover.
With the Lekki Art Market, I literally stroll through the stalls for hours! I go from stall to stall looking through the different art pieces. And when I find a special piece, I find another slice of heaven!
If you've never been,  you should! And if you're planning a visit to Lagos, you should add a visit.

Preferably go with the local currency: Naira. Go with cash, not your card.

title: So many shops!
text:
I wanted souvenirs to take back with me and found the Lekki Market on Trip Advisor. 

If I had spent 8 hours there it would not be enough time! Each little Shop contains so many beautifully created object from carvings, clothing, cloth, jewerly, and so many different and well displayed wares.

You need to go several times to fully appreciate the vast volume. 

Do not be afraid to negotiate, a great place to learn if you have never haggled before.

title: Bits and Pieces of Nigerian Artwork
text: Though the road to this market is not exactly smooth, but like the proverbial "narrow gate' it leads you to a market that has a lot of local Adire fabrics for table cloth and mats, traditional  Yoruba fabric Aso - Oke , unimaginable wealth of Nigerian as well as African artwork and painting collection. I went there at the beginning of the year when I needed a gift for an out -going British colleague. Got a painting that depicted the Lagos you must see from the main bridge that connects the mainland to the Island- Little huts built in the Lagoon. It is a must visit when you come to lagos. Better to arrange with your hotel for a tour guide.

title: LOCAL ARTS & CRAFT TYPE OF MARKET
text:
The market is surrounded by slum / shanty town and the unpaved road has huge pot holes with large boulders hidden under the mud and water.....
I personally do not find it worthwhile to make this trip to Lekki Market to see local handicrafts unless one has a serious SUV to navigate the mud track.

title: Good place for ethnic handicrafts and paintings
text: Good place to shop for ethnic handicrafts and paintings at reasonable prices. Lots of tiny shops with variety of wooden artifacts, paintings and artificial jewelry. Only buy precious stones if you are an expert and can differentiate real from fake. Feel free to negotiate hard and strike a reasonable bargain, sometimes 50% or more. Avoid going there on a rainy day. Best time is after and before office rush hours. Sunday the market is closed though some shops are still open. Good for couples or grown ups for young kids nothing much interesting. A must visit even if you don't want to shop!

title: Pamiątki ok ale miejsce słabe
text: Ten rynek jest w innym miejscu niż pokazuje Tripadvisor, szukajcie na Google prawidłowego położenia.Biali lepiej niech sami się tam nie wybierają tylko z przewodnikiem i nie chodzić wieczorową porą bo okolica jest niebezpieczna. 2 duże obrazy za 50$ cena do zaakceptowania.

title: It's a market
text:
I don't know what to tell you, it's a market. If you are a foreigner it's advisable to go with a trusted local, be prepared to "price" (haggle) everything.

A good tip is to divide whatever price they give you by four or five and work your way to a happy medium and be prepared to walk away if the amount is still too high.

title: Foreigner Rip off
text: You get much better value visiting markets in other Nigerian states to purchase the local handicraft, some at one fifth of the costs in this market and without even much bargaining. While i understand there are transport costs involved to bring items to Lagos to sell, but the prices quoted were ridiculously high. Surprisingly even though we walked off after some negotiations, they did not call us back.  Secondly, the layout was confusing and there was poor ventilation.

title: Heaven for shoppers
text:
Availability of the beautiful Nigerian cultural artifacts at affordable prices.
Pearl jewellery awesome and most importantly original.

title: BEAUTIFUL AND COLORFUL MARKET!
text: The Lekki Craft Market is an open air African market, In which almost everything you need is available for sale; from furniture to food, from paintings to table cloths and CD’s; the list goes on. This market will engage all of your senses and emotions; as such one should come prepared to buy several items from this market. The walkways are flanked on either side by stalls laden with beautiful jewelry made from glass countries such as Ghana and Senegal, there are intricate wood and stone carvings with exquisite detail, some carry rare and old bottles used for oil and alcohol, some which date as far back as the 1930’s and 40’s you will find antique telephones, record players and typewriters, there are traditional Nigerian woven fabrics (aso oke) and batik pieces for sale, leather goods abound, with some goods made from alligator or snake skin, there are Benin bronze works, wood carvings, drums and masks and still, the list goes on. There are great bargains to be had and take time to engage your vendor about the origin of his pieces.

title: cool market
text: you will get the exact thing you want in good quality, great way of appreciating customers who patronize, its such a wonderful market you will like to go there all the time

title: Myriad of traditional treasures
text: Great to go and experience a well established local Lekki market. Shop for leather sandals, jewelry, artworks, iron and wood sculptures and even large pieces of furniture. The traditional glass beadworks are exceptional and well worth investing in. Haggle hard, but with good humour and you'll come away with great bargains. Good for good quality herbs and vegetables that may not be in the main food shops, and popular with many expatriate communities. Watch out for flooding in rainy season or take your wellies.

title: Good place for African curios
text: Went here with some work colleagues. Great little place for African souvenirs and seems safe to walk around. All the usual stuff and some decent art. Very cheap prices by European standards though you will need to bargain, even if the starting prices are still cheap! Be warned though, the roads leading up to it are awful.

title: Great Nigerian mementos
text: Lekki market is great for buying Nigerian arts & crafts and jewelry. The road leading to it (off the highway) is rough though. I understand it's currently being fixed. Feel free to haggle and never accept the first price given to you.

title: Only place to buy arts and crafts in Lagos
text: I have been coming to this market for years. It has a huge selection of arts and crafts, as well as other small shops and services.  Its hidden away from the road and you need to find a driver who knows how to find it.  If you bargain well, the prices can be very reasonable.

title: Great value for money
text:
This is an arts and crafts market. Good for shopping for souvenirs, great and small.

There is a huge variety of African (not necessarily Nigerian) articles that you can buy. From as little as 25cents (0.25USD) for key rings, upwards.

I always get a receipt/invoice for payments, and I suggest you do same if you are taking your purchase out of Nigeria.

For some articles that are copies of artefacts, you may need to process them with the National Museum, to get a certificate for customs purposes. Normally for small items or common, there will be no issues.

title: Alladin's cave
text: Tucked away off the expressway is a maze of shops selling everything you could possibly want from some really impressive original art work through 'pirate' DVDs to hand woven rush table mats, pottery, bangles and beads as well as wooden figures and some really old artefacts - better than you can find in the museum! If you enjoy bartering then this is the place for you. Beware of opportunists but most of the traders are friendly and very entertaining.

title: Hidden Treasures
text:
We have been going to the market for the last 10 years and it has always been a pleasure.
Suggest you spend time in the shops selling masks and curios. ...
Ask the shopkeepers about the history and you will be surprised ... 
Once done head to the beach....

title: African Art, Coral & Pearls
text: Place is 9 KM from Victoria Island. Local market with amazing artworks, souvenirs, paintings, wood carvings, masks, pearls, Corals, wall hangings, and many more. Park inside the allocated parking space and pay N200. Always go with a driver and frined who knows Lekki market. You have to bargain a lot...

title: A visiter
text: Franchement je ne suis pas très musée, et bien ce petit musée sans prétention  est à voir. On ne peut pas rester insensible à cette collection d'art africain et on est agréablement surpris alors qu'il ne bénéficie pas de beaucoup de publicité dans les guides.

title: Art,collection  et culture locale
text: Mérite le détour dans cet ancien palais pour 8€ une expo de peintres cap verdien,une collection d'art africain remarquable evec de superbes "pièces et bien sûr un hommage émouvant  à la Diva au pieds nus qui retrace avec profusion de "fotos" intimes et ses principaux "tours" dans le monde..Très agréable dans cette atmosphère coloniale..A voir !

title: A voir
text: Beau résumé de l'icone du Cap-Vert.Une exposition photo riche,énormément de tenue portées par Cesaria.Le tout à un prix modéré de 500 escudos.

title: Importante per la storia di Sao Vicente
text: Cesaria Evora ha viaggiato in tutto il Mondo ed è stata, non solo grande musicista ma ambasciatrice della sua Terra che deve a lei molto. Il Museo merita senz'altro di essere visto per celebrare una delle figure più importanti di Capo Verde. In un'area separata dell'edificio invece, è possibile accedere anche a una collezione privata di arte africana da tutto il Mondo

title: Musée original...
text:
car situé dans l'ancien palais du gouverneur, d'un joli rose malabar, on peut visiter 3 expos très différentes d'un coup (8€ par pers.): celle consacrée à Cesaria Evora (gloire locale et internationale), celle qui propose des tableaux d'artistes capverdiens et une magnifique expo d'objets d'art africains (masques, tam-tam, armes...). Le tout, dans un joli espace clair et bien entretenu. 
Comptez au minimum 30 minutes de visite. Il existe des fiches d'informations en français.

title: Interessante
text:
In questo bel palazzo coloniale, in passato casa del governatore ci sono due musei interessanti, uno e' il museo Cesaria Evora dedicato alla cantante di Mindelo.
Ci sono centinaia di foto, scritti, strumenti e alcuni suoi vestiti che indossava durante i concerti.
Il secondo museo e' una esposizione  di arte capoverdiana e africana.

title: African Art Museum
text: Excellent Museum. Small but filled with african art fom different West African  countries. It is also part og¡f the Museum devotde to Cesarea Evora that I do not visited

title: Exposition africaine remarquable
text:
2 expos, une sur C Evora que nous n’avons pas choisie et une sur l’art africain de toute beauté.
Des masques, des statues, des portes....un ensemble remarquablement mis en valeur.
A voir absolument pour 500 CVE par personne.

title: Een charmant, klein museum, relatief prijzig voor het gebodene
text: Een leuke, kleine tentoonstelling van allerlei herinneringen uit het leven van Cesaria Evora. Foto's, jurken, cd's en ga zo maar door. Stel je er niet teveel van voor, dan is het leuk. Als je de zangeres niet kent, is bezoek niet zinvol.

placeInfo.name: Alternativa Galeria
placeInfo.address: Av. 5 De Julho, Mindelo, Sao Vicente, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

addressObj.street1: Av. 5 De Julho, Mindelo, Sao Vicente

title: Super!
text: Très bon magasin d'art artisanal et FairTrade. Tout est fabriqué sur l'île, les produits cosmétiques sont également de très bonne qualité. Toutes les vendeuses étaient parfaites!

title: Muito giro tudo e causa linda. Compensa e recomendo
text: Muito giro tudo e causa linda. Os produtos são tradicionais e especiais. Tem desde produtos cosméticos como decorativos e com utilidade

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Negozio artigianale
text: Personale molto gentile e disponibile, la ragazza che ci ha serviti parlava bene italiano. Abbiamo comprato caffè del luogo e un liquore tipico, tutto eccellente! Consiglio vivamente questo negozio se volete portarvi a casa un souvenir artigianale.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

text: Lovely shops in Sal with fair trade  products to support local artisans. Includes local liquors as well. Visit more than one as they have different products

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: As nossas compras
text:
Djunta Mo Art, uma loja sustentável com produtos locais e de cariz solidário, da qual, ficamos ainda mais fãs.
Sem dúvida a melhor loja para comprar souvenirs.
Adorei o atendimento. Super simpáticas e atenciosas.
Recomendo ❤️ 

Maria e Diogo

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Lovely shop ♥️
text: We were looking for some native made art and luckily found this amazing shop on the main turist street of Santa Maria town. Great selection of wares and amazing staff. I definitely recommend this little shop 👍🏾

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Da farci un salto!
text:
E’ un negozio molto carino, con prodotti creati da artigiani capoverdiani.
Ci sono moltissime idee molto graziose, etiche, di fair trade, che cercano di opporsi alla concorrenza cinese nell’ambito dei souvenir.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Netter Laden
text:
Netter Laden mit nettem Personal.
Man wird weder aufdringlich dazu aufgefordert den Laden zu betreten, noch wird man drinnen bedrängt oder zum kaufen überredet. Es wird gefragt, ob man hilf ebenötigt odernur schauen möchte und kann sich dann im aller ruhe umsehen. 
Es gibt einen Taste-Stand für die diversen Liköre an dem man freundlich beraten wird.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: great present
text: We  just came back from our trip and got a beautiful colorful totebag as a present for our daughter and she loves it so much. It’s very good quality with a pocket inside and a cute button. everyone was so nice! Thank u!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Volle Empfehlung
text:
Toller Laden mit nachhaltigen und fair trade Artikeln. Tolles Projekt, dass der Bevölkerung zu gute kommt. Die Produkte sind schön gemacht und nicht so ein Ramsch, den man sonst überall aufgeschwatzt bekommt... 
Personal war freundlich und unaufdringlich. Bezahlung war auch in € kein Problem.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Fair trade, no scams
text: The place to buy locally produces goods in Sal. Actual local goods and a good purpose. Polite service, no pressuring.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Skvělé nakupování.
text:
Je to nádherný obchůdek se skvělou obsluhou. Holky jsou milé a příjemné.
Koupili jsme několik dárků a byli jsme moc potěšení jak nás obsloužily a přijaly od mé ženy jako dárek pár obyčejných náramků že skla. Zde je svět plný emocí a krásných výrobků. 
Určitě se tam jednou vrátíme. 
Renata a Anton Czech Republik.
Děkujeme.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Fair trade and craft beer
text: Small shop in the main pedestrian street. Wide range of fair trade souvenirs and other stuff including excellent craft beers

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Artesanato de verdadeiros artesãos Cabo-Verdeanos
text: Loja muito acolhedora, funcionárias simpáticas e muito produtos e artigos artesanais naturais de Cabo-Verde.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Muy recomendable
text: La tienda está situada al lado de la playa, me atendieron muy bien, los productos son naturales y de calidad, encuentras alimentación, cosmética, regalos y joyería artesanal. Muy recomendable, la atención de las dependienta muy amable. Si quieres contribuir al comercio justo esta es tu tienda.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Loja de produtos regionais produzidos por cooperativas locais
text: A loja oferece boas opções em produtos alimentare e bebidas locais, além de artesanato, produzidos por cooperativas caboverdianas, com certeza um local a ser visitado se procura produtos regionais ou pequenas prendas. As geleias produzidas com frutas das ilhas são maravilhosas, já testamos todas, nenhuma deixou a desejar!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Fair trade
text:
Place whith fantastic customer service, explaining everything bout the objects we wanted to buy.
Great prices for fair trade.
must visit

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Such a wonderful experience
text:
🇪🇸Mis padres fueron de vacaciones a Cabo Verde decidieron pasarse por esta tienda para comprar unos souvenirs. La atención excelente y los productos que tienen son preciosos. Realmente vale la pena apostar por el comercio justo y local. Además, ellas son majisimas y su trabajo es delicado. Muchas gracias!

🇬🇧My parents went on vacation to Cabo Verse and decided to go to this shop to buy some souvenirs. The customer service was excellent and the products that they have are beautiful. Investing in local and fair trade is worth it! Besides, they are very nice and their work is done delicately! Thanks!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Fantastic shop for souvenirs and gifts! Fair trade and supporting local craftspeople.
text: Amazing little shop filled with fantastic, locally made gifts to take home as souvenirs or gifts. The staff were really friendly and helpful. I loved the fact that purchases support local producers and many of the items are made with recycled materials. Support the local economy and shop here!

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Souvenirs
text: Gostei do conceito da loja, em que os produtos vendidos eram feitos em Cabo Verde. Estive duas vezes na loja da Rua 1 de Junho e a simpatia das funcionárias foi imensa.

placeInfo.name: Djunta Mo Art
placeInfo.address: Rua 1 de Junho Predio Plaza, Santa Maria, Ilha do Sal 4111 Cape Verde

title: Occasion raté de mettre une endroit classé par Unesco en valeur
text:
L’ enceinte des palais devrait être assez impressionant, mais l’ indifference pour la patrimoine de Bénin par les autorités de ce pays devraient drolement s’ améliorer avant que la visite sois satisfaisant au lieu d’ être une grosse déception.
La toiture traditionnele en paille de TOUT les palais est remplacée avec de l’ ondulé. on ne peut prendre AUCUNE photo, et ils ne disposent même pas d’ une brochure, et encore moins d’ un catalogue.
Pourtant il y plein de bas reliefs de toute beauté sur les murs, et une collection d’ objets assez impressionante.

title: Lieu impressionnant à découvrir
text:
un lieu classé à l'unesco pour de très bonnes raisons. J'ai découvert les raffinements d'une culture que je connaissais peu. Les palais forment tout simplement un ensemble magnifique. Le guide est efficace et répond à vos questions.
Cependant, une petite déception, j'aurais aimé passer plus de temps sur les différents blasons et mieux observer l'architecture des palais. Il y a un art visuellement très riche qui s'étale sur les murs des palais et que l'on voit un peu défiler au pas de course... pour se concentrer sur les objets vaudous qui au final m'intéresser peu. 
Par ailleurs, il est urgent d'agir pour la conservation des objets !

title: Enrichissant
text:
Une visite à faire qui explique bien la dynastie du Dahomey qui s'étale sur 3 siècles avec ses 12 rois.
Il ne faut pas s'attendre à trouver une architecture phénoménale, ce sont des constructions en terre, mais il y a quelques expositions avec les sièges des rois, les autels portatifs, des manequins, photos, ... l'essentiel donc, qui se visite en 1h / 1h30.
Le guide (essentiel !) a su mettre en valeur et à faire vivre le site.
Tarifs doux (2000 CFA pour de mémoire pour les étrangers), petit village artisanal.
Bémol : photos interdites dans le site même, toilettes pitoyables, pas d'eau pour laver mains, pas d'indication pour trouver le site (faut demander sur la route ;)

title: Un patrimoine à protéger
text: Le musée est intéressant, on se laisse guider par un guide local qui connait bien l'histoire du pays et les petites anecdotes. Malheureusement, le musée commence à vieillir, les expositions sont peu protégées et prennent l'humidité. Il reste peu de musée de ce type au Bénin, je trouve cela triste que leur patrimoine ne soit pas mieux préservé.

title: Excellente visite
text: Très bel endroit, il vaut le détour et les visites guidées sont de très bonnes qualité. Le personnel est agréable et fait partager sa passion pour l'histoire béninoise.

title: Awesome souvenir shop
text: I went a week ago and it was odd that they randomly decided to close the palace visit 1hr early. I had the time to come the next day but it sucks for those with limited travel time. On the flip side, the market place is pretty awesome. I purchased a dinning table clothe with place setters despite lack of not having a dinning table, it was that beautiful.

title: interessante
text:
sicuramente un posto da visitare per capire come si viveva due secoli fa in africa. pur essendo un sito unesco la manutenzione lascia molto a desiderare, e se lo confrontiamo con i palazzi europei della stessa epoca riusciamo a comprendere perchè l'africa è terribilmente arretrata.
guida solo in francese

title: Explications tres claires de la part du guide
text: Cette visite du palais des rois d Abomey ( 12 rois jusque 1900) est très intéressante et les explications du guide sont très claires et permettent de vivre le passe

title: viaje a benin semana santa 2017
text: No es demasiado interesante si no te explican lo que ves y un poco la historia del reino de abomey y de sus reyes,todo es de barro y excepto en la plaza principal no se pueden sacar fotos.

title: decent visit
text:
The palaces are probably the highlight of Abomey but are not amazing.  Yes it is an interesting tour and your must do it if you are close but it wont blow you away at all.

Tour takes about an hour maybe a little more.  Interesting history for sure.  Can get hot and sunny so consider sunscreen for sure and bring water!!

title: You really need a guide to understand the stories behind the palaces
text: We had an excellent guide.  You can visit two of the 12 palaces (the only ones that survived when the then-king burned them down in 1892 as he fled the French invasion).  The buildings contain traditional thrones, weapons, etc.  On your way out, you can take a look at the handicrafts: some fairly good stuff actually made locally.

title: For history buffs!
text:
If you are interested in the history of Benin then this is a must-see UNESCO site. There are no pictures allowed inside and you can only visit two of the palaces as the rest are in ruins. Our English speaking guide was exemplary and by asking lots of questions we learnt a lot which brought together our knowledge from visiting other sites across Benin.

At the time of visiting we were made to pay an additional tourist tax of 1000 CFA which was advertised on the wall in French. We were given a receipt for this but it is worth bearing in mind for budgeting.

title: Great tour
text: The Palaces are very interesting as is the tour. If you do not speak French you may not understand all the information as the tour is very detailed.  Pictures are not allowed which is too bad, as it would be nice to revisit memories.

title: Abomey Palaces - A Royal Letdown
text:
The royal palaces of the Dahomey kingdom are spread all around the town of Abomey.

We are traveling around West Africa with a Togolese English-speaking guide. He suggested we begin our tour of the kings palaces with a visit to one palace that also houses the main museum. 

We didn't visit a second palace. 

Our visit to the palace was underwhelming. Yes it was interesting to see the architecture and a few of the items showcased in the museum, however the museum collection is spread all over the complex in small, dark rooms in locked buildings. 

A map of the complex is not available aside from a heavily weathered, to the point of being unreadable, plaque when you first enter. 

We were provided with a museum staff member who was supposed to be our guide, but he did essentially no guiding and just followed us around. I refuse to call him a guide. 

We wandered around the complex with our Togolese guide doing his best to recall what he'd learned on previous visits to the museum. 

We had to wait for our museum staff member to unlock every building before we could enter. 

You aren't allowed to take pictures for some reason and our unlocking staff member did double duty as our photo policeman. 

In my opinion, tourism works as follows: a tourist visits somewhere, takes photos, shares photos and the experience with others and inspires them visit as well....

Don't waste your time travelling all the way to Abomey to visit here.

title: Un musée qui s'appauvrit
text:
Le musée perd en qualité et s'appauvrit en objets d'année en année. Sans compter le fait que le prix vous sera demandé avec un facteur 3 ou 4 par rapport aux locaux. 
Il reste tout de même une part de l'histoire du Bénin et mérite qu'on s'y attarde si on a un peu de temps

title: Interesting if you are into cultural history
text: Yes it is true, some of the palaces are not well preserved and not being taken care of. UNESCO efforts to restore and protect have been burned down several times "accidentally" by children igniting the grass around the structures to catch bushmeat. But a lot of archeological sites in the world have not a lot to see any more. The history behind those palaces is really fascinating and you can get a very good feel of the sites if you take some time and walk around the premises of the ruins. Locked front gates should not prevent you from it, everybody walks around them. The guide we hired from the tourist office was very helpful though not knowledgeable to an academical level naturally. We liked him anyhow and hired him next day to show us markets, places to eat and the museum. Official rate is CFA 4.000 for two hours plus 2.000 for the tourist office. Later one you can save if you hire him directly. We strongly recommend a guide, they are helpful, not expensive and you do a good job in directly supporting the young people there. Our official guide from the tourist center was the only English speaking one, we where his second customers this year in October.

title: Pas très bien mise en valeur mais des nouveautés en perspectives
text:
Guides très bien parlant 3 langues : Français, anglais, espagnol
Par contre le site n'est pas très bien mis en valeur et il faut pas hésiter à poser pleins de questions pour bien comprendre.
Le site est immense (45ha) mais tout ne se visite pas et surtout les photos sont interdites.
Ne pas hésiter (si vous avez un véhicule) à demander en fin de visite d'aller voir le fossé périphérique de protection pour bien comprendre comment était organisée cette place forte.
Un pan d'histoire de toute la dynastie des rois de Dahomey, des guerres, du business de l'époque avec portugais puis français ...

title: Une visite à enrichir de lectures
text:
Si vous ne savez rien de l'histoire du royaume, vous aurez bien du mal à comprendre. 
Abomey et son histoire se vivent au quotidien. Les guides ne sont pas toujours à niveau, mais les efforts sont tout à fait perceptibles pour rendre ce moment abordable au visiteur non initie et chaque béninois  vous en contera... Un morceau... Avec sa vision... 
À voir : les collections d'assens et trônes dans le musée, les nombreuses cours et le village des artisans avec la boutique où vous trouverez de la documentation sur le site et des cartes postales. 
Complétez la visite par un tour de ces 44 ha en Zem ou à pied pour vous imprégner de ce haut lieu du patrimoine mondial : palais du roi Behanzin, palais d'Akaba,honnouwa d'Agadja, marche des amazones... 
Ce site est magique comme la ville, comme ce royaume encore tellement vivant, patrimoine de l'humanité.

title: Royal Palace and Museum
text: Well worth a visit. Unfortunately they wouldn’t let anyone take any pictures inside the palaces. The temple walls in the palaces are built from clay mixed with the blood of prisoners of war combined with gold dust, pearls and gunpowder. There is a royal throne inside which rests on the skulls of enemies.When a king died all of his wives were buried alive so that they could serve him in the after life. And most of the kings had more than 200 wives.Get a guide who can speak English, otherwise you cannot make head or tail of what you see.

title: rivivere la storia
text: è stato veramente interessante entrare nel palazzo e immaginare come era nel passato: tante volte ci piacciono solo i grandi resti della nostra storia ( e niente da dire, sono certo eccezionali) ma anche conoscere altre "storie" ci può permettere di imparare qualcosa che forse non avremmo immaginato

title: A memorable experience at Nike art gallery
text: Visiting Nike Art Gallery with my friends Oluchi and Uche was such a refreshing and inspiring experience. From the moment we arrived, the space felt extremely neat, welcoming, and full of creative energy. Timothy showed us around and did a fantastic job explaining the different art pieces, which made the experience even more meaningful. We went upstairs and were amazed by the variety—vivid, colourful artworks, and fascinating pieces made entirely from trash. Each artwork told a story. Outside the gallery, the vibe continued with drummers and dancers performing live, adding a lively cultural touch. We had so much fun and left feeling inspired. I highly recommend this place to anyone who appreciates art in all its forms.

title: Very good experience
text: My experience of art revolves around generating images that combine natural beauty with personalized elements. I created a series of snow scenes with intricate snowflakes and the name "CHISOM" incorporated into the design, often with gold and silver accents. Each iteration offered a unique blend of serenity and elegance, showcasing the versatility of digital art in capturing the essence of winter landscapes while making them personal and special. Through these designs, I aimed to evoke a sense of wonder and tranquility, highlighting the beauty of art in personalizing everyday elements.

title: Great Experience!
text: We took a 2.5 hour drive from Accra to visit the castles. Our guide was very knowledgeable and covered many aspects of the castle. The tour started with a visit to the museum. We had ample time to check out the museum on our own before starting the castle tour. It lasted for about an hour and was very informative. There is a gift shop that sells books and CD’s about the castles.

title: Life-Changing Experience
text:
Visiting the Elmina and Cape Coast Castles is an essential experience, especially for those (like myself) who live in countries based on a history of enslavement. Our guide, Martin, was excellent and did a wonderful and thorough job explaining the cruel history of this place. Understanding what happened here is essential to understanding the history of my own country, as well as the history of Ghana and other parts of Africa. I will never forget what I learned and experienced here, including standing in the dungeons where so many thousands of men and women suffered and died. I will reflect on this visit for years to come.

(Those who visit, please remember to tip your guides.)

title: A must see for the children of the African Diaspora
text:
This was the third slave stockade I have visited and nothing can prepare you for the emotions which can erupt for the ancestors of stolen Africans.
It is a glimpse into our past...to see an actual "Door of no return". The doors where my ancestors were pushed, shoved and dragged through by their captures and dispersed across the world.

This building is proof to those who lack knowledge that SLAVERY was not a choice for the captives, it was only a choice for the gun toting captors.

title: founded in 1482
text:
Of the several fortified trading posts along the coast of Ghana, which today belong to the UNESCO World Heritage, only the three biggest ones are called castles: Christiansborg of mainly Danish origin in Osu, Accra (not open to the public, since it gets used by the government), Cape Coast (mainly British in its today construction) and St.George in Elmina, which is mainly Dutch in character.

The castles of Cape Coast and Elmina are now museums and they are by far the best preserved (and restored) and also the most visited of all these heritage sites. On top they are only about 13 km apart from each other. If in the area, it definitely makes sense to visit them both.

The castle at Elmina was first built by the Portuguese in 1482, thus 10 years before Columbus had reached the America's. The main reason was to trade in gold, which apparently was abundant here at the 'Gold Coast' (as the old colonial name of Ghana went). In 1637 the castle became Dutch until 1872, when all their properties here were sold to the British. 

In its structure the castle is still mainly a work of the Dutch and there are inscriptions in Dutch language to be seen at different points. From the Portuguese times only the chapel in the courtyard is left, which the Dutch turned into a warehouse and where now a very worthwhile exhibition with photographs and comments about Elmina's past can be seen - with themes like 'Trade, Slave Trade, Religion. Traditional Building, or the Asante in Elmina'.

Unlike at the much more visited Cape Coast Castle, one gets pestered here, when approaching the castle, by a whole bunch of youngsters, who all want to shake hands with you, then get into some kind of business, trying to sell you something, offering guiding services ot asking for supoort for their local soccer club.

At the castle gate I had to pay 40 GHS, thus the same entrance fee is at Cape Coast, only here I was not given a ticket. An aggressive, unpleasant looking official guide wanted to offer me his guiding services, but since - unlike Cape Coast - they are not compulsory, I declined and was quite happy to visit the place all by myself.

Besides the exhibition there are several empty rooms to be seen, but also the dungeons for the slaves. From the parapet are great views towards the beach, the lagoon, Fort St.Jago on an opposite hill and the fishing harbour. The architecture of St:George castle, as it was called by the British, is quite impressive, almost more so than at Cape Coast.

title: Let op!
text: Het kasteel met bijbehorende geschiedenis is uiterst indrukwekkend! Let op: ‘scam’: je stapt uit de taxi en voor het kasteel vragen mensen om je naam, vervolgens vragen ze je om die te spellen. 2min later krijg je een schelp met je naam (een gratis gift..), een seconde daarna staan ze met een lijst naast je met de vraag of je wilt doneren voor het een en ander. Pas hiermee op, met deze ‘gift’ proberen ze je in een lastig hoekje te duwen.

title: Sad history but very interesting
text: If visiting Cape Coast, Elmina Castle is a must see. Very sad history of the slave trade but interesting. Well maintained and we had a very informative guide. Well worth the admission price.

title: Tolle Führung!
text: Eine sehr beeindrucke Anlage.  Unser Führer Martin hat uns wunderbar informiert. In sehr gutem Englisch das auch Nichtmuttersprachler leicht verstehen konnten hat er die Geschichte lebendig werden lassen. Thank you Martin for this wonderful tour!

title: Beeindruckende Anlage
text:
Nachdem wir am Vortag schon Cape Coast besucht hatten, konnten wir beide Burgen gut vergleichen. Elmina ist grösser und „schöner“, wobei wir in Cape Coast einen deutlich engagierten Guide hatten und uns das Schicksal der Sklaven dort stärker berührt hatten. Hier war der Guide sehr lustlos und sein Englisch schwer verständlich. 
Nach der Besichtigung lohnt sich noch ein Blick in den Innenhof hinten mit einigen Souvenirläden. 
Bei den Jungs auf dem Parkplatz fiel uns Peter Cobbina auf, er ist sehr engagiert, interessant im Gespräch und hat uns eine schöne Führung durch Elmina gegeben.  +233556282740, P.O. Box Elmina 311

title: À améliorer
text:
Évidemment le fort St George est un immanquable et le poids de l'histoire impose une visite. 
Cependant, le fort mérite une petite rénovation à certains égards, il souffre la comparaison avec Cape Coast. Prix incluant le guide en anglais, visite en petit groupe durant une grosse heure.

title: If in Ghana-a place must see
text:
Smaller in comparison to Cape Coast Castle but definitely in a better location with three side facing sea.
How can a place so beautiful have such horrid history?
Sad historical monument makes you wonder why human are said to be most intelligent animal?

title: nice place, yet getting too commercial
text: the castle as such is nice. yet, half of the tour is shop hopping, through several shops that are spread throughout the castle, and that are interrupted by the really interesting and good parts.

title: Grim reminder of a terrible past
text: Like Cape Coast (well worth a visit), Elmina tells the story of slavery in Ghana - it's a grim tale of men and women at their best and worst, of greed, suffering, rape, exploitation and hope. People throughout the world can trace their roots back here and for many it must be a pilgrimage to come; for tourists like myself, it is a lesson and a warning lest anything like this should ever happen again. Get a guide to take you round if you can - it's difficult to understand the experience here without one - the spaces will mean little without knowledge of their true function as - for example - a parade ground for officers to choose slave women for their beds. For many, this is a shrine and so it's essential to have regard for the sanctity of the place. Thoroughly recommend - a must-do for us all.

title: Increíble!!!
text: El recorrido de la historia escondida de Elmina Tours es increíble. Recomendaría hacer esto según llegues a Elmina. Sankara dio muchos consejos útiles sobre qué hacer y dónde comer. La gira fue a muchos lugares interesantes y aprendí mucho sobre la ciudad, Ghana y la trata de esclavos que no hubiera conocido sin hacer esta gira. El grupo era bastante grande (sábado) pero hizo un gran esfuerzo para asegurarse de que todos pudieramos escuchar. También fue bueno poder decidir cuánto queríamos pagar. Recomendable 100%!!!

title: toccante
text: le stanze buie, soffocanti ed umide perfettamente conservate dove per settimane venivano tenuti gli schiavi mettono i brividi. In netto contrasto con gli alloggi dei soldati e ancor di più del governatore. Posizione bellissima. Tutto sommato, ben tenuto.

title: World heritage site
text:
This is rated to be the oldest European site in West Africa, established by the Portuguese in the late 15th century. Taken over by the Dutch and then the British, it was a major trading post for centuries, first gold, then slaves. The dungeons are chilling, as are the stories told by the guide. Your guided tour of the castle is part of the entrance fee. 

The building itself is attractive, with many stories, rooms and ramparts, with broad views along the coast and down to the beach and harbour. This is a significant world heritage site, well worth visiting if you are in Ghana. These are several shops inside with fixed prices and good value.

title: Elmina Tours
text:
You must visit Cape Coast and all the castles when you are in Ghana with all its hidden history. Please do this trip with Elimina Tours. Sankara, the tour operator is a great guy and he knows his stuff. The good thing its abosolutlely free but you can tip him what ever you want.

Highly reccomended

title: Bellissimo
text:
Un posto da visitare ancora intriso delle sofferenze patite e della crudeltà se lo uomo.
La struttura architettonicamente parlando e strepitosa sia la posizione sul mare che la costruzione in se
Una visita da fare assolutamente se si viene in ghana

title: Don't miss visiting here when in Ghana
text: If in Ghana, you must visit this historic site.  It is impressive in design and construction but certainly frightful in terms of it’s grizzly history.  Opt for a private tour to understand the design and function of this trading post turned slave castle.  The tour is in English and last about an hour.  If you also visit the Cape Coast Slave Castle, which was built by the British, you will appreciate the differences in this Portuguese/Dutch castle of horrors.

title: Free walking tours
text: I went to elmina castle some years ago I was very impressed. So much so that I decided to go again. This time I went with the free walking tour  with my wife and I was blown away by how knowledgeable the new tour guide was. There was no stone left unturned when it came to detailed information. I highly recommend that when you visit elmina, check out the free walking tour. I promise you that you won't be disappointed.

title: Very educational and moving
text: Visiting Elmina Castle is ABSOLUTELY A MUST!!! I learned so much from this tour about the side of slavery that is not often featured in history class. It is moving to see the place where so many people were tortured and died. The tour guides are amazing and take you on a journey. There are also toilets on site, which is nice. There are cool art gift shops throughout the castle, and these are places you are not pressured to buy (unlike many other tourist areas!). However, when entering and exiting the castle, beware of people trying to sell bracelets and get you to 'sponsor their soccer team or school'. They are persistent, which is frustrating.

title: Must see
text: This is an importaint part of the countries history and defentively a must see. Yet again non GH get charged quite substantialy more. The tour around the castel was very good and informative. An exhibition with more pictures/paintings would be quite informative and helpful in my opinion.

title: A faire absolument
text:
Attendez-vous à de fortes émotions...
Cela vaut la peine de prendre un guide (tous formés) pour une visite en détails

title: Orjakaupan linnake
text:
Suurehko linnoitus, jonka sisäänpääsymaksuun sisältyy noin tunnin pituinen opastus. Ennen opastusta vierailija ohjataan museorakennukseen, jossa kävijälle paljastuu linnan synkkä menneisyys.

Myös ruotsalaisten (Suomi oli Ruotsin vallan alla tuolloin) osuus orjakaupassa tulee hyvin selväksi. 

Oppaan opastus hyvä. Kierroksen jälkeen (tai vaikka ennen) mahdollisuus itsenäisesti kierrellä linnoituksessa. 

Käynnin aikana sisäänpääsyn täytyi tapahtua ennen kello 17. (Viimeinen opaskierros) Ulos linnasta pääsi omaa tahtia. Itse poistuimme vasta hämärän saapuessa. 

Linnan vieressä parisen ravintolaa ja normaalit turistirysät. 

Hyvä käyntikohde. Myös lapsiperheelle menneisyydestään huolimatta.

title: Must See
text: A must see spot. Not only is it a beautiful view of the water, but rich in history. Extremely sad, but eye opening about how slaves were treated, sold, and murdered.

title: Door of no return
text: Despite the horror history of the Castles that line the coast of Ghana, this is a must see in Cape Coast. The castle history is detailed in a respectful and honest manner. There are many guides around the place who want to help, but there is a museum inside which outlines the history of the slave trading routes from Africa to the Americas and Caribbean through to the Independence of Ghana. We spent an hour or so walking around the castle, which was well worth the visit.

title: Amazing place!
text: The Castle was one of the places that impressed me a lot in a long time! It has a very sad history and it is strongly recommended to take a guided tour around the Castle and you will hear the history of the case that built by Swedes but in different time periods belong to Danmark, Netherlands and Great Britain. Do not miss Elmina and Dixcove castles as well!

title: Slave fort
text: The whole world should visit this place. It is like auschwitz- a reminder of just how bad humanity can be. Just let it speak. Very challenging to black as well as white . The local black tribal leaders were as much involved as white traders. Won’t say anymore. The place speaks for itself. May it stand for a long tome as a warning as to what happens when we forget our humanity.

title: Lohnenswert
text: Wir haben Cape coast und das bastle als Tagesausflug von accra aus gemacht. Das war eine recht lange Anreise und Anreise, aber der Besuch des Castles mit der Führung hat sich gelohnt. Auch das Museum ist gut gestaltet. Schade dass im Castle selbst einige bauliche Veränderung durchgeführt wurden im Laufe der Jahre. So wurde der Tunnel zugemauert und die Tür ohne Wiederkehr gibt es nicht mehr.

title: Форт кейп кост
text: Мой отель находился в 200 метрах от этого флота. Я дошел к нему по пляжу, полюбоваться на монументальность стен и зашел внутрь. Билет стоит около 8$, можно взять гида. Сам форт не очень большой, но сохранился неплохо. Использовался как перевалочная база для переписку и рабов в Америку

title: A reminder that the Empire was built on blood
text:
Cape Coast castle is an impressively situated fort in the old capital of Ghana. The tour, by a very knowledgeable and thoughtful guide contrasted the claustrophobic, dark slave dungeons with the British governor's airy quarters.

Rows of cannon can be seen on the walls and the views of the coast, fishing boats and the town is worth seeing. 

The slaves brought from what was then called the Gold Coast were transported to the Americas and British colonies in the west Indies.

title: Should visit
text: There are a number of Forts/castles on the West African coast and some in Ghana, including Elmina, there is a Fort at Cape Coast half an hour away. This was built by the Dutch/British and is a larger fort. In 2009 Barack and Michelle Obama visited this fort and there is a commemorating plaque adjoining the entrance to the 'male slave dungeon'.

title: Life-changing visit
text: Cape Coast Castle has a shameful place in history. Touring the grounds was emotional and draining, but a must-do for anyone visiting Ghana. We took a day trip from the African Regent Hotel in Accra. We had a guided tour and the tour guide was FANTASTIC. He took us through the castle and into the rooms where the slaves were kept and tortured before being taken to America or the Islands. You cannot visit here and not be touched and saddened over this horrible time in history.

title: Chilling History Of Rape, Murder & Slavery
text: So much to say about this place... everyone needs to go here to hear  the stories firsthand. To hear about how African were taken from there homeland using this "dungeon" (not a castle) to aid in the process. Get yourself a guided tour here. Bring comfy shoes to walk in. And bring tissue...

title: Castle
text:
Beautiful, I recommend. I forgot water and I couldn't buy water, only souvenirs.
They plan reconstruction next year

title: Very Interesting
text: This  is well worth a visit, the guide who took the tour was very informative, also there are lovely views from inside of the castle out to sea and along the beach, it is pretty dark in the cells so you need to let your eyes adjust.  It is very moving when you hear about how the slaves were treated and the conditions they lived in before they were sent through the door of no return.  It was very hot when we were here so take a bottle of water with you.

title: Never to be forgotten
text:
Africa will show us many harrowing areas of the trans Atlantic slave trade. Cape Coast is such a place. It was so harrowing to hear the stories and see that the Door of no Return would separate families for ever....it touched me so much 
This horrific period in history must not be forgotten.

 P!ease visit Cape coast.

title: Worth a visit
text: Cape Coast Castle is well worth a visit, though be prepared for a stark reminder of the horrors of the trans-Atlantic slave trade - thousands of black Africans forcible removed from their homeland to serve as slaves in the Americas. The Castle is a firm reminder that such things should never happen again...

title: Cape Coast Castle
text:
Ghana is the land of the European forts and castles, as there are more of these trans-atlantic chattel slavery and colonial edifices in Ghana than any other African country by a country mile. 

There are several forts built to protect Europeans and their wares all over the coast of Ghana, but there are only three castles that remain till date: Elmina, Cape Coast and Chrisitianborg or Osu. 

The Elmina and Cape Coast Castles played significant roles during the slave trade. The Portuguese, especially, traded over eleven Africans from across the Westerh Africa region, while the British traded over four million Africans from all over West Africa respectively to the Americas  during the duration of the slave trade.

It is therefore always a form of soul cleansing to visit these two castles and as said by someone, "no African should live through life without visiting the slave castles in Ghana". The Cape Coast Castle for example shows how the Europeans lived and did business with the locals and their ilk and sometimes how wicked they were towards their fellow human beings. 

I implore all who can to visit the Cape Coast or Elmina Castles to learn some of the sordid things done to the black race by  a race that thought it was superior.

title: Beeindruckende Geschichte Ghanas
text:
Das Cape Coast Castle ist ein beeindruckend Ort, an dem man einen sehr guten Einblick in die Geschichte des Sklavenhandels in Ghana erhalten kann. 
Die Tour durch die Burg (Student - 30 GHC) dauert ca 1 Stunde und ist super informativ. 
Definitiv ein Muss während der Ghana Reise.

title: Cape Coast Castle
text: Never have a quoted another reviewer.  However, I could not find better words..."One can actually feel the anguish, fear and humiliation slave men and women must have felt in the dark slave dungeons. The slaves did not know any crime they must have committed to deserve such dehumanisation. Families were ripped apart, family history was lost, centuries old culture was lost and all sense of humanity was sacrificed for filthy lucre"  NOT TO BE MISSED

title: C'est La Boutique où faire le plein de souvenirs et de cadeaux originaux
text:
Cette boutique, située dans le Centre Culturel de Mindelo (expos et spectacles) prpose tant des livres, disques et petits tableaux) que de nombreux objets fabriqués par des artisans d'art locaux.
Et à des prix très corrects.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Good vibes
text:
Culture, échanges, convivialité.
L'endroit ne paye pas de mine et c'est ce qui le rend interressant, lorsqu'on gratte un peu, on y découvre pas mal de choses très intéressantes. Créer à partir de tout et rien, transformer, améliorer, associer, apprécier ce que l'on a et lui donner vie par amour de l'art. Je conseille cette courte interlude pour faire le plein de bonnes énergies.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Good local art shop
text:
Popped into this shop whilst wandering about. You could not see it from the street as its inside the cultural centre in a small room.

Once we found it we found a good selection of crafts from the islands so a good place to pick up a souvenir if you haven’t found one, or have not been to the island where a specific craft is made.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Expo de peinture
text: Lieu de culture ou théâtre et concerts ont lieu. C'est basique mais chaleureux, avec un petit amphi qui sert aux fêtes. C'est un lieu qui permet d'ew

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Действительно Арт!
text: Однозначно место для любителей арт-искусства. Инсталляции, картины и композиции несомненно не оставят равнодушными ценителей модернистского искусства. Хоть и недолго, но есть что посмотреть. галерея расположена в одном из первых коммерческих складских помещений города, построено во второй половине 19 века. к галерее прилагается книжный магазинчик и магазин с оригинальными кабо-вердийскими сувенирами. Правда некоторые картины и картинки неоправданно дороговаты, но возможно они написаны местными знаменитостями. Но что приобрести есть. Наслаждайтесь!

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: "Museum" of Temporary Caboverdian Crafts
text: Worth a visit and even shopping if something catches your attention; otherwise just walk around and enjoy what people hands can make and how far imagination can go - amazing use of different simple materials:)

text:
Bof. Il faut vraiment l'art à partir de récupération.
C'est plutôt une casse et des gens désemparés qui regardent le visiteur avec mélancolie.

title: moyen
text: quelques outils intéressants mais sans plus, peu ou pas d'explication, bref si vous avez du temps...

text: Les bibliothécaires très sympathiques, on peut emprunter des livres d'histoire du pays,   il y à de la musique, des concerts.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Recordações
text: Local simpático com artesanato e produtos da terra. Tem uma escolha razoável, no entanto, os preços são claramente para o turista com algum poder de compra. Merece a visita pelo espaço onde está inserido e com algum critério pode-se levar uma recordação.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Artesanato local!
text: O lugar é bastante rico em artesanato local, com produtos das diferentes ilhas que compõe o país. O preço varia de acordo com o tipo de artesanato escolhido, tem produtos mais baratos e bastante caros também. Os artesãos são bastante receptivos e explicam tudo com bastante paciência. Pra quem gosta de conhecer a cultura do país de visita, é parada obrigatória.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: пустая трата времени
text: Миндело- не дешевый городок. Что то оригинальное местного производства Вы здесь не найдете. Резьба по дереву, африканские маски-грубой работы. Видимо привозные и дорогие. Первый случай , когда не нашел сувенира по душе

text: Com uma variedade de produtos de todas as ilhas de cabo verde. Localização privilegiada dentro do centro cultural do mindelo com o monte cara mesmo em frente completando um cenário lindíssimo juntamente com a marina mindelo.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

text: Muitas tendas com um artesanato muito variado e com coisas muito lindas. Os artesãos muito atenciosos e simpáticos, com muitos artesãos a laborarem no próprio local a mostrar a categoria da sua arte. Um local que vale a pena visitar e tentar adquirir peças de muito bom gosto e a preços muito acessíveis. Gente boa a do Mindelo. Adorei a cidade e as gentes.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu
placeInfo.address: Ave 5 de Julho Centro Cultural Do Mindelo, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Stop here. You won't leave empty handed.
text: By far one of the best craft shops I visited on the islands. Beautiful handcrafted goods at fair prices. everything was made available from postcards and stamps to local liquors and wood crafted keepsakes.

placeInfo.name: Art D’Cretcheu

title: Nice
text:
Very interesting structure that is in wonderful shape. Its quite Portuguese as is resembles a structure in Lisbon. 

Houses a museum of naval artifacts.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Museo do Mar
text: Replica of the famous tower in Lisbon right next to the fish market. Inside there is a maritime museum with some finds that were recovered from ships that sank off the islands.  English descriptions only on the first two floors. There is a beautiful view from the roof. Entrance fee 3€ or 300 escudos.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Décevant
text:
La visite se fait en quelque temps. Pensez à bien arriver à l'heure d'ouverture pour ne pas rester bloqué dans les escaliers plutôt étroits.
Il n'y a que très peu d'explications, seule la vue vaut peut être le détour.
Les détenteurs d'une Lisboa Card bénéficient d'une file d'attente rapide à la billetterie.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: schöne Aussicht von der Dachterrasse
text: Der Turm ist an der Küstenstraße nahe dem Fischmarkt ein Blickfang. Das Museum ist einfach, aber es lohnt sich, hineinzugehen, weil man dann den super Ausblick von der Dachterrasse aus genießen kann.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: MIndelo's Museum of the Sea is a real "Must See"
text:
Mindelo's Museum of the Sea is a gem -- located in the repurposed Torre de Mindelo national monument (which was modeled after Lisbon's Torre de Belem), the museum chronicles northern Cape Verde's rich maritime history.  

Featured exhibits include such themes as whaling, warships, migration, bio-diversity,  aquatic archeology and even music!

The museum also offers for sale books, mostly in Portuguese, about Cape Verde.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Magnífico
text: Faz-nos lembrar a partida das caravelas de Lisboa….Cidade lindíssima. Gente hospitaleira. Parece que estamos em Portugal.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Kopia wieży z Belem k. Lisbony
text: Znane miejsce w Mindelo, przy nabrzeżu. Warto się przejść. Piękny widok na nabrzeży, łodzie, rybacy sprzedający świeżo złowione ryby, panowie siedzący na nabrzeży, rozprawiający, grający w karty, lokalne planszówki.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Tour de bélem
text: On a l’impression que c’est la tour d’un château qui est au bord d’une plage. La vue en haut de la tour est magnifique. Je vous conseille de monter tout en haut en une seule fois pour éviter d’attendre entre chaque étage. Près de l’entrée on peut voir les prisons et l’emplacement des canons

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: klein museumpje met goed uitzicht op de baai
text:

Voor 2000 escudos p.p. krijg je toegang tot het museum. Er staan enkele curieuze items maar ook foto's met uitleg over de walvisjacht, de oorlog, muzikanten, etc. Kortom een kijk in de geschiedenis van Kaapverdië

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: Pessima imitazione
text: Non mi è piaciuta, ammirevole l’idea, nonostante sia  il monumento più “grande” e vistoso nei paraggi è comunque estremamente più contenuto dell’originale portoghese.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde

title: En famille février 2020
text: Une petite réplique à visiter pour 200 Escudos en plein cœur de Mindelo. Belle vue sur les marchés de la ville une fois sur la terrasse. A faire

title: Museum
text: Der etwa 100 Jahre alte Turm ist kein architektonisches Schmuckstück, ist durch Einheimische durchaus belebt und beherbergt ein Meeresmuseum.

title: A not to be missed museum of the sea.
text:
A museum of the sea; with many old pictures of how the port looked , when it was an important coaling station for shipping. The history of the visiting whaling ships needing local people to work upon them.
Don't miss the fine views of the harbour and town, from the top of the building.

placeInfo.name: Torre de Belem
placeInfo.address: Avenida de Republica, Mindelo, Sao Vicente 2110 Cape Verde
